An amazing game with some annoying technical issues and a few much more major scummy things that hold it back. Basic issues:

-Nearly no graphics options (pretty much just motion blur is toggleable, no lens flare, bloom, etc.)
-Horrible defaults on upscaling, not properly setting to DLSS/FSR on Nvidia and AMD respectively sometimes
-No FSR 3 or even 2.2
-NO OPTION TO DISABLE UPSCALING
-Throw bugs
-Random added input delay bug
-Poor jukebox options
-Bad mixing/audio quality on a lot of older tracks
-Missing tracks, even ones from Tekken 8
-More minor things

More majorly, the addition of microtransactions post launch and plugging. Bamco and Harada have alleged that MTX is necessary as "online video games cost more to make and keep up than they did on PS2", yet if they truly felt it was a perfectly fine feature they should not have withheld its existence until a few months after launch. This was done to avoid negative reviews and bolster their initial sales (the most important period) and it was extremely scummy. Furthermore, the principle that MTX is necessary to keep video games online is ludicrous, and such costs should be factored in at launch. For $70 minimum with NO REGIONAL PRICING, and a guaranteed cash flow from all the future DLC, the idea that skins are necessary to keep the game up is incredulous on its own--but it gets worse. If you don't know how online works in games like these, you may be unaware that matchmaking in fighting games does NOT USE SERVERS. It directly connects you to your opponent through your ISPs and does not cost Bamco literally anything. The only thing that costs money to keep up... is the beloved 10fps tekken fight lounge. Allow me to word it like this:

Would you rather have all cosmetics and skins be completely free until the end of the game's life cycle BUT we have to bid farewell to tekken fight lounge, or have all skins and cosmetics cost money and keep tekken fight lounge? 

Would anyone pick the second option? Not to dunk on anyone who actually uses it, but does anyone actually go to the tekken fight lounge? It's so slow and feels completely vapid and pointless to me. Regardless, it's complete bull to believe that paid skins are necessary or should even be a thing at all in a paid video game, and the online matchmaking (99.99% of the game, especially now that most people are probably done the story) does not even cost anything to keep up. If they really wanted you to support the game by buying skins (you've already supported them with $70, remember!) then why can we not buy them directly? Why do they cost tekken coins, a made-up currency that will FORCE you to spend more? Individual skins will not be $4 if the coins only come in packs of 1000 (which they likely will), they will cost $10. Maybe $6 if they opt for packs of 600 (so you want to buy two) if we're lucky? It's shovelware mobile game crap in a triple A next gen full price video game. Justification for this in any way is completely asinine. 

And how the hell is there no penalty for ragequitting? It feels like crap when it happens, and only the dude who DOES NOT RAGEQUIT loses? Why do you lose your winstreak (which gives you more points when you have one) when someone plugs? How is this shit seriously still a thing in 2024?

Aside from that, the game is extremely good. There is a lackluster amount of stages and stage variety, and the base (we have to call it that now) customization is not anywhere close to as good as past tekken titles like tag 2, but that's pretty much where it ends. The story mode is great (shakespeare compared to Tekken 7), the music and music options is amazing, the visuals are very good, and the core tekken gameplay is fantastic from all the intricate movement to flashy moves to the new heat mechanics and more. The online actually mostly works too... we've finally almost caught up to online games from two decades ago!

It's great but held back by some miscellaneous issues and some really scummy bullshit. I'd recommend it from newcomers to fighting games and veterans alike even at full price, but damn please do not buy into this MTX garbage and just use the regular customization or mod something special in. If all the things holding this game back get cleaned up--which is 100% possible--I think it's a pretty safe 10/10. Right now, probably like an 8.5 though.

I honestly believe that this is a love letter to all fans of fighting games.  Tekken 8 provides many options and depth for any fan of the genre and with many modes to enjoy, it has some pretty epic replay value.  With plenty of fighters to choose from, you are bound to find a character that fits your play style. Story mode was a blast and was a satisfying way to end the Mishima arc and start a new one.  All and all, you getting this game is a win win.  Piece of advice, be patient and use the tools provided to you to get better. Tekken 8 has some of the most innovative training tools seen in any fighting game and will more than likely be implemented into other fighters.

You constantly feel cool in every battle. Over the top action. Easy to pick up too, and if you don't want to sweat up against people who don't use deodorant you can activate the assist amid battle to leverage things up. And if you don't want to use deodorant, it is still better to know how to play full-on against all types of players. The game has a lot of features that will teach you how to play, you can even replay battles and the game will make suggestions on what could've been better in certain situations

If you're angry about the Tekken Shop just don't pay for it. I blame gamers  for the trend of paying ridiculous money on aesthetics. If gamers didn't bother to spend money on this concept, it would have been dead years ago. Content is just excess crap that can be sold. I seek meaningful art like good game mechanics, new characters, new levels, additional fun missions. If you're a business, and you notice that meaningless content is making more money than thoughtful art, what do you think you will likely do? I don't want content, I want art that can offer me a different experience.

[h1][u][i]A Desperate Plea[/i][/u][/h1]



Harada-san,

I am desperate.

I am asking you for one single thing.

I ask you, despite already knowing deep within my soul what you're going to say...

I ask you, as a 25-years-faithful Law main, who has spent many of those years of his life practicing backflips...

I ask you, in the memory of the child I once was, who one day stumbled into an arcade at the beaches of New Jersey and spent all the quarters he had, trying to run the gauntlet with backflips only...

I ask you, in the memory of the weekend warrior I once was, who always kept renting copies of Tekken 4 and 5 from Blockbuster, backflipping along to the music in the Tekken Force and Ghost Battle modes...

I ask you, in the memory of the diligent student I once was, who practiced with both PSP and PS3, brushing up on his skills by maintaining triple-digit winning streaks, with only backflips, in ghost battles in Dark Ressurection, Tekken 6, and Tag Tournament 2...

I ask you, as the stubborn old man I have become, attempting with every fiber of his being to once again brave the trials and tribulations of the art of backflipping...

Please, Harada-san...

Would you kindly add a 'random stage select' option to the quick menu after a ghost batte?

And to everyone else, I have a different question for you...




[spoiler][b]DO YOU WANT TO LEARN MARTIAL ARTS?[/b][/spoiler]

Probably the best game (in general) in a decade. Gaming industry doesn't seem to care a lot anymore, so it almost feels weird to play a game that does. 

The game is full of clarity and the movelist has become informative, compact and very well sorted. This in turn makes learning much more intuitive than previous titles. The HEAT system is particularly great since it acts as an easy goal for beginners to build their gameplan around.

Other honorable mentions goes to
- The removal of the 2d bs characters
- Increased mobility and simplified inputs for movement
- An actual story mode
- In-game frame data
- Decent hitboxes on most moves
- Replay and a crazy ghost system
- Proper practice mode during queue

I've held off on writing this review because I wanted to see what I could possibly do to make the problems I am having go away. But before I get into all of those issues, let me preface by going on record and saying that I absolutely love the Tekken Franchise and as such have thousands of hours logged in Tekken 7 and a couple hundred at least in 8.
Day 1 launch fiasco (constant crashing) I could overlook as this release was big and the first time we got cross play in this franchise.
Day 2 was amazing. No more crashing and as perfect as you could get gameplay. 
Then came the first patch and that’s where everything went downhill.
I’m not sure what they did to “fix” the crashing but whatever they did makes this game lag like in online matches.
My system specs are as follows.
•	I9 9900k
•	RTX 4070 ti
•	32gb Corsair Dominator Platinum 
•	Samsung 990 Pro 2TB ssd
•	Gigabit Ethernet 
There is absolutely no way that this game should run as poorly as it does at 1440p.

From the atrocious online frame input delay, the rollback code that should be called fruit rollup code, and general overall poor optimization, I can’t in good conscience recommend anyone buy this game. Not in its current state. If you are like me, you are somewhat competitive, enjoy good clean fights, and can’t have a good time in a game where you need a lag input degree to compete.

The graphics are amazing, the characters are pretty good. It’s the gameplay at the end of the day that matters and as much as I want to thumbs up this potential masterpiece I cant. It’s terrible. Try again later. Go play something else for now.

The fact that people are giving the whole game a "not recommended" review because Bamco is selling some costumes is mindblowing. You might as well recommend that your audience avoid nearly all modern fighting games. I care about microtransactions when they affect gameplay. I don't care if they sell costumes I can ignore. Costumes will not improve your terrible movement, or your non-existent defense, or your shoddy execution. Once the bikinis inevitably start rolling into the Tekken shop, they will only distract you from improving those things.

TEKKEN 8 has 32 characters, great mechanics, top tier graphics and visuals, arguably the best fighting game story mode, good rollback netcode, crossplay, fast loading screens, character customization, the best replay mode, good tools for learning the game, stellar sound effects, great soundtracks, awesome stages. I could go on. The base game feels like it already came with all DLC unlocked compared to the other full price fighting games. 

The new heat mechanic is awesome. You can basically use it whenever you want for whatever you want. Extend combos, force mixup situations, defensive panic button, you name it. Every character gets wild new options in heat, and they're just fun to use. Though this also ties into my main issue with the game because the most powerful heat moves have too much reward for how braindead they are. They deal cataclysmic levels of damage while being massive mids and giving the user a mixup even when I block them. I expect many of them will be toned down in future balance patches.

Overall, worth full price.

Tekken 8 is a great game, heat has alot of potential to be fun and unique.  Offline content is better then 7, better animation with obviously more budget.  32 character roster to start in any fighting game is a blessing, and DLC characters are already leaked.  

For some negatives, some of the Yoshi changes are bad.  The flip went from a easily steppable unblockable to a easily steppable non unblockable.  Its low damage with horrible tracking, 0 reason that property should of been removed.  Flash is also brain dead now, you don't have to be frame perfect anymore.  In 7 is was more satisfying to pull off because it was a lot harder and more rewarding.  Asides for that the other Yoshi changes are really good.  The character episodes are pretty low effort, they all start with a boring tournament fight but for the endings its worth.  Also the story plot was a bit underwhelming, very predictable story but still better then 7.  T8 is also way more casual, you can get away with more in 8 then in 7 with cheeses.

As expected, Tekken still is by far the best fighting game in the market.

- Exceptional gameplay.
- Good netcode.
- Crossplay on release day.
- Legendary story.
- Banger OST.
- Outstanding graphics/character designs.
- Great customization system.

Rage art and heat does not create aggression. It's literally a waiting game Zzz. At higher level play there isn't much use for rage unless its for more combo damage, so you barely use it cause its highly punishable(considering if both players are waiting out for it)Characters need buffs and nerfs but that will come when more patches come out. Heat is too strong, considering heat smash does as much as a rage art. heat engagers and extended combos don't seem bad to me imo. Chip damage seems pointless, barely recovers much when fighting unless you are jun and you can recover just anything including regular health. if they are going to make heat powerful at least make it so you can get more health playing aggressive. This game is so mix up heavy you are never going to recover the health.

The single player is good for a tekken game. Not much outside of there. 

Once they take rage art out and create a few patches ill change my review. Always thought rage art was dumb. they don't realize most of the reason people weren't aggressive in Tekken 7 was cause of rage art, or at least it was 70% the reason.

That being said its a great game, mechanics feel nice and its a lot faster compared to Tekken 7. Ranked can be hairsplitting if you are trying to learn, unfortunately you really need to lab out a lot and figure out your character to do decent, and then later on learn a lot of enemies moves you need to punish as you progress. This game does have one of the best ways to practice and train compared to any other fighting game out there now. You can take control of replays and test out what you could have done better. Practice mode is also in depth with a lot of tutorials and great tools.

After 100%'ing the game, this is GOAT'd with the sauce Kazama style. Story is super entertaining, albeit short, and enjoyed it despite it being my first entry into the Tekken franchise. My only complaint is online mode seems to be not as fluid as I imagined, against wifi players. Overall, great game and I appreciate being able to unlock everything without microtransactions!

Tekken 8 is such a beautiful game. I played Tekken 7 for almost 200 hours combining the time I spent playing on Steam and Console and it felt great having everything upgraded in Tekken 8. They added crossplay so you can play against more people. The characters kept their identity with some adjustments to make up for the fast pace that the game now has. The rounds are shorter which causes more pressure each round to do something. 

I'm really impressed by the tutorials and learning resources they have. I recommend new players to go to the Arcade storyline because it explains most of the concepts to help you get better. There were a lot of hidden techs in Tekken 7 that took me too long to find and learn, but they explain so much in Tekken 8 that most of the gameplay makes sense (I haven't been through all the resources yet, so maybe they really do explain everything). There are easy to play characters that still have flashy moves so that it is friendly to new players to the series, and there are a lot of things to master for the loyal fanbase who played for years. 

You don't need an expensive contoller or arcade stick. I play on keyboard and I love it. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys fighting games. Beautiful game, 10/10.

As a longtime fan of the Tekken series, I eagerly anticipated the release of Tekken 8, hoping for another exhilarating experience in the iconic fighting franchise. However, my excitement quickly turned into frustration as I delved into the game.

One of the most glaring issues that significantly detracted from my enjoyment was the abysmal server performance. The laggy servers plagued my gameplay experience, causing frequent disruptions and making it nearly impossible to execute precise moves and combos. Whether I was playing online matches or attempting to enjoy the single-player modes, the lag persisted, creating an infuriating gameplay environment.

The constant lag not only hindered my ability to fully immerse myself in the game but also made it challenging to compete against opponents effectively. It's disheartening to see such a fundamental aspect of the game, like server stability, fall short, ultimately detracting from the overall experience.

Despite Tekken 8 boasting impressive graphics, diverse character roster, and engaging gameplay mechanics, the persistent server issues overshadow these positive aspects, leaving me deeply disappointed. Until the server performance is improved and the lag is addressed, I cannot recommend Tekken 8 to fellow gamers who value a smooth and enjoyable gaming experience.

In conclusion, Tekken 8's potential is marred by its subpar server performance, resulting in a frustrating and ultimately unsatisfying gaming experience.

I will change my review when some of the major flaws are addressed.

i'm a tekken fan and this game is a great sequel to tekken 7, that's the short of it.

[h2]i'll elaborate.[/h2]

[b]The actual fighting[/b] : i think it's really good, the heatmode is fun, the passives it gives are fun and create risk/reward, ofcourse tekken just feels so good to play, and doing combo's is fun.
the only complaint i have is being unable to decide if a move activates heat or not, i would have liked maybe HOLD to activate heat on hit, it often removes those moves on the movelist when it comes approaching the enemy if you don't want to use heat yet.

[b]singleplayer content[/b] : the actual story mode is about 6-7 hours long and FAR better then tekken 7's story, arcade story mode can vary from 4-10 depending on if you beat every single guy at the arcades or if you just rail straight through to the end.

there is also Super ghost battles that uses the surprisingly good AI learning mode they have so you can fight your friends or random people from all across the world forever and increase your rank.

then there is also the character stories and i'm so happy to see a return to form with these slightly short but very entertaining and fun little snippets of what the characters are up to, we'll see if they can keep it up with the upcoming DLC characters too.

i sat at round 27 hours after beating all the singleplayer content.

[b]multiplayer[/b] : the meat of the game, this is what is gonna keep you playing for hundreds of hours.
the online is not as good as street fighter 6 but far better then tekken 7's netcode, i can play with my friend on the other side of the earth and i get 1 frame of rollback.
if you'e having a terrible connection it's not because the game's netcode is bad, but it's because your wifi is dropping more packets then Amazon does in a day

[b]practice mode[/b] : this is where i live, i often just get fighting games to figure out the characters and do cool combo's. this practice mode is extremely good, the features that have been added are monumental timesavers for setting up situations and, for instance saving your position and state and being able to reset to it in a flash.
Watching back replays lets the game analyze it and give you tips on how to punish moves and then lets you actually practice it instantly which is a HUGE feature for people wanting to get serious with the game.

[b]customization[/b] : another fun part of any 3D fighting game is character customization, it's an improvement, quality of over quantity this time around, fabric sticks closer to the skin in most regards, the fidelity is obviously higher,  and you can color basically everything, compared to previous entries there are few items to choose from (i don't consider a T-shirt with a different picture on it a unique item)
there are misc items that you can put all over your body and you can get creative, but you can't put any item anywhere you want which i guess it to prevent people from making characters with D*cks

[b]Negatives[/b] : there are some strange quality of life features that have still not been added.

you can't host a tekken ball game online in player match, you have to go to the arcade lobby and then to the beach area.

no tournament mode, my friends and i like to run a tournament now and then, the tournament mode in T7 was incredible for that, but now we just have to keep our own bracket.

this is definitely a very personal take but tekken ball is not very interesting, it does nothing particularly well compared to games with balls that are also fighting games like lethal league.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2] : 70 euros is pretty steep if you're not planning to play with friends or online but you must put value to your own time, it's quality over quantity and overtime i have no doubt they'll add a lot more content.

TL;DR: 9/10 Tekken keeps taking Ws. Just wish we had a Capoeira fighter. Story falls into the old pitfalls, but surprised me with a nice change of pace I wasn't expecting.

Legitimately the only thing I dislike about Tekken 8 is that it launched without Eddy Gordo or Christie Monteiro. That's it. Everywhere else, this game does what a good sequel should do. Tekken 8 adds some new bells and  whistles to the established formula, and with just a little figuring out, you'll wonder how you ever lived without them. Old characters feel just like they should, new characters add variety and flavor to keep Tekken from getting stale.

Tekken Ball is back in all its glory, and it's incredibly fun to play, with a few new tricks up its sleeve. Tekken Force doesn't seem to be its own gamemode, but without spoiling anything, I think you'll find something [i]kinda[/i] scratches that itch if you play the story ;)

Speaking of the story (and only the most mild of spoilers ahead) [spoiler]I had a hard time enjoying large swathes of it because it's pretty much the same as it's always been-- one contrived dust-up after another that ends with you taking on a ridiculously-overpowered boss with abilities that you'd never have to see anywhere outside of story mode. OR SO YOU WOULD THINK. No, actually the game ends with a pretty meaty challenge, but it's against a regular fighter the likes of which you might see anywhere else in the game! That was a breath of fresh air. I'm still docking points because there were like 7-8 fights against the big bad devil boss leading up to the final fight, but still. Holy cow is it nice to face a final boss that feels like it actually belongs in this series. And to top it all off, there are multiple endings![/spoiler]

I've been playing fighting games for a while now, and have played a wide variety of them over the past few years, but with a few glaring problems. Before I dove into the Tekken series, I was playing other obvious picks like Smash Brothers, Street Fighter and Mortal Kombat, and in all of those games, I didn't know what spiking was until a couple of years ago, I could barely pull of a quarter circle or dragon punch move, I couldn't even hold a 10-Hit combo to save my life.

I've dabbled in Tekken since Tekken 4 and 5 on the PS2 whenever I visited one of my friends as a kid, and we'd play hours of those games. Then when the arcade cabinets for Tekken 6 rolled out in Australia, I only played those games at the arcade. But then Tekken 7 came out, and I wanted something different in a fighting game. So I bought myself a copy and went on the grind for hours on end, and a visit to Japan only reinforced my appreciation for the mastery that is the Tekken series that has become more than just a fighting game.

So of course, I had to pre-order Tekken 8, and Harada and the rest of the TEKKEN Project team has not disappointed. This game is easily the best fighting game of the year and I can't wait for the future post-launch support the game will receive. It retains everything that makes Tekken's combat iconic, memorable and fun while also adding in a few new features that set it apart from the other installations of the franchise. It's easy to learn but hard to master as always, but the Tekken scene is growing strong and finding new players. If you want something other than your typical fighting game, Tekken 8 is your ONLY option.

I'm not against monetization - but I am against how some companies choose to monetize. BAMCO has done a few things that are shitty.

[b]Announcing a Micro-transaction Shop 4 Weeks After Release[/b]
[list]
    [*]BAMCO knew they would get blow back if they had revealed this before or at release.
    [*]Cosmetics that used to be packaged into the base game are being released in exchange for Tekken Coins (more on that in a minute)
    [*]This is putting aside the fact that they are prioritizing the development of this shop instead of addressing major issues such as plugging (where players disconnect to avoid a loss)
[/list]

[b]Using Proprietary Currency is a Shitty Business Practice[/b]
[list]
    [*] The only way to buy anything is to exchange cash for "Tekken Coins."
    [*] These systems are varying degrees of predatory, since it's possible to setup the exchange rate and cost of goods such that there is always a certain amount of "tekken coins" left over, leaving you to either add more to purchase something or be comfortable with losing whatever change was leftover
    [*] Ideally, consumers should be able to buy goods with their credit cards for the specific amount listed for the item.
[/list]

[b]The Fighting Game Community is in Denial: Most Fighting Games Are Pay 2 Win[/b]
[list]
    [*] I can't believe this even needs to be said, but Pay 2 Win is literally anything that gives you an advantage over players that do not spend money.
    [*] In Tekken 7, BAMCO offered frame data - invaluable information for determining which moves are safe or unsafe on block - for money, which fits the definition of pay 2 win
    [*] Even more egregious is something folks in the community have just come to accept: in order to lab and practice against certain types of characters, you need to buy them. In other words, the only way to remain competitive is to pay money for characters even if you do not actually want to play as them.
[/list]

[b]There Should Be A Way to Earn Anything (characters/skins) By Playing The Game[/b]
[list]
    [*]Most folks would agree that a larger player base makes for a healthier game. The smaller the player base, the longer it takes to queue, and the more likely the game dies. 
    [*]Providing a way for players to earn items in game gives them something to grind for. All of the most successful micro-transaction based games (see league of legends and fortnite) give you a way of earning [b]anything[/b] in game with enough play time. 
    [*]This facilitates a healthy player base by keeping folks engaged and giving them something to work toward - and consequently increases the longevity of the game by giving people of varying skill levels someone to play against while also providing a larger base to monetize from. In other words, if the krill go extinct, there's nothing for the whales to eat.
[/list]

[H3]Now - for all the retorts I can see coming from a mile away.[/H3]

[b]UM WELL, GET USED TO IT BUDDY, IT'S JUST CAPITALISM[/b]
[list]
    [*] True, it is just capitalism and I'll be sure to wait before ever buying another BAMCO product
    [*] I'll also be sure to hand wave your salt when you complain about how much your landlord charges you rent, how little your employer pays you, all while slurping up BAMCO micro-transactions
[/list]

[b]IT'S JUST $3.99 FOR COSMETICS, WHAT ARE YOU, POOR?[/b]
[list]
    [*] A fool and his money are soon parted
    [*] I'm probably richer than 99% of you losers
    [*] But I also don't frivolously throw my money away
    [*] As mentioned - this argument misses the point - Micro-transactions in and of themselves are not bad. How they are done is what makes them bad. 
    [*] I love supporting developers that show a lot of love and care for their communities. Some of these monetization choices are at best incompetent, and at worst anti-consumer and hostile.
[/list]

[b]STOP BEING ENTITLED!!![/b]
[list]
    [*] Like I said - I don't have a problem with supporting developers and paying for additional content. Micro-Transactions in and of themselves are not the issue - HOW they implemented it is.
    [*] I'm willing to pay for additional content to support the continued development of games I love. Always have.
    [*] As a result, this argument is essentially attacking an argument and behavior I never made or exemplify.
[/list]

[h3] Final Thoughts... [/h3]

It is remarkable that people cannot hold two ideas at once in their head: that this game is a lot of fun and adds a bunch of features that are really neat (like the replay feature and labbing) while simultaneously criticizing the less than stellar parts related to the Tekken Shop.

I feel like the fighting game community has been so used to tolerating and taking shit with respect to HOW fighting game companies monetize that they have resigned themselves to apathetically accept that [b]This Is Just How Things Are™[/b]. Most fighting games have been straight-up pay 2 win the second they started offering advantages to those that paid money and its a shitty business practice that could be ameliorated by giving everyone an even playing field in practice mode.

I don't think I have come across any single monetization system that has been perfect. I've seen worse than Tekken 8 (see mobile games) and I've seen better (league of legends / DOTA / fortnite). Those that are better in my mind still have flaws (I hate randomized loot boxes when you pay cash), but again, at least there is a way of usually earning most, if not everything, by just playing the game. 

Overall, the fighting game community and tekken fans will get what they deserve based on whatever they are willing to tolerate. Perhaps their tolerance for burning their hard earned money and time is higher than mine.

I really like this game. The fighting is some of the best I've ever experienced, the characters are almost all interesting and usually have something going for them to make them enjoyable, the music is at its worst okay and at its best amazing, and visually it looks fantastic. There is a lot of newcomer accessibility as well, which I appreciate as this is my first time really playing a Tekken game. But there are some things to be wary of.

I've had some performance issues. Understandable ones, considering my PC is several years old now, but it should be noted that the game will run seemingly fine and then on occasion just crashes out of nowhere. 
The singleplayer/offline content, while done well, is relatively short if that's what you're picking this game up for. The only way you'd get more than around 30 hours of playtime is if you engage in online play, or spend a lot of time in the various training modes, like practice, CPU fights, Super Ghost Battle, or the replay mode.
As with most online games, the community can be kind of toxic at times. It hasn't seemed too crazy to me, but you'll find "plugging" on occasion in online matches where people will quit out of the game before they lose a match, which is very frustrating and doesn't count as your win and doesn't really penalize the other player (though you can report them and there's supposedly effort going into coming up with a ban process for people who do that).

The most glaring issue though is controversial. I, at least, expected an online store function to be in this game, and on launch there wasn't but now that DLC characters and costumes are coming out, an ingame store is being established. I'm not really surprised and frankly am confused at some of the outcry against it, but the main problem is with the approach. By implementing the store after the game's release, many people have bought the game potentially thinking there wouldn't really be microtransactions, but now there are some and the rating can get retroactively affected as well. It seems naive to think there wouldn't be a store, but I also understand that it wasn't conveyed before that there would be one, so I can kind of see both sides to it in that regard. 

At the end of the day though, I still heavily recommend getting this game. While some of the approach to microtransactions seems kinda shady, it ultimately doesn't affect much about the game, especially if you don't have issues with purchasing cosmetics in games, either because you have enough money to buy them all no problem or you have the control not to spend on them. It may even be a GOTY contender considering how good it is, though fighting games are still niche enough that I doubt it would actually be nominated for something like that even without the controversy.

Everyone hearing the quena and zampoña on the Ortiz Farm song knew immediately that we were so fucking back.

Jin has returned to the forefront of a new struggle, as well as a battle that goes beyond just the legacy of the Mishima Zaibatsu. Forced to reconcile his past and also the devil gene power within him, he finds himself dissonantly in the protagonist role once again. How does one tell a story that redeems a man that once set the world on fire and against itself? Remarkably, Bandai Namco comes full force with their best Tekken campaign by a long shot.

Gone are the terrible sins of 7's horrific non-protagonist and beyond lame narrator, 8 delivers all the hype of 7's final arc from the very beginning and rarely loses momentum as it exceeds it proportionately with a solid pace. Ignoring the many microtransactions and hazardous DLC ploys for those who did not pre-order the deluxe edition, at the very least -- it can be said that BN learned from 7 in regards of its singleplayer content.

Not all of the content is rich, per say, the juvenile near drivel of the cutesy arcade quest is adorable however. It is a glorified tutorial, but one of the first of its sort in a Tekken game that actually gets you to learn the game but also celebrate its competitive culture in a silly, albeit fun way. 

The actual story mode is beyond rediculous and falls hard on the tropes that were there from the beginning of the series. To critique anything seriously in Tekken's story is a fallacy in itself. The presentation of 7's solid story was absolutely abysmal and made it one of the worst stories in any fighting game as a result, despite having some of the best characterization in Tekken's history (as well as a satisfying end to one of fighting games' longest running rivalry arcs). Tekken 8 and the Character Episodes are a grand treat, however.

Both modes utterly flex the mechanical prowess of the engine and while the story mode doesn't always deliver on some of the things it promises, it cohesively nearing the greatness of Mortal Kombat's overproduced campaigns and I mean that in a very good way. That being said, the cutscenes present in Tekken 8 are truly artful, stylized, spirit filled and will not age for the next decade most likely unless huge innovations occur in the industry.

The game performs a bit poorly in its current state, but even Tekken 7, after a near decade of patches, chugs on my rig that can effortlessly play 2077 on high settings. Optimizing this game is some sort of magic us mortals will never know, but Tekken 8 will be very playable in the coming months, I am sure.

The character episodes are soulful, often hilarious and are great introductions to the characters for those unfamiliar with them. Tekken 8, narratively and setting wise, offers a lot to long time fans and newcomers alike.

But let's be honest, Tekken is all about the gameplay. And at first, I hated it.

When I got Tekken 8, I was still visiting Spain on extended vacation at the time and had the opportunity to get the full 'family on the couch' experience that is mandatory for appreciating Tekken at its best. And I have to say, local multiplayer in Tekken is still among the most unbeaten experiences one can have in modern times. Something about Tekken brings the young and old together and Tekken is both utterly accessible to everyone while also having an extremely high skill ceiling.

The downside is that this game is crushingly difficult at times. Tekken has always been a 50/50 dance of defense and offense depending on character and I've always favoured very reactive defense as a Tekken player. As a result, online and even IRL, I was getting absolutely stomped. Which was confusing, because I was definitely a high tier Tekken 7 player and had fairly recently played at a semi-competitive level with some local talent at a convention last year. 

Tekken 8 favours aggression, even arcadequest says this, that aggression is the name of the game. I spent many hours, utterly frustrated, that I was being beaten by cheap tricks and cheap characters (admittingly, King and Victor and even Bryan Fury can absolutely murder unskilled or non-adaptive players with little effort). I thought, briefly, maybe - I was finally too old for competitive fighting games.

That opinion shifted immediately when I remembered, this game just released and mostly the Tekken veterans are online grinding the ranked mode levels at this moment. You aren't just fighting a dedicated fighting game player, but someone who has cultivated Tekken skill generationally.

Tekken has been present in people's childhoods to their adulthoods, entire households have been raised with this game and started their own in-between releases. No matter how much adult life has separated some from these games, you can see the nostalgia and fighting spirit light up in people as they pick a familiar character they know by name and heart. Its incredible that even older generations, who remember the originals, can pick up and play, understanding the mechanics that have been passed down title to title. 

As far as fighting games go, Tekken is an inheritance. Like a wushu master that cultivates generations of martial skill through their family, I, too, had to tap into youthful knowledge and recruit my inner child to assist me in persevering through learning the new edge to this game.

Once I unlearned aspects of 7 and "got" Tekken 8, boy did I get it. I started getting ridiculous win streaks, perfects and had crafted an entirely new proactive defense play style with aggressive punishment, contrary to my previous method. The euphoria I felt, climbing the ranks and actually fighting people numerous ones above me with some relaxed ease once I became comfortable with the new flow and the combos of my selected character - few games will ever make me feel this again.

Much like 7, I can tell I will be returning to 8 for the next 8 years on and off. Socially, competitively or just for the sake of it on my own.

8 is not immune to some of the pains of the ever growing, capitalism-driven corporate industry of video game development - but for the price I paid for it, I'm happy to say I've gotten years of continuous memories and a new generation of skill-building has begun.

That being said, I absolutely can't wait for more patches and months to pass, when it will then be my turn to do some rookie-crushing, specifically the new faces to the franchise. However, in victory or defeat, they will inherit apart of my fighting spirit and with great perseverance, they will enter the Tekken family for life. Just as it had happened to me, so many years ago.

I've tried multiple times over the years to get into fighting games, it's been an ongoing quest for over a decade. And although I own a bunch of them on Steam, it never quite clicked for me. The barrier of entry was way too high, and almost every game required a multi-week correspondence course to even know wth is going on.

The win turned slightly with SF6 which was the first fighting game I played that seemed to actually care about the new player experience, and T8 now has enough stuff to get newcomers on board that I am somewhat comfortable recommending this to people who want to get into the genre, but could not before.

I will add one asterisk however, T8 is a very hard game to learn properly. Despite all the tools the game gives you, if you buy it with the intent on going PvP you WILL get absolutely bodied. A lot of your initial experience Online will be a 2 minute slideshow of somebody not letting you hit any buttons and punishing you if you do. I mellowed a lot now that I'm in my 30s, but Tekken is the closest a game has roused me to want to yeet my controller at the wall in the past decade.

If you're genuinely up for putting the time in, T8 is a great game to pick up. I still recommend engaging in some Online ressources to learn more fundamentals.

Tekken 8 is a phenomenal game mechanically and loads of fun, but the post launch reveal of a real money cash shop that utilizes “premium currency” on top of the already hefty $70 base game price tag is a scummy business move. 

To clarify, I don’t even really object to the existence of microtransactions in this game and would be happy to support the game, but gutting the free customization options compared to Tekken 7 and making the paid options filtered through Tekken Coin bundles is gross to say the least. Not to mention that the tekken shop reveal only came after the initial glowing reviews.

I’ll change my review if they walk it back or allow you to purchase tekken coins in exact amounts (and not bundles that force you to spend more than the price of a single skin), but I think it’s fair to warn new players of this bait and switch nonsense.

Longtime fan of this series, and don't get me wrong, this iteration of tekken is simply amazing. The combat has never felt more fluid and I feel like they really listened to the players to deliver what we've been asking for on this one.

However, what nobody has been asking for is their recent rugpull with adding capcom-esque microtransactions post-launch after reviews have come out and everyone has had their hands on the game. On top of the already full-price you pay to get the game, it's a shame that it seems like everything released post-launch will have to be paid for as well. It's no wonder that the customization items were so barebones at launch... And it sucks because what's present with the current customization is quite nice, but unfortunately that will be the extent of your fun with it unless you decide to pony up some more cash. What's even more unfortunate is that no matter how much the community despises this, there's no doubt that whales will fund this profit-model into perpetuity, making it seem like a success on their end.

Not even to mention that this will probably destroy the mod community for this game, as I expect bamco to crack down on those releasing free user-made customization content to the public if they think that it'll lose them a few dollars. But, time will tell.

As much as I love the game, there are still issues with it (primarily, the online: cheaters, pluggers, disconnection rate not working, some people having issues with their ping; also, balancing and bugfixes). 

Another reason for a negative review is adding an in-game shop with predatory tactics into the game 1 month after launch. 
The predatory tactics include
- in-game currency (most likely sold in packs that are either lower or higher than the price of items)
- selling nostalgia ($4 a pop)
- adding "promotional stuff" for in-game money (essentially, free advertisment for the people who they are collabing with, imagine wearing a white T-Shirt with "Cup Noodle" on it and then going online to play, bringing the eyes to the brand of anyone who matches up with you and then if you get to a streamer's match, all his viewers will get to see it, free advertisement driven by players)

The customization in the game is weak, even compared to Tekken 7. In T6 and T5 in was leaps and bound of what we have right now and it was done purposefully so that you would get to the cash shop.

Also, there have been talks online regarding Namcops going after modders and taking down any mods that would compete with their shop. 
Right now, after 70 hours of playing the game I'm sitting on 118, 000 000 coins of in-game currency and even if I buy all the in-game items, I would still be left with around 116-117 million units of it. It's worth less than dust and is pointless.

To add insult to injury, the game costs $70 on release and the Premium and Deluxe editions cost even higher. Essentially, they are quadrupple dipping (base cost + premium edtions/collector's editions, season pass for characters/separate characters, skins) and the fourth addition would be in-game advertisiment in the form of the dome inside Game Lobby with the arcades and avatars, where Michael Murray said it would cost up to $1 mil to advertise there. 

Shame on you, Bandai Namco.

The best Tekken has been in what feels like forever. Finaly a worthy successor to Tekken 5 (took them "only 3 games" to get there xD)

The unimportant things first. The Game looks outstanding, both from a technical view as well as from its asthetics. Probably the best Stages we had since T5, only Rebel Hangar is a bit boring.

Gameplay wise its still using the way Tekken plays since T6, but to such a refined Level, where combo routes make sense, tornado is probably the best bound we had, being somewhat of a mix of the classic bound and the T7 screw. There were a few changes to the movement, they reduced the time needed to recover from a backdash, allowing even beginners who cannot kbd to get a certain degree of movement into their gameplan. Sidestepping is stronger than in Tekken 7, however backdashing is weaker, on some characters more than on others.

The music is finaly good again.

Now for the bad part. Customisation is lacking again, and this week we learned why. Selling old, badly upscaled outfits for 4 bucks in a title thats over full price with dlc characters is a sad joke. Dont think that any of the money generated this way goes to the dev team, it doesnt. It goes straight into the bank accounts of the shareholders and only bamco shills can defend that bs. If you want to support the devs than just play the game, popularity is the lifeblood of fighting games. MTX are not, they are the lifeblood of corporate greed.

For the long version, I was going to give this game the benefit of the doubt and not tear into it like I did T7...but its absolutely unacceptable. I enjoy this game, and I want it to be good, but I will not encourage anyone buy it until Bandai gets their act together.

This game was made to coddle new players, every character has a safe (or even plus) on block panic button now, if not several, characters like Victor, Jun, and Jin are made to enable people with 0 actual game knowledge to beat players significantly better than them. A lot of the harder characters too, have been scrubbified. I'm not great at Tekken, but character cheese has let me pulled tons of undeserved wins, as well as pull wins against players with thousands of hours in other Tekken games. Pair this with the fact that Tekken is incredibly complicated and learning basic mechanics such as sidestepping  (because moves randomly have tracking, or some strings realign you with a person stepping you, and some moves just have broken hitboxes), and you'll never actually 'learn' this game...only have to beat scrubs, without having someone who already has thousands of hours in Tekken to help you personally. 

Also 'Special' controls gives people one button electrics, need I say more? Everything else about it isn't that bad but...really? 

This game is comically poorly balanced, Jun can turn her punishable moves into safe moves by taking chip damage (damage you can heal back) to herself, and can deal 110 damage with unblockable followups. Dragunov has boss character frame data, who enables a 50/50 on block, and even if you guess right and block he's winning because he's plus AGAIN, the only way out is to make a possible hard read but your punishment for guessing wrong is (you guessed it), your entire life bar in that case.

This game has no anti-cheat, or enforcement for cheating, this includes scripting, macroing for easy just frame inputs, boosting, and even ragequitting...ragequitting counts as a loss for the person who left AND the person who beat them to the point of leaving, whether or not you're allowed to get a 'win' is entirely up to someone deciding to DC or not when they're going to lose. You could argue getting a 'win' marked on a server somewhere doesnt matter, and I would generally agree, however this is still a game that costs 70$ and it should at least function as a game where counts cant be falsified. 

Thats just one issue, players playing their router instead of the game is a massive issue, every few matches you'll run into a player whose connection magically drops after taking two rounds off them, or even as blatant as WHEN ITS YOUR TURN and ONLY THEN. 

And the biggest elephant in the room, the thing that tipped me over the edge and made me salty enough to loudly complain about everything else...They pretended to have 0 micro-transactions on launch, but now a month later are adding a 'Store' to the game to avoid backlash from influencers and reviewers for having them in the game at launch. They're trying to have their cake and eat it too, and they think we're stupid enough to not realize. Its likely why the in game outfits at launch are lacking compared to every other title; they were taken out before launch to be sold back to us. Well, I'm only slightly mentally ill, so your whale baiting isn't going to catch me.

No more paying extra for frame data since it's now included. SUPER robust training mode that includes punishment practice, jumping into match replays, etc. Game runs great, feels great. The newcomers are awesome (Reina gang here), there is a ton of content you can do singleplayer/offline before even needing to jump online. Lots to like,

Online seems... okay? I've had some pretty good feeling connections, and a couple REALLY laggy wifi games (which is par for the course with online games; please get an ethernet wire if you are able to guys, it is SO much better trust me). I haven't played enough online against far away opponents to give a full opinion about the netcode but one REALLY stutter-y input laggy mess of a match is already enough to tell me that there are certain connection conditions this game's netcode won't be able to handle, so bear that in mind when you're choosing your online opponents.

**EDIT: After spending some time in ranked mode with the online, I can confirm the game does have functional rollback! Long distance connections should feel good on standard. Wifi will be a 50/50 unless you priorities fluidity (but please please PLEASE, if you can play on ethernet you should)

If you're coming from older Tekken games, this is Tekken all right; just pick a character, learn the new heat system, and you're off to the races. If you're new to Tekken, this is a great one to jump into with all of its casual content as well as great learning features

Set aside those other fighting games because this is the one!  Excellent mechanics, visuals, flow and game options.  Tekken 8 also has the most advanced practice mode ever created for a fighting game, including the ability to watch online matches for tips.  On the replay, you can even take control of your character and determine what you "should" have done.

They also introduce a arcade quest mode, which is very beginner friendly and fun at the same time.  They really nailed the ability for a complete newcomer to enjoy the game with some easy mode features.  With that said, this game has more depth than any fighter I've seen, and a person can really push the skill ceiling.

Once you get into your character, there's nothing like learning all the details of what moves to execute when, and man those online matches are competitive and fun.  The only downside is right now they haven't solved "plugging" where your opponent disconnects when they begin losing.  Luckily the devs just announced they are working to resolve that problem.

All in all, this fighter is a 10/10, easy for me to say it is the greatest fighting game of all time.

This game is incredible. The combat is pretty easy to pick up, pretty much just smashing the same button over and over again. The story lines that you find in this game are some of the best in any game that I have ever played. The world is also the most dense world I have ever played, it feels like there is more to do in one fight  then there are in other fighting games  combined. The character progression and options you have to choose from with gear is absolutely great and beating a hard opponent feels rewarding when you get a nice new rank to show off to your friends.

The game is something that is difficult to pick up, but when you get the hang of it and get some good satisfaction. It immediately becomes addicting and almost as rewarding as beating a difficult opponent. I found myself lost in these ranked matches, wanting more and trying to get even more powerful opponents.

I have spent about 60 hours in the game and I'm not even out of training mode yet. This game is one of the best games I have ever played.

Ну чтож , вышла новая часть серии теккен и даже с нормальной графикой и тут я подумал , а почему бы и не начать с нее.(главная ошибка за последние несколько лет) 
Ну начнем по порядку: 
1 - наконец-то нормальный визуал ,а то как-то теккен 7 посасывал с приличным заглотом у мк11 , но энивей мое знакомство с файтингами началось с мк1(12).
2 - обучение новых игроков . Хорошо сделано , думаешь что тебе все понятно и в принципе относительно легко , пока не зайдешь в онлайн))
3 - кастомизация. Сделать себе луфи и Сайтаму ну тут определенно лайк. 
С этим плюсы игры для меня закончились.
Началось самое интересное , я зашел в онлайн. 
Первые мои бои решил пойти в анранкед , думал поиграю посмотрю что вообще тут происходит и тут мне первым же боем кидает последний оранжевый ранг , он хуярит меня всем чем можно и я геймпадом в рука сижу и пытаюсь хоть что-то понять. Мои мучения закончились со счетом 3-0 и я подумал , ну бывает , и регнул еще одну и тут мне попадается гарью и хуярит меня абсолютно так же . По итогу регнув еще парочку ниже оранжевого ранга мне не попадались . Ладно, пошел рейтинг и наконец-то встретил таких же как я и начал совмещать теорию с практикой. Покопавшись в основах этой игры и освоив все мувы своего персонажа (Клаудио) быстро поднялся на зеленые ранги и тут понеслось. Я прохавал только маленькую крупицу как тут играю люди и мне этого было достаточно. Кто-то пиздит про баланс в мк1 , братья , вы еще в это не играли . Как минимум выделю парочку мои любимых персов - азусена , Кинг , драгунов , Ларс и Алиса . Встречая это говно в своих играх ты думаешь , а зачем я в это играю , пытаюсь учить какие оптималки и наказания , когда можно просто пикнуть какую-то хрень из выше перечисленных и мешить , не понимая , что ты делаешь. 
Отдельно хочется сказать про Лоу в этой игре , я не знаю каким нужно быть мангустом , что бы на них реагировать из просто надо угадывать) 
Персонажи с бесконечными миксапами (напоминаю что Лоу имба) , и если ты не знаешь эту серию , то тебя ей и заспамят и персонажи с бесконечными плюсами . 
Ебучие захваты наносят миллион дмг в игре где мид пробивает сидячий блок , это что шутка , так мало того не знаешь на что рвется определенный захват , готовься с постоянному его спаму. 
Бесконечные серии с лаунчерами и контрхитами , которые еще и выводят на нормальные комбо (у Клаудио единственный нормальный контр хит df2 имеет 13 кадров , но он одиночный))
Ну и хотелось бы еще отметить импут , да , возможно дело привычки , но вводить df db uf ud с это системой считывания кнопок превращается в меш по 100тыс. нажатий ради одного мува и про 1+2/3+4 тоже не забываем. 
Анимации ударов это тоже , что-то с чем-то, визуально отличить хай и мид возможно в 20% случаев , остальное ты должен выучить , молчим про паниши , которые должны вводиться моментально и ты еще должен знать какая из миллиона серий имеет подходящий для паниша фрейм , так и прием которым можно это сделать (с этим конечно же проще). 
Подытожим - если вы хотите потратить хренову тучу времени на изучение этой игры когда попутно вас будут чикрыжить мешеры и «старички» , можете брать. А если хотите переодически заходить ради удовольствия , то вам в покупке этой игры - отказано, потратьте их на более приятные вещи , от этой игры вы точно не кайфанете.

Tekken 8 had some giant shoes to fill. In the face of the phenomenon that was Tekken 7, Tekken 8 needed to be bigger, better, and more flashy. Is it bigger? Yes. More content, bigger story. Is it more flashy? Well, so long as you don't run it on a potato....YES. The graphics are awesome. The particle effects beautiful. And the sound design is AMAZING. But the big question is...is it BETTER? In most ways yes. However for right now the game is completely BANANAS in terms of balancing. Characters like Devil Jin have an instant, full screen, plus on block, leading to okie heat smashes. If that sounds bloated to you....it's cause it is. However stuff like this will matter little to your average Joe who just wants to play some Tekken. While the game may be crazy for competitive players, anyone who's casual is going to be hard pressed to find a better Tekken game.

Long-time fans of Tekken, like myself, have always valued the series for its rich and freely available customization options. This tradition was a hallmark of the Tekken experience, offering players the freedom to personalize their fighters in numerous ways without extra costs. Until Tekken 7, this approach was consistent and greatly appreciated.

However, with Tekken 8, there was a noticeable shift. The game launched with a surprisingly limited set of customization options, leaving many of us wondering about the change. The recent announcement from Bandai Namco about introducing microtransactions and an in-game currency for additional customization pieces has shed light on this issue. It seems the initial limitations were by design, aimed at moving towards a pay-to-customize model.

The essence of Tekken, for many of us, wasn't just in the combat but also in the creative freedom it offered. Moving to a model where players are expected to pay for that creativity marks a departure from what made the series so beloved. While the need for developers to explore new revenue streams is understood, the way it's been introduced in Tekken 8 could have been handled better to maintain the franchise's integrity and its relationship with the community. Tekken stood out in the gaming world for its commitment to value and player respect. Introducing these paid elements without clear communication beforehand feels misleading and undermines the trust and loyalty of the fanbase.

After careful consideration, I've decided to keep the game even though my first impulse was to request a refund. Despite feeling cheated, I still find enjoyment in it—but I believe it's important to inform others about these changes and let them decide for themselves.

Tekken 8 is a fantastic Fighting Game. It took everything that made Tekken 7 boring at it's end and fixed it. 

- Backdashing isn't as good, forcing you to stay closer to your opponent.
- Reversals lose to Hop Kicks, but Chickening is gone (more than a fair trade in my opinion).
- Counter Hit Throws (normal Tech Windows are i20-ish, depending on the Throw. Whilst Counter Hit Throws makes the Tech Window go down to i10-ish, also depending on the Throw).
- Chip Damage is a fantastic addition. Chip Damage cannot kill you. Instead, Chip Damage takes away Chipped Health, which you can gain back by hitting your opponent; Either on Hit or Block, you will gain that Health back. It really incentivizes you to get in there if you want to stay in the game. Rage Arts also take away ALL Chipped Health, giving Rage Arts some much needed utility. This can be huge for gaining an extreme amount of value for some huge comebacks.
- Heat is such a cool mechanic. For those who are familiar, Heat is very similar to Soul Charge from Soul Calibur. It allows you to play so much more aggressively. It even goes far enough to change the properties or Frame Data of certain moves whilst active. This allows you to go for new Frame Traps, or opens up the opportunities to set up Unbreakable Throws, depending on the character you're playing of course. 

I really feel as if the competitive scene for this game is going to be extremely exciting.

As for Single Player content, Tekken 8 has reshaped how you approach Arcade. Instead of you loading into matches immediately (although that is still an option), you're introduced to an Avatar Creator. These Avatars resemble XBOX 360 Avatars, which is very nostalgic for me. Although the customization is a little limited for them, it's extremely charming. You then follow a small story line, where you go to individual Hub Areas and play against the NPC Avatars in the area. It's really cute, and makes Arcade have an extreme sense of charm. The way that Treasure Battles work is when you load in, you just look for the NPCs who have a little Treasure Box next to their name. If you beat them, you get the Treasure. Pretty simple. When you beat the story line for this Arcade Mode, you're then introduced to one of the coolest things; Super Ghost Battle.

Super Ghost Battle is a mode that allows you to fight against... yourself. As you play the game, the game is compiling how you like to play; Your movement, Combos, etc. then gives all of that data to an AI. As you fight your Ghost, it will actively learn from you and pick up new habits as you go along; Your set-ups, how you play footsies, etc. It's really cool. It isn't perfect, it definitely needs a little work, but Ghosts are such a cool idea. As neat as this is, this alone wouldn't be so great though. What makes Ghosts so freaking cool, is that you can download other Player's Ghosts. If you're nervous about playing Online, either look up or approach a Player, download their Ghost and learn how to approach that person's character without the stress of just hopping straight in. This is an incredible tool for not only newcomers, but also for people who would like to learn at their own pace and take things one step at a time. If you're playing online and you just can't figure out that match-up, download that person's Ghost and really try to nail it down. 

Another way that the game helps you learn is the Replay System. Instead of just simply watching back your gameplay, there are mechanics built into the Replay System that directly help you learn! You blocked a move that you could've Punished? The game literally pauses and tells you what you could've Punished with! Got grabbed by a Throw and didn't know how to Tech out of it? Want to try it out yourself in real time to get a feel for it? You can take direct control of your character during the Replay and experiment to get the hang of those situations. This is so, so sick! What an amazing idea!

All in all, I feel as if Tekken 8 is an amazing game on it's own. If $70USD is a little steep for you, keep an eye on this game for when it goes on Sale. If you're a fan of learning Fighting Games, this is a definite must-play. The learning experience is beyond extreme-- Most would say it's too much. But Tekken 8 has truly made learning the game easier than ever with the tools that they provide you. 

I've been enjoying every second of this game, and I would highly recommend it.

The music is great, the sound is great, the stages are great. There's a lot about Tekken 8 that is great.

The Bad:

I cannot endorse you buy this game at full price because once again sleazy anti consumer business tactics have reared it's ugly head once again and the publisher of Tekken 8 Bandai Namco Entertainment have chosen to prioritise DLC and in game market places over Game balance and making Tekken 8 the best possible game it could be. 

Not only have Bandai Namco Entertainment decided to add an in game shop, they did so sneakily by waiting a month after release to announce that it would be added, very much tricking a lot of the initial buyers who might've otherwise given Bandai much needed criticism and backlash for this decision.

Players who have blatantly cheated since Tekken 7, even on stream, have yet to be punished and are at the time of this writing topping the leaderboards. Bamco simply does not care about competitive integrity in the online mode, only offline. We only got empty threats from Murray and Harada that cheaters would be banned but nothing has actually happened.

Another worrying aspect is the predatory microtransactions that are being introduced into the game. Bamco removes customization options more and more from every game, and Tekken 8 is by far the most barebones so far. Not only is the player customization lackluster, they have the audacity to one month after release introduce the "tekken shop", where you can buy "premium" scam coins with real money to purchase legacy costumes for the equivalent of 4 euros which were always free before. In game currency is obviously predatory practice to make more money of the consumers who already paid 70 euros for the base game, and they also clearly did not include this on release to avoid bad reviews on launch. They are even going so far as to copyright strike videos of mods for legacy customes out of corporate greed. I guess selling above expectation and having DLC on the way wasn't enough for the stakeholders. Well, here is my bad review for you.

I'm ready for my clown award because I am leaving a somewhat negative review and all the brown nosing, boot licking, dick sucking fan boys that have nothing better to do will be giving me some sweet steam points. I actually don't even dislike the game. I think the heat mechanic is fun and changes the game as they intended it to.

Let's start with pros. Jukebox for everyone. Somewhat improved tutorial in Arcade quest. I LOVE REINA. She is such an awesome new character and actually has lore and relevance to the story. Unlike poor Gigas, Josie, Katrina and Lucky Chloe whose only character development came in the form of episodes. I love how 3 is just basically movement and how she embodies a lot of Heihachi's style. Good design too. SKIP ABLE OUTROS. WHY FOR THE LOVE OF ALL THAT IS HOLY WAS THIS NOT AN UPDATE IN TEKKEN 7. 

EDIT: Story mode is actually very good and a huge improvement over 7 in every way. Character episodes are fine, but a lot of characters involvement with the story were superficial and not important. I was hyped to see Hwoarang, but disappointed when he didn't have any significant impact on the story. Still no brownie points for having a good story mode because one, it's not hard to improve over the trash that was Tekken 7's story and 2, any good game that costs 103 CAD$ has a good story mode by default.

I honestly cannot think of too many pros that aren't just expected of a video game at this point. Good balancing isn't a pro, a functional game isn't a pro and having online modes isn't a pro. HAVING FRAME DATA is bare minimum requirement. These among other factors constitute a bare minimum experience for people and do not deserve brownie points. 

There are a lot of cons and they outweigh the pros because of how prevalent/frustrating they are. 

Con 1: Input eating. This was really really bad in Tekken 7 and it's one of the main reasons I ended up not trying to get better at the game because once I hit Raijin, it became apparent just how awful the input eating was. I tried everything from different computers, controllers, keyboards, Bluetooth, cable and nothing worked. However, the input eating in Tekken 8 is not as bad and no where near as frequent. I could never pin down what caused it in T7, but I suspect it had something to do with the net code. How I mitigate/eliminate it entirely is beyond me and I pray to Harada it is fixed. 

Con 2: lack of offline modes. Story mode is a minimum requirement, vs is a minimum requirement, arcade mode is a minimum requirement for fighting games. None of these things constitute a positive. Tekken ball gets extra points for not being paid DLC. But seriously? The character episodes feel the same as Tekken 7. I'm not a fan of the new cinematic story mode and I enjoy Tekken 4-5 story telling much more, but that's a personal preference. Either way, a frequent complaint myself and many others had with Tekken 7 was the lack of offline content to wash the pissy taste of ranked out of your mouth. No team battle, no survival, no time attack, no goofy lore like Devil Within, nothing. Same goes for Tekken 8. Bare minimum requirement do not get any praise even if they are good. 

Con 3: DLC BEING ANNOUNCED EVEN BEFORE THE FUCKING GAME RELEASED R U KIDDING ME BAMCO. "BUTTT DO YOU HAVE ANY IDEAAAAA HOW LONG IT TAKES TO DEVELOP CHARACCTERRRSS" stfu. Then release the game later. We had already waited 10 years, I'm sure a few extra months to ensure characters that have been in the game since Tekken 3 wouldn't kill bamco. (I would much rather have an obscure character that has been forgotten like Bruce or a new character over Eddy as DLC.) There is no defending this, stop brown nosing.

Con 4: Lars and Alisa. No explanation needed.

Con 5: Azucena and French Noctis feel a bit like wasted opportunities. Azucena's gane plan seems somewhat unique, and her dodge mechanics are interesting. But a lot of her move set is recycled from Brunce, Josie and Fahkumram and I'd much rather have one of them over her. AND YES, that is because I mained all of them in previous games. Anyway, Azucena does have some unique moves, but they look hella dumb. I really, really, dislike dancing characters in fighting games. I hated Lucky Chloe, and I have Azucena's dancing. It looks dumb as hell. Personality is equally as annoying, vapid and void as Lucky Chloe too. The game refers to her style as "MMA" but it doesn't resemble MMA aside from the kick boxing/muay thai moves they took from Brunce, Josie and Fahkumram. Just looks like a hyper coffee girl who needs to chill out on the caffeine. Lackluster design too, could be the lack of personality/development though. 

My first experience French Noctis was really funny because I remember saying "he wouldn't have the b and b 2 spam combo like Noctis, would he?" Lo and behold I go to practice mode and DF2 and 2 spam Yeah, somewhat the same B n B combo. Not an issue though, most of his other combo inputs feel very unique and aren't copying from Noctis, I just thought this was funny. A professional Noctis player actually broke down the main differences between French Noctis and Nocits fairly well, but I still felt a lot of moves, animations, some combos, and game plan was recycled from Noctis. Which is fine,  I also mained Noctis and I'll miss him, so French Noctis is a nice addition, but feels very lackluster and not like a new character because of this. Not an extreme negative like with Azucena through. 

Con 6: Rage arts. I have hated rage arts since Tekken 6 and I still hate them. A big complaint a lot of people had and myself is that rage arts slow down the game. Having a one button combo that can kill if you're both low health sucks. Yeah, yeah, block and punish, duhhhh bait it out, duhhhh it's not used in high level plaaayyy, then why is it included? If it's such a bad awful, stinky, useless mechanic that only finds its use in low level play and high level play combos, why include it? Rage drives were the best thing to happen to rage arts, but of course those are gone. Rage arts are also antithetical to this games new aggressive game play. Uh oh, better stop being aggressive because they have a rage art that will kill you or do 55% unearned damage with one butttonnn. It's silly at this point especially when they claim and advertise Tekken 8 as aggressive. Rage arts are stinky.

Con 7: Crashes, save file corruption, random hitching when playing online. All of these issues will be eventually fixed, so not an extreme negative. But it adds to the shit pile. Edit. These issues have not been fixed ...

Con 8: Customisation is somehow worse with each game and now I can't mix and match different parts of their outfits with different pants, shoes or shirts? Come on, Bamco.

Con 9: Tekken Metaverse. The avatars are so low effort. Why no 3D models like SF6? God forbid a 3D game should have 3D avatars. Cheaper to make Tekken Metaverse I guess.

EDIT. Con 10: As I have been playing, I have been getting consistent crashes both online and offline. Luckily, I haven't got any during ranked matches, but I have during quick play.

Edit: Are you brown nosers satisfied yet? Added MTX store added after launch, I wonder why. Keep brown nosing though.

I'll start with the good. Definitely a very high-quality product. Generally feature rich, replays are good, training mode is good, and story mode is pretty sick. There's Tekken Ball and the Customization options, and the Arcade quest seems like a decent onboarding tool for beginners. It feels complete.

As always, tekken is an amazingly sick fighting game experience when you are playing against your friend you play against all the time, or deathmatch against a total stranger for an hour learning the matchups together. When you aren't bogged down by trying to remember shit about each character every 10 minutes, tekken can really come together for anyone. Sidestepping and punishing feels incredible, ducking a high and blowing up your opponent makes you feel like a genius, and the combos feel really cool and good to pull off. The sound design is on point as always, and this time around the camera work (the slowdowns, zoom ins on big counterhits) are fucking rad, and the supers are actually awesome this time around as well. Not to go too in-depth in the actual gameplay, but heat seems to be a totally 'fine' addition to the game. I can't speak on character changes, but sidestepping has been buffed which encourages players to actually play tekken how it's meant to be played, and that's rad too.

Unfortunately, there's still a couple pretty major problems. The primary one is that tekken is very intentional about NOT reducing the friction in going from low/intermediate play to high level play. One could argue that adding red/yellow/blue hitsparks to each move would only serve to save players the time and effort of going into training mode to figure out what type of move it is. It's so silly that moves from previous games have been changed from mid to high or high to mid, without the animation changing effectively at all. There's no intuition about it, which is why the additional friction of choosing to NOT allow the players to have that information is so frustrating. I'm a grown ass man, and even though I love the complex interplay you develop between two characters with 100 moves, I HATE the fact that you can't learn a damn thing in the heat of battle, and you have to stop your ranked session to go into training mode to see what that move was or did.

Hell, there's even some pretty easy solutions to this that AREN'T adding colored hitsparks. You could have "Go into training mode against this character" after a match just like in Street figthter, and would be practically no effort at all. OR a "watch replay" button, which also is in its entirely own menu.

It's wild that when you go into training mode/replay mode and change a bunch of settings (show frame data, go backturn, etc) that shit won't persist for the next time you go into that mode. If I spent 4 minutes combing through Dragunov's movelist so I can practice defending against various things at once, I should not have to do that again the next time I want to try it. Same goes for spectator mode, you shouldn't have to open up that silly menu to turn on the opponents inputs and frame data and attack level even though that's CLEARLY the reason you're there. Like I said before, it's just that little additional friction between intermediate and high level play that really pisses me off, because they're so close to greatness. But it's 2024: Demanding that your game be the only game someone plays in order to even be good enough to "play the whole game" feels icky as hell. Respect people's time, Harada.

Overall, this is clearly a good game. Tekken 7 was a halfway-decent game, and this is an improvement on all fronts. If you have no intention of really getting into grinding it competitively, then you don't have to worry about any of that friction stuff, and there's totally enough here for you to enjoy, so I'm comfortable giving this game a light recommendation. That said, if you consider yourself competitive, then you can also consider yourself warned.

Alright, giving this a positive review for the offline content that I can go back to years later. It's one of those tekken games that I will revisit just because of the ghost battles and smarter AI than 7. It is scummy that they release the tekken shop after release to avoid negative reviews for implementing microtransactions (remember when they talk crap on DOA for pointing out Namco selling frame data for 7? I still do, well look where we are.) but I can just ignore that, after all, it's just a company wanting to capitalize on the hype and popularity of their IP. We're familiar, every company has done it and tbh I'm not surprised at all. And, it's up to you if you're spending on that anyway. 

In the end, this is truly the tekken game for everyone. I praise them for including the helpful features to learn the game, they are appreciated. The use of AI for the ghost is impressive, not perfect but there's big potential there. The game is well optimized (find that guide to optimize the game further), runs 60 fps all the time for all stages. Just like everyone, the game crashes for me sometimes, been a problem since Tekken 7. Oh and they are not banning pluggers at all so don't bother using the report feature. They will ban you on the live stream chat if you keep requesting anything though which is arguably a more taxing process than programming something automated to ban pluggers temporarily.
