TLDR;
Huge improvement from Tekken 7 with a multitude of features on release. Lots of offline content to enjoy, with tutorials/tools to help improve at the game. Online works really well on launch with a newly improved replay system. Customization is a bit lacking. Arguably the best Tekken release to date.

Wow, just wow. Where to start? This is one of the best launches for a modern video game I've seen in a long time, let alone a fighting game. Tekken 8 is incredibly feature rich upon release with more to come. There are so many tools that help improve your game-play as a beginner and veteran alike, from the in-depth practice mode, punishment training, combo challenges, to arcade quest.
As an offline component, arcade quest is a great way to drip feed information of how to play Tekken for beginners while also introducing the new heat system for veterans in a well contained story of fighting in arcades making your way up to the world stage.
By the end of that, the big offline feature is the super ghost battles, where the game learns how players play certain characters and simulate them as a "ghost", which you can train and upload/download them to fight against.

As for story mode, Tekken 8's story completely demolishes the story mode from its predecessor Tekken 7. It's actually refreshing to see the entire cast interact with each other that makes the Tekken world feel truly lived in (yes, all 32 characters in the base roster have time to shine in the story, and many of the Tekken 3 original cast are finally relevant to the main plot again). Bamco has embraced the absurdity of the mainline story and cranked it to 11, and honestly it benefits from it, making it such an enjoyable ride and wrapping it up in a satisfying conclusion.

I'm surprised that online works as well as it does while also being able to support cross-play ON DAY ONE. The fights online have very little lag if at all and you can adjust your matchmaking settings to search for the best connection possible. One of the HUGE improvements to online matches is the replay system. You can replay a fight and the game will automatically pause to give you feedback on how you can punish your opponent in certain situations, then you can try it out by taking control of the replay to see how you can execute that specific move.

As for the bonus stuff, Jukebox makes a return, allowing you to customize what songs you want to play in every stage of the game, including menus. The fact that all the music from EVERY Tekken game is in Jukebox was an unexpected boon too. Tekken ball also returns and is more fun than ever. I think the biggest criticism I have is that the character customization could be better. The most in-depth customization can alter appearances is colour differences, which is mildly disappointing, though I wasn't jumping into this with expectations of Tekken 6/Tag Tournament 2 levels of customization.

Another criticism would be the value proposition of the game editions. Ultimate edition only adds avatar skins and customization options which is a bit pricey compared to Deluxe and Base. Even then, the value of the Deluxe edition could be questionable since it includes a year pass for the first 4 DLC characters, which is still a mystery outside of Eddy Gordo being the first one. Most people would recommend the base game and MAYBE the Deluxe edition if you really want the next 4 playable characters.

All in all, one of, if not the best entry to the Tekken franchise and can't wait to see how this game expands with more to come as we wait for DLC characters and content.

I am going to preface with that I am on disability for a mental health condition and brain damage from a brain surgery gone wrong, I am 33 and have played games all my life and being that I'm too sick to leave bed games are about all I got left, earlier this year I bought sf6 and mortal kombat and I put over 100 hours into both but the micro transactions disgusted me and were triggering so I abandoned both and swore I wouldn't buy tekken, then online I saw the game was released without micros, I thought to myself wow maybe I can actually have fun with a fighting game and grind out and earn and enjoy a full product without it being ruined by greed, so I grinded out 100 percent of the content in the game including reaching max rank just to unlock all titles, I finally felt like I had a fighter where I could just feel like a badass and fool around endlessly in arcade, now the company is going to suprise release the tekken shop and ruin the sense of achievement in the game completely and manipulative, corporate greed is destroying my hobby completely, this currently business model trend for fighting games makes what should be enjoyable probably the most unrewarded genre to play without opening up your wallet a million times, this is the type of shit that makes me want to quit my hobby forever and hope my illness hurries up and takes away my miserable life, I'm glad to say at least I know that all the ceos of these gaming companies will be rotting in he'll with their balls cut off and sewed up in their mouths

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This is the first Tekken game I bought at launch and decided to play longer than an hour or two. It has many beginner-friendly modes to ease you into the mechanics and spend time offline learning the game and characters without resorting to banging your head against the wall in a dry practice mode (by the way, even the practice mode is excellent and provides a lot of opportunities to practices moves beyond simply looking through the move list). Tekken 8's story mode is good fun if you care about the spectacle of Tekken, Arcade Quest is a good place to put some of the mechanics into practices against of variety of playstyles, the Ghost Battles are an innovative way to see how you play and find ways to improve, and the online mode provides fair match-ups that don't feel miserable or stressful, even if you lose. This is the time to pick up Tekken if you ever had interest.

I grew up in arcades, and Tekken 8 is the best fighting game I have ever played. It is everything I wanted and more. It is feature rich, addicting, deep, has amazing training tools, excellent tools to bring in new comers, everything. 

And all of it is flushed immediately down the toilet because the developers refuse to address a nearly 10 year old problem: plugging. There is 0 penalty for rage quitting in ranked-- in fact, you can break your opponents win streak just by closing the game. The message from the developers is loud and clear: you should cheat. All you will lose is your dignity, and people who plug obviously don't have any to begin with. 

I just cannot recommend this game until this shit is addressed. Tekken 7 at least they told you how often your opponent disconnected (this could be reset, but it required some effort), but there was still no penalty, so people did it constantly. It is even more rampant in 8. It isn't just a few people doing this, I get plugged on every third match. When I watch streams, I always see a plug. Its pathetic. 

I am not a developer or programmer, but games with way WAY smaller budgets have implemented systems where DC = lose. If you don't have a stable internet connection, this game is not going to be enjoyable for you anyway. There is just no excuse for this bullshit after so long. 

Fix your game Harada.

Matchmaking is the most annoying thing for me. I literally spend more time waiting for a match than actually in a match. When I do get matched, 80% of the time the opponent is either afk, let's the timer run out, or flat out denies. I've literally been matched 8 times in a row where one of those things happens. Make it so players who let the timer run out or decline are removed from queue. No point in letting them sit there in matchmaking only to *NOT* play the game. Really love this game. It will remain to be seen how heat played out but right now during the honey moon phase the game is really fun. The game continues to do what Tekken does best: offer a fighting game package in which there is enough depth that you can pour 1000's of hours into the game and still have things to explore, but is also accessible enough that new players can hop in, find a character that seems cool and mash away. Heat is definitely a powerful mechanic, but I was surprised to find that there is quite a bit of strategy and decision making surrounding how to use it effectively. The meta does fall into how well you can use heat so it is absolutely the defining factor in matches but how to use heat has some depth to it. I think that in subsequent patches, the strength of some heat moves will be tuned down, as T7 slowly lowered the power of certain characters over time. But I think we're in a period now where the game feels explosive and fun, which honestly is great for the first season of a game. Refinement can be the flavor of the game over a long lifespan, but the first few months-year I'm okay with being a slugfest personally.

To me the biggest drawbacks are QOL and optimization. Currently there is no benchmark to play online, so if another player's PC cannot properly run the game, the game will stutter. They really need to add a benchmark / recommended for online setting type of system to 1) reduce stuttering 2) not alienate the players on lower power PC's but instead guide them to the correct settings to reduce stuttering. There are many upscaling options but how they work are a blackbox. 

The other issue is the complete lack of infinite matches and poorly optimized user experience. FT2 in ranked is fine, but having player matches and lounge matches also be FT2 makes no sense. In a game as difficult as Tekken, it can be really difficult to learn match ups if new players are only encountering 1 character on a 32 roster every once in a while and then for only a 2, maybe 3 games at best. Also searching for lobbies needs to be implemented. I am part of a discord community and when we are trying to play with players in other platforms and are unable to invite via stream, it becomes a game of refreshing the available lobbies over and over until our lobby comes up. 

Overall, I love Tekken and I think this is a great game for newcomers and veterans a lot. If you go into this game with the right mindset, it's just the best.

I haven't played online extensively or really like tested a diverse range of pings or anything so I can't really comment on that. If you're Australian like me then all I can say is, I have dubious feelings about TEKKEN 8's netcode, it seems mostly okay... I have not played the game at 'prime time' hours either, so I don't know how many other AU players are out there. The few random times I did try and find matches I didn't find hardly anyone so it's possible Oceania is pretty low population.

This might be a problem for you, or, if you have friends who play, it might not be a problem. Depends on how you enjoy TEKKEN.

Online stuff aside, I am very pleased with the game itself.

The game feels different enough from TEKKEN 7, while being still very similar. I play Bryan, and he feels really effective and fun, all his best moves are still in there and he got a couple 'new' ones, or they're easier to execute or something. I've had to play all of the characters at least a little bit thanks to the story but also just because there's something fun to get out of each one of 'em.

The big change I think is, what I would say are improvements to the formula by the inclusion of 'heat'? Heat mode? Heat meter? It feels versatile in that you can use it to keep up pressure and keep your momentum going and you can use it to try and get your turn back. That much is cool, I'm into that. It feels like a refined version of rage drives from T7, which, were okay but I found myself not using that often. Heat in T8 is like something you can do in addition to your rage and you can use it at any time, and I think that's just great.

It does mean literally everyone has a meter of some kind now, kind of, for example with Bryan it means he can use Snake Eyes moves for free in exchange for a bit of meter when in heat mode. So that's sort of weird for TEKKEN but I'm okay with it. It's not at all intrusive and once you've used it a couple times it really is intuitive, it fits your character's kit in a way that makes sense and it fits the game seamlessly. It's not 'gems' from SFxT or whatever, it's not some poorly thought out additional layer to the game that gets in the way or has a weird meta you have to learn or whatever. It's still TEKKEN. I had my doubts at first but was quickly won over.

The practice mode by the way will just tell you if moves are plus or minus on block or on hit and by how many frames too, so, that's pretty sweet. I haven't spent all that much time in training so far but the little I have spent I learned a ton just by throwing out random moves and seeing what was fast and what was slow and what was safe on block and for how much, and it's great. Really pleased with that addition.

The character selection is decent, I think many of the important bases were covered. I knew we weren't getting Eliza, Geese, Akuma back and I didn't play them that much anyway or well, only really for fun, but I'm still disappointed. At least having Eliza would have been nice... and thinking about it actually it seems kind of a surprise to me that we got several new characters for T7 that are just not even present in this one. I feel bad for Eddy players, people who liked Lucky Chloe, and I'm disappointed that Heihachi is completely gone - Reina has absorbed seemingly some of his moves, hardly all. But anyway, overall it's 'solid' and the inevitable DLC will probably round things out a bit. 

Given how much work has to go into all these crazy HD new models and textures and getting the voice actors back and all the rest, like wow, how many more can they even do, or will they even want to do? But I guess we'll see.

On the subject of DLC & pricing I really kind of can't believe how aggressively priced the game is. I'm glad that they haven't pimped it out with extra costumes and that kind of nickel & dime trash, but wow! $105 AUD for the standard edition? And we know there's season passes - plural, season passes - coming, since they only promise like the first one in the big package or whatever. Not too happy about that.

The whole development of this game feels simultaneously really expensive and sort of cheap at the same time, expensive in terms of they have clearly spent a bit of money on a lot of CG cutscenes, voice actor talent, making all the highest definition character models and all sorts of that stuff. And I can only assume everything had to be made fresh after T7 because all the new T8 character models don't... look like the T7 models. So they just had to redo everything I guess. Once upon a time that wouldn't surprise me, really, but nowadays... anyway I suspect we'll be seeing them for T9, I bet that was part of the plan, they're thinking long-term, and that's what feels cheap. We have Lee, but no Violet, who was probably cut for time/money reasons. So, again, feels cheap.

In addition, if you see T7 outfits in customization, those feel like the materials aren't quite up to spec or match the nicer brand new materials made for T8, not sure on that, just an observation. And so, I guess I can mention the customization. The T7 customization was a bit limited, but in this game it feels so limited that I really am at the point now where I ask - why even bother.

SOULCALIBUR VI has great customization, in fact it's really impressive, they have a great huge focus on that as a selling point to the game and they make it all about that, and it's great. It's incredibly robust. They invested in that and it really shows.

And this is harsh, but TEKKEN 8 has customization that just is not good enough. It feels obligatory. These two video games shouldn't necessarily be compared in this way, that's not what I'm saying either here, but my point is that if you aren't going to put the effort in, why spend the money and the dev time on making it and making it not all that well, when you could have just made like one or two more unique outfits for each character...? That's just my opinion anyway. The limited customization I've done on my characters is mostly just recolor the outfits I like, using the unique, per-character outfits that are noticeably significantly higher quality than many of the generic options.

So yeah that annoys me too.

Anyway, aside from that, singleplayer stuff. The story this time around was... good, it wasn't as great as T7, it wasn't quite as exciting, it felt like very little happened despite how long it was, they invented a Tekken Force-like mode which I don't think can even be played at all outside of the story so I'm not sure why they spent the time/money developing it? And, the story ends somewhat inconclusively in my opinion, and only raises more questions that I guess now we have to wait for TEKKEN 9 to get answers to, so that's a real 'see you guys in seven years' moment!

The weird arcade adventure 'mii' thing was alright though it wasn't all that engaging, it was just like tolerable to sit through mostly, it didn't really have strong characters or anything, I am not altogether sure again why they wasted time/money on it. I assume it may have had something to do with trying to help newer players get invested in TEKKEN, to help teach them things. The best it was for me was, it at least help teach me what the new mechanics are and how to utilize them, because I didn't really pay attention to pre-release video or anything, I just bought the game on release day.

I feel like many players curious about fighting games more just need to learn to face the game with the right attitude which is, losing is almost better than winning because it means you have a new avenue of improvement to take, and TEKKEN 8 can show you your replays and you can at least look at what you were doing when you lost and before you lost and see where you went wrong and what the other guy was doing. That's probably more valuable to know about than, doing a 70 damage combo or whatever.

Overall TEKKEN 8 is good. Some flaws, but it's good. I'm happy with it.

Another strong showing for this series. Things are a little different compared to T7, but most of the changes are for the better and the core game still has all the appeal you come to know and love from the series.

BE ADVISED: Many prominent players have noticed a somewhat significant quality in online games when playing wired connections vs. WiFi connections, and I can say I've had similar experiences. If your wireless connection has/had occasional issues in other games like Street Fighter 6, it might be time to start running that Ethernet cable. Wired online feels noticeably better.

+ Looks good (unreal 5 goes hard)
+ Feels good (core game is fun asf, online works well enough to give serious time to)
+ Sounds good (this soundtrack goes nuts)
+ Strong launch roster (no 2D gimmicks this time around)
+ Heat system adds cool options that don't feel too overpowered
+ Plenty of modes and options to keep you entertained
+ Story mode has a surprising amount of variety
+ Character customization is awesome (fight anyone from Leon Kennedy to John Wick)
+ Jukebox mode is on all versions of the game this time
+ Ghost battles (an AI you train to fight like you) are a great new addition

- Story mode's plot is kind of nonsensical if you don't have old Tekken nostalgi
- Arcade quest isn't the best at teaching you much outside of beginner concepts
- Still no option to turn off some of the more annoying character customization in ranked
- Individual Character Story modes are a joke
- Not sure if there's something up with particular online matches, but when playing against console players specifically the built-in performance monitor starts to go red and the game can really start to stutter. The netplay is acceptable for the most part, but the code still needs some work.

If you're a fan, it's an easy 5 out of 5. I think the only caveat here is that if this is your first fighting game, it's kind of a doozy to get into compared to some other quality offerings for beginners out there right now. Still, if you think it looks sick and you understand there's some practice mode, YouTube tutorials, tournament footage (high-level Tekken is something else), and a LOT of online losses in your future, it's worth going in on.

Positives:
+ Crossplay.
+ Rollback.
+ It's very well made.
+ Has a good amount of content
+ Someone finally implemented the Killer Instinct (2013) Shadow Labs mode again,
+ Character customization has a good amount of options.
+ The Replay system has a really cool "tips" feature that pauses the replay to give you tips on how you could have played better at certain points - like telling you how you could punish certain moves and etc.

Personal negatives:
- Character customization has a good amount of options - many of them way too silly or ridiculous for my taste. Your enjoyment of that may vary, of course.
- Despite crossplay and a healthy population, finding matches take a long time and it's almost never against a proper opponent. Very different from the matchmaking of, for example, Street Fighter 6.
- Well... it's Tekken. It's a rhythm game disguised as a fighting game. Not my personal favourite type of fighting game. Has about as much player interaction in a match as Solitarie.
- Optimization seems lacking.

Most of the negatives there are nitpicks or just my personal tastes, so it's likely an easy recommendation for most.

Though I do am disappointed with the matchmaking.

I was initially very hesitant to buy this game - and many of my reasons have proven to be correct now that I'm playing it:

[b]Character models:[/b] Some of the character anatomy is just.. Really bad. Law's face, Feng's back (???), and the cold lifeless eyes of particularly the women in the game (its forbidden for them to frown or something I guess, while the men are allowed to look like they're at the end stage of a particularly bad Taco Bell experience when they're particularly angry).

[b]Particle effects:[/b] Readability is important. Even though it has Electrics and laserbeams, characters haven't generally had massive screen-filling wooshlines and trails behind their moves. I find the massive particle effects pretty ugly, but more importantly they clutter the screen and make it difficult to see what's even going on. The whole screen flashing with sparkles whenever a heat thing happens gets pretty tiresome.

[b]Mindless offense:[/b] Aggression was core to the game's design and the devs have been open about it. Even characters that previously struggled to open up defensive opponents have now been given 50:50 tools that strongly favour the aggressor. Throws have been made harder to break, rage arts are MUCH safer, and for most characters Heat mode gives you access to even stronger pressure tools. At times it feels like everyone is Josie from Tekken 7. 

[b]"I am here to interrupt your flow":[/b] Rage Arts were great fun when they were sharp and snappy, but anmations towards the end of T7 got longer - and they're now even longer than before in T8. Being in the middle of an intense match and then having to just go make a cup of tea because someone's doing their stupid super move is lame. 


While all this is true, I have still found myself enjoying Tekken 8. While the Heat system I believe is ill-conceived, it is preferable to 7's system where some characters had a meter system and others didn't. The game is still Tekken too, characters have the same complexity that you'd expect from the series, and the ability to self-express through combat remains superb. It's also where the bulk of the playerbase is now, so if you want the Tekken experience you've not got much other choice.

The stages are also worth a mention. Not only are they absolutely gorgeous, but this game finally introduces the Jukebox - a library with all the Tekken music ever made, which you can assign to each stage (and final round). This was only previously possible with mods (and hoping that someone had uploaded the music you wanted somewhere) so having it as an in-game tool is fantastic. It's a tremendous quality of life improvement, and has done more for my enjoyment of the game than any other feature.

Lastly, and least importantly, the story. Tekken 8's story mode is the worst story I have ever seen in any game - it was so juvenile that I went full circle from disgust to amazement. It is the filtered and concentrated essence of crap. I absolutely loathed it, and recommend it only to people who desperately want the 100% completion achievement, or people whose minds have succumbed to the anime rot. Buuuuuuuuuut it's a Tekken game - story was never going to be the reason I picked it up, and being upset about the story in a Tekken game is like being upset at the wine selection in a McDonalds.

At its core, Tekken 8 is a very competent and visually stunning 3D fighter with memorable characters and reasonably good character balance. I expect to be playing this for a long time.

Tl;Dr - game is actually fun, more fun than SF6 IMO. 8/10.

Ghost battles are fun and actually provide a lot of training potential, may it be your own AI ghost or literally anyone's in the world. You can find some replays from different matches and the game lets you interrupt the replays to teach you potential counters to that situation???? As each character has like 100+ moves from different angles, stances etc, it really does help you to learn a handful of them and how they work in a real match. As much as I hate learning combos and grinding it out, this has been one of the best features in any fighting game that I know of.

Soundtrack is mint af, legit no issues with it.

Story, no issues, it's Tekken so what's to expect anymore.

Arenas are nicely designed, pretty to look at.

Character customisation is good, they may add stuff in the future but as of now, it's sufficient.

Minor downside - best of 3 is really nice but everyone leaves after the first round? Win or loss? And after the match ends, you cant jump back into the queue again, you either go to the Lounge or the Practice vs AI. Bit annoying with the load times.

The biggest downside, as of currently, is the unstable ranking. Due to the game being new, a lot of vets and og players will be at low ranks looking to climb up, so get ready to get bodied 80%ish of the time. Quick play, as with any fighting game, will be filled mostly with high ranks. So have a really strong mentality for getting bodied A LOT and learning.


EDIT: Changed to thumbs down because for a new player, anything during and after the Orange ranks is genuinely the most mind numbing experience known to man, almost borderline League of Legends mind numbing. You'll start getting matched with Spanish people who cant afford a decent connection so good luck with the constant frame delays. And the 3-4k hours of Tekken 7 and god knows what else.

If you're looking for something to play without knowing what touching another human feels like because you reek of BO due to the lack of showering and eating, this games for you.

Before anyone thinks "oh he's just playing to win and not get better" then you're right. There's only so much improvement you can do vs bots and sitting there for hours on end getting 30% of my HP chunked off with 2 hits or thrown into some combo grab loop and dying, isint how I want to spend my free time.

I’m asking for a refund I know will be rejected, but not touching it any more either way. I have no problem with in game purchases on free games as part of their business model. On full price games I don’t like it but I can accept it if the game is feature complete and has enough content to justify its price.

Tekken was just that; I would have gladly paid 70 for what I got even if it had a cash shop. Or even if they said it was coming later. But to drop it after reviews so they can manipulate the perception is a bridge too far for me. In this case I can’t vote with my wallet because I was tricked.

I hope others do the same and just stop playing. This is a new low and if we keep playing into it, it’ll just get worse. I was even planning on buying all the extra characters in whatever pass or bundle they came out in because I wanted to support what I thought was a well done game.

Back to DBFZ, Strive and SF6 for me. Respect yourselves and don’t give them your business or online traffic if you agree with me. If not, enjoy what comes next, cause it won’t get better.

All in all this is not only a top tier Tekken installment, but a top tier fighting game.

In the realm of gaming, few titles have captivated players' imaginations and stirred their adventurous spirits quite like Tekken. Renowned for its intense battles and diverse characters, Tekken has often served as a catalyst for exploring uncharted territories and confronting mythical adversaries. Imagining oneself in the shoes of Tekken's warriors, players embark on journeys through caves teeming with perilous creatures, from ferocious dragons to ancient dinosaurs, engaging in epic battles that test their skills, courage, and determination.

The allure of exploring caves lies in the mystery they shroud and the treasures they conceal. However, in the world of Tekken, caves are not merely repositories of riches but also battlegrounds where the brave clash with formidable foes. Venturing into these dimly lit passages, players encounter a myriad of mythical creatures lurking in the shadows, ready to pounce at a moment's notice. Each step forward is fraught with danger, as the echoes of distant roars and the rustling of wings signal the presence of adversaries waiting to be vanquished.

Among the most iconic adversaries encountered in these caves are dragons, majestic beings revered for their strength and feared for their fiery breath. Inspired by the formidable dragons of Tekken lore, these creatures pose a formidable challenge to players, their scales impervious to conventional weaponry and their roar shaking the very foundations of the caverns. Engaging in combat against these mythical beasts requires more than mere brawn; it demands strategy, agility, and quick reflexes as players dodge searing flames and strike with precision to exploit their weaknesses.

But dragons are not the only denizens of these subterranean realms. Ancient dinosaurs, remnants of a bygone era, also roam the caves, their colossal forms casting imposing shadows on the walls. Inspired by the prehistoric creatures featured in Tekken's imaginative universe, these dinosaurs are not mere relics of the past but formidable adversaries capable of unleashing devastating attacks with their razor-sharp claws and thunderous stomps. Battling against these behemoths requires players to adapt to their relentless onslaught, finding openings amidst the chaos to deliver decisive blows and emerge victorious against overwhelming odds.

Yet, amidst the chaos and peril of cave exploration, there is also a sense of exhilaration and triumph that accompanies each hard-fought victory. With each defeated foe, players forge their legend, their exploits whispered in awe by fellow adventurers and chronicled in the annals of gaming history. The caves become a testament to their resilience and tenacity, a proving ground where they hone their skills and emerge as champions, ready to face whatever challenges lie ahead.

In conclusion, the hard battles in caves against mythical creatures inspired by Tekken encapsulate the essence of adventure and heroism. Through these virtual encounters, players embark on epic quests, confronting fearsome dragons, ancient dinosaurs, and otherworldly beings with courage and determination. As they navigate the treacherous depths of the caverns, they prove their mettle, forging their legacy as fearless warriors and masters of their destiny. And though the challenges may be great and the dangers ever-present, the thrill of triumphing over adversity and emerging victorious resonates long after the echoes of battle have faded away.

Excellent launch of a modern fighting game. 

Tekken 8 is visually gorgeous with a large roster of varied characters to thoroughly enjoy in both the most casual through pro level fighting. The storymode and other offline play is mashable for the newest of rookies while the skill ceiling is exceedingly high online for those looking for a challenge. 

Quite accessible for newbies too, for a fighting game. The very basics are taught well enough by the Arcade Quest, and the training mode is quite comprehensive. The movelists are as usual in Tekken very intimidating and long, but helped by the combo challenges and probably the best replay functionality I have ever seen this game provides every tool needed to get to grips with characters and mechanics. For everything else, there's always youtube guides. 

I can't say how it fares at high level, as I've barely gotten a bit over 17 hours in so far and maybe five or six of those went to Arcade Quest and the storymode, but I absolutely think it's worth the cost of entry. The matchmaking is generous and provides quite a lot of opponents with quite excellent connection quality, which has personally been a bit of a problem for me in SF6 due to living rurally and Capcom being far less generous with the matchmaking. 

If you're just after a singleplayer experience though... I don't know. The storymode has no challenge to it and while the production value is ridiculously high, the writing is hilariously bad. This story feels like a tween just tried to condense every Shonen anime arc into five-six hours of play, which I suspect is the intent. It's downright funny in its cheesiness. 

Highly recommended if you're looking for either a pro-level fighting game or just a casual masher. It's fun for everyone.

This game is phenomenal....

I come from games like MVC, MK & SF, I only played Tekken in the arcade as a kid, never really got into it. When Tekken7 came out it was crazy how much everyone talked about that game, however, at that moment I didn't care to jump in it. Fast forward to the end of T7's lifespan I started becoming very excited to hop in Tekken for the 1st time with T8...

I did not realize what I was stepping into....

This is so much fun it's crazy! It's been since the MVC2 that I've been this excited about a fighting game. The access to a massive move set is so nice. It gives you the ability to approach characters how YOU want to play them. This game gives you the freedom of expression with your character.

Graphics, amazing, don't even have to talk about them.

Stages, man are they awesome! Having "the ground of the stage crumble while you and your opponent fall through the sky slamming down into a hidden treasure room... all because it's the "final round!"" is so sick!

Lastly and surprisingly, I don't really care too much about the UI in video games. When people are crying it's amazing I'm thinking, "yea, it's cool." When people are crying it's terrible, I'm thinking... "yea, It's cool." The Ui in this game is great strictly for the color scheme, the customization of characters, and the customization of THE MUSIC!

Yep, you can allow the music of the game to shuffle through the playlist of every Tekken ever made... sounds kinda cool but not really a big deal right? yea right, it's a huge deal! I never hear the same song twice, I keep hearing so much cool stuff, this game rules.

You should absolutely spend your money on projects like this and with companies that build games like this. I'm all in!

[h1]Preface[/h1]
By no means am I Tekken master nor am I a fighting game maniac. But as a gamer who is familiar with almost every genre, I try to play every fighting game I can get my hands on. It's safe to say that I at least know the basics of fighting game mechanics and what it takes to "get better." In the recent years, with the help of my best friend from high school, I've had a chance to learn the ins and outs of games like SF6, Dragon Ball Fighterz, MK, and even some anime fighting games. As a result, the more I invested, the more I learned. The more I learned, the more I enjoyed the games. I grew up with the OG Playstation and Tekken 3. Now, 20+ years later, what a great time it is to be alive: to witness the eighth installment of the Tekken series.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
In the fighting game genre, I think we can all agree that if the game is fun, the game is already great to a certain extent. Back in the day, that's all that mattered. Now, we've got other categories to consider like amount of content, cosmetics, replayability, updates, etc. But let's face it: when it comes to Tekken, no one can deny that it's the legend among legends when it comes to the bare bones. They solidified the game and introduced the new heat drive(?) system. They went the same route as Street Fighter 6 in that they brought the "special style" for newcomers - akin to Modern controls in SF6 - to just press buttons and enjoy the game for what it is. Of course, we all know that this will only get you so far; and to really delve deep into Tekken, one needs to get the kids' gloves off and play like the Tekken legends of old (lol) to learn combos w/ manual inputs and understand what you're actually doing. Regardless, there are many ways to enjoy the game by whatever means necessary. The game perfected the Tekken recipe and it is indeed the best Tekken to play in 2024.

[b]Content[/b]
Two things that were noticeable: companies know that a lot of players are not as hardcore and excited to play online/ranked so it feels like they implemented a strong Ghost system for players to enjoy in the long-term, especially those who deem themselves "less competitive" like myself. When it comes to replayability, I think this is a good way to enjoy the game further past the story/arcade modes without stressing out about playing online. Second, the special style allows players to "see" what certain characters can do without lifting a finger, really. Well, maybe using your thumb to chain simple combos but it definitely makes the character bust out the flashy stuff on the fly.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[b]Story[/b]
Tekken's story is beyond disappointing, and this has been the case since T4. It's your average hero beats villain, angel vs demon routine that every Tekken has brought so far. No real character development, no real stakes. Just a Jin/Kazuya fest as usual. I have this lowkey feeling that the writers have this hard-on for making the Japanese characters look cool and have the characters that represent the rest of the world be their side pieces, but this might be just minor politics at play and wouldn't really bother me.... IF THE WRITING WASN'T SO SUBPAR. $20 says AI technology can do better for Tekken 9. Then again, every anime series post-2010 has had similar subpar storylines all over the place so.. I guess they just lack creativity and prefer to take the "safe" way when it comes to stories (just like Ubisoft).

[b]Customization[/b]

[UPDATE] Feb 15, 2024
Upon further analysis, the customization in Tekken 8 is the best in the FGC. Beats the likes of MK1 and SF6 out of the water. Still would like to see more accessories, as we had in the T6 days, but from what we've seen people around the world come up with these past few weeks since launch, the potential of creating various characters from different franchises is astounding.

[strike]This one's a bit disappointing.[/strike] Do they plan to release more accessories and outfits in the future? If so, are they gonna be paid DLC...? Case in point, the customization options that are available at launch are underwhelming to say the least. I don't know why I was expecting to feel more excited to see the likes of T6 and TTT revived. But I might have gotten my hopes up a bit too high. At least we can make LEON from RE4? Cyberpunk for Jin? A bootleg Kenshi from MK for Victor? GOKU FOR LARS?

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Final Verdict: S[/b]
Arguably the best Tekken game of all time, for veterans and newcomers alike. The biggest compliment I would like to throw is that in a game industry where we're used to companies releasing unfinished games to rake in the $$$, Harada and his team really took their time and sweat blood and tears to bring Tekken 8 to a near-perfect state before unleashing it upon the world. Also really looking forward to how Knee dominates the tournament scene once again.

As a longtime fan of the Tekken series, I eagerly awaited the release of Tekken 8, and let me tell you, it exceeded all of my expectations. From its stunning graphics to its refined gameplay mechanics, Tekken 8 is a masterpiece that sets a new standard for the fighting game genre.

One of the first things you'll notice when you boot up Tekken 8 is its breathtaking visuals. The character models are incredibly detailed, with fluid animations that bring each fighter to life like never before. Whether you're playing on a high-end gaming PC or a console, the graphics are nothing short of jaw-dropping, immersing you in the world of Tekken like never before.

But Tekken 8 isn't just a pretty face; it's also got the gameplay to back it up. The developers have taken the core mechanics that made the series so beloved and refined them to perfection. Battles are fast-paced and intense, with a perfect balance of strategy and skill. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, you'll find plenty to love in Tekken 8's gameplay.

One of the standout features of Tekken 8 is its roster of characters. With a diverse cast that includes old favorites like Jin Kazama and Kazuya Mishima, as well as exciting newcomers, there's a fighter for every playstyle. Each character feels distinct and unique, with their own movesets and playstyles to master.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of Tekken 8 is its online multiplayer mode. Whether you're looking to test your skills against players from around the world or team up with friends for some friendly competition, Tekken 8's online mode has you covered. With smooth, lag-free gameplay and a robust matchmaking system, it's never been easier to find a worthy opponent.

In conclusion, Tekken 8 is a triumph in every sense of the word. With its stunning graphics, refined gameplay mechanics, and diverse roster of characters, it's a must-play for any fan of fighting games. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer looking for your next gaming obsession, Tekken 8 has something for everyone.

First time playing a fighting game since like Tekken 3. 
Its a refreshing game that welcomes new and returning players to the world of Tekken. 

I am a huge fan of lore and story so its definitely refreshing to see a gallery short movie that sums up the lore series to catch you up to Tekken 8's story campaign. The cinematic are gorgeous. 

Finding a character you enjoy playing as and just learning how to kick ass with them is really fun. The game is definitely challenging with a constantly evolving AI ghost that learns your habits and becomes your in-game mirror to help you grow as a fighter. 
Little steps of progression and frequent breaks in between ensure that I wont get burnt out on the game. 

You can even customize your own character outfits and cosplays.

I do recommend this game to anyone that enjoys fighting games or even has a slight interest in picking up the game as a new player.

Having a tekken release without an arcade port first is something else. Everyone is learning at the same time, and it's a total blast. This is the best tekken has been in some time. Story mode is a blast, and arcade quest is a good starting place for new players. I spend a decent amount of time in singleplayer just having fun, something I never did in 7.

With the replay feature, learning is much more fun than it's ever been, and if you have a coach they can easily show you what you could have done in your matches.

This is not an easy game, but it's a game that I won't get bored with for a long time, highly recommended. (pls bring back mokujin, I miss him)

Tekken 8 is a reminder that i'm getting old because i can't see anything that goes on anymore.

Is it fun? yeah.
Is it spammy and overwhelming at times? yeah...
Are some characters cheap? yup 
Does it reward constant aggression? For sure.
Should the heat system maybe undergo some changes? Yes. 
[spoiler]Rage and Heat are more or less "comeback" systems, and although Heat can be a helpful for an inexperienced player, in the hands of a veteran, they're tools which easily lead to extremely one-sided battles, if you don't perfectly keep your guard up, which can lead to battles of attrition about who makes the first mistake, which then can turn out to be mostly fatal or allow patient gameplay with a player that can just outspace and spam the super moves that come out really fast and deal around 40-50% of life as damage, as a punish. [b]More times than not, you just have staring competitions until the heat bar runs out, so it kind of works against the pace of the game and what it the Heat system intended to originally do.[/b]
In contrast, Rage arts, despite their damage output, are only available when you are at 30% life. The only problem they have is that they not high-risk, can armor through attacks and can also be used as a punish against a player that throws out any attack.
Personally, even in Tekken 7, i never held rage arts in high regard, since most of the time, it's a get-out-of-jail-free card and the damage increase of rage, really should have been enough.
It doesn't help that the standard input of rage arts in 8 can be easily misinput'ed.[/spoiler]

Are you going to sweat in every online match? Definitely.

Offline modes for single players and customization are still lacking and i do not know if Bandai Namco are going to add more stuff down the line.
The story mode, arcade quest and character episodes are basic but alright.

Should you get this game as a newcomer to fighting games? Sure. Tekken isn't hard to learn, it's casual friendly but it's just incredibly difficult to master until it becomes second nature, then you stop thinking alltogether. 
But maybe get with some friends, throw a party and play this game just casually. Maybe just play the game for the sake of playing a fighting game or playing a character you like.
Don't get sucked into the competitive rabbit hole or the mindset; it will only make you miserable; This counts for many games out there.

[b]Honestly, just have fun playing the game and never forget to Ki charge. I do appreciate if you do that.[/b]

This is a pretty solid game in most aspects. But, since it's so expensive, I have to get a bit picky.

Basically what you are buying here is like a ticket for an event. The event is called "those first n months during which Tekken is in fashion".

The game, by its own, though, has enough features for everyone, and all features go from great to 'at least decent'.

- Online play is very good, with good lobbies and matchmaking and cross-play and anything you may want.
- Input lag is the lowest of all Tekken games, as measured by Nigel Woodall. In a game in which input lag actually matters.
- Customization is very good.
- Character variety is very good.
- Story mode is decent and well produced, especially for a Tekken game. It's cheesy, and funny, and childish, and extremely over the top from the beginning to the end.
- Graphics are... Unreal Engine 5, with its goods and its bads. It runs really smooth, otherwise it implements TSR brilliantly, and all the bells and whistles that you want with modern GPUs. It looks really good for a fighting game. However, does it look 70$ good? There's a demo, up to you.
- Ghost AI opponent remains to be seen, so far not very challenging, maybe needs more usage.
- Arcade quest mode... is decent.

In general, the new player onboarding has not worked very well. Very low % of players doing the arcade, tutorial, individual character story or whatever. Needs maybe more coverage of movesets, maybe more locations... more avatar customization?... don't really know the cause, but I'll just leave that there too.
Good old fashioned Tekken action, polished and refined.

Tekken 7 was so bad with a lot of reused assets from previous Tekken games, character models were reused from Tekken tag 2 & They were using dialogues since Tekken 4, there was some new dialogues tho but not really, reused assets from Tekken 6 campaign which due to the boring-ness no one played it to notice the thing except me because I was a fool aka die hard fan of Tekken, but in the end T7 was a low budget game & I had to accept it for what it was
7 years after the disaster that was Tekken 7 I expected NAMCO to get their shits together & this is what we got!
I have to admit, Tekken 8 graphic is a big step forward compared to Tekken 7 but still there was so much room for improvements, take a look at how MK11 & Injustice 2 evolved, characters are so lifelike in those games but in Tekken 8 they look like dolls, graphic looks good & bad at the same time
I'm not even playing other fighting games but just look at the difference between Injustice 1 & Injustice 2, or MKX & MK11, SFV & SFVI, you can notice the differences just by looking at them from miles, & It feels like they just remade their game from the bottom

Voice acting: Finally for the first time Namco hired all voice actors to redo all the voice-lines, this is not something that I should praise because it's their job, SF & MK doing this for every entry but when it comes to NAMCO before T8, they were recycling all the dialogues from older Tekken games since Tekken 4, in T7 they reached the next level & picked some random dialogues from T6 campaign to act like they brought new intros & win poses but they didn't, that made Tekken 7 characters extremely soulless & dead

Customization keeps getting worse & worse since Tekken tag 2, As a Lili main I wanted to get her Tekken 5 DR outfit but it was fucking gone, so many classic outfits are gone, how could you be worse than T7 when it comes to customization?

Models: although It's their job to make new models or improve the old models without reusing same models but I appreciate that they tried but somehow they managed to mess it up! looks like male characters are all so jacked, what's up with Marshal Law, Steve & Hwoarang? they all look like body builders, why are they younger than they were in Tekken 4 & why they look like dolls/plastics while were living in 2024 where in most AAA games you can't tell the difference between a game & movie

Animations: Yeah, they're still recycling animations since Tekken 1, Kazuya still has the same electronic uppercut since Tekken 1 from 1994

finishing a match against a King, sweating and crying, my breathing labored, visibly shaking, as i look up to my screen.
a victory.
but i felt no emotion. when you play against King, things like winning and losing become meaningless.

i only booted up online for a few fun and fair matches, eager to see how far my leroy training had gotten me.
but there is no fun against King. yet there is no annoyance, nor is there a sense of weariness upon seeing King's character art appear on the loading screen.
i take a few deep breaths before the match starts.
but no amount of deep focus or relaxation can hold against the wave of instinctual fear that overcomes my very soul once the announcer ends the countdown with that word.
the exact same word i'd heard in so many matches that i'd come to not even pay attention to it anymore.
but it's different when that barbaric mass of mexican muscle makes his presence known.
i couldn't possibly hear the announcer more clearly, it's like it was the first time i ever even heard the word, but i still knew exactly what it meant.
as if i was a meek peasant forced by an emperor to fight in a gladiator arena as punishment for stealing bread to feed my starving son.

and what is a peasant to a King?

what happens during the match cannot be explained in words, it's something that can only ever be felt.
it's beyond fear, the closest thing in our mortal realm that can be considered lovecraftian.

as the match ends, and i see my well earned victory boost me up by a rank, i feel as if i had aged an entire year in one battle.
was this how the samurai felt charging into a battle and witnessing a hwacha launch too many arrows to count, barely surviving the metal rain, and coming out on top regardless?
victory hardly matters when you've witnessed such horrors of war in the heat of battle.
a human made that, and it will only get worse.
humans evolve, war evolves faster.

Im gonna start with the bad: Customizing is lackluster, netcode can get wonky (i feel like most of the time its that people play on shit hardware, which is causing some stutters) and there is no Heihachi.
 Other than that this might just be the best Tekken game of all time. With 700 hours in T7 im not a beginner but neither am i really good at it (played a lot without learning, just goofing around).

 I was very very sceptical of the game the Heat system, chip damage and emphasis on agression, which felt like the opposite of what Tekken usually stands for. I can say that i actually enjoy all of it. The emphasis on aggression does make defense more difficult but its still rewarding. I dont feel the need to play rushdown, u can still poke and step to create whiffs and punish etc. The heat gives u more to think about, it makes me always keep an eye for my and the enemies heat-meter. UE5 looks splendid, and i havent finished all the "single-Player" content yet. There is actually some of it and with those ghost battles even people who hate online play might find some fun stuff to mess araound. And the Jukebox feature is insane, something id wish for more fighting games. Im positive i will spend hundreds, if not thousands of hours on this game. 
ps. Please give me Heihachi

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I have played Tekken on and off since I first encountered it in the arcade as a child. The variable characters, the 3d animations, the flashy hits, and the cool older kids doing weird stunts with a sword wielding ninja entranced me at first, but it was many years before I could actually identify the arcade game I had seen as tekken, when I discovered a copy of Tekken 4 at a friends house and played it while hungover.

Years later, I played Tekken 7 and was impressed but found it a little sparse. The gameplay was deep but understanding it required a dedicated pursuit and the tools that were provided were not really up to the task. You had to do research and keep notes and build actual in-game experience against others - but the netcode wasn't that good, so online matches lagged and irl play, well, it wasn't long before all my friends refused to play me because the basic mechanics of this game (lows, armor moves, backdashing, throws, etc.) feel like unfair cheating to someone with little to no mechanical knowledge.

Starved of good matches, I dropped Tekken 7, Now, Tekken 8 is here and it has arrived at a time when my schedule is open to it. Everything I could want is in the game - the core cast is essentially intact (though some will surely contest who is in the "canon") and the roster is an expansive 32 fighters with the promise of more to come (how many were in Tekken 4? 18-20? And I thought that was a lot to learn...). Animations and graphics generally have received a nice bump from 7 and the stages are beautiful, with multiple tiers to throw your opponents through (and now there are stage hazards as well). These stages are the best in Tekken history, visually fascinating and detailed enough that I have stopped in practice mode to admire the small details like the ongoing gunfight on the warzone level. The songs are all hypnotic bangers, and there is an option to use the soundtrack from any previous game.

There are a lot of reviews out there that talk about how this is the Tekken to be initated with, with all the improved practice tools and tutorials and that is all true. The game does what it can to put you on a conveyor belt to competence which is great, since it has produced a bumper crop of new players for a franchise that richly deserves them. 

This however should not overshadow the fact that this is a great Tekken. I really enjoy the new heat system, it has added a new element of intensity to matches and meshes decently well with the older rage system. The special moves that each character has with heat really add speed and style to fights. I am not wild about the continued inclusion of rage arts but this could be personal bias - they are a cheap equalizer for less experienced players when a veteran forgets about them. I still think this game represents a further refinement of everything the devs learned from 7 and matches feel great to play, even after several hundred in a row.

Also helping this tekken is the introduction of cross platform play and better netcode. Matches will still lag from time to time but it's almost always a more reliable experience than 7.

This is the one to get if you are new and the one if you are old. Just pick it up, so we can all plaay together.

Could be the worst TEKKEN game I've ever played.

In Bandai Namco's quest to increase aggression, they've completely neutered the systems and neutral that define TEKKEN.

Out with poking, timing mix-ups, and footsies. In with forced unearned mix-ups on block, and non-stop immediate timing responses.

With no adequate defensive systems to balance out the offensive ones, the game has devolved into a chaotic mess of who can oppress the other player with their buttons more. And it's lead to this game having a clear top 8 characters at launch, that are almost untouchable.

It's a gorgeous game, has a fantastic story mode, and is loaded with features. But the game-play that underpins it is a bastardised version of the series.

As a long time loyal TEKKEN player, I can honestly say, this goes right alongside TEKKEN Tag 2 as the most volatile, stressful, un-fun TEKKEN game ever made.

In addition to the game-play being volatile, it's still full of bugs that can crash the game outright, and it also has a lobby system that is so bad in makes Arc System Works blush. 

Hoping the game gets better in future updates, but I will not be holding my breath.

I’ve played Tekken since T2, and I always felt that the fights were always a 50/50 split of aggression and defence, Tekken 8 has shoe-horned in new systems and changed the balance to openly favour aggression. 

The heat system incentives and rewards high-pressure and all out-aggression play, and actively punishes and disincentives defensive styles. 

I feel that there is fundamentally something wrong with the core of Tekken 8, which I don’t feel can be fixed without a significant overhaul.

The overall presentation and content of Tekken 8 is great; sound, visuals, single player content, training mode (wanted to mention the ghost and replays here specifically as being next level good) are absolutely fantastic.

So far the best Tekken game when it first released. Devs really put in a lot of their budget in the development of this game; it has a lot of single player content aside from the online mode. What's more - this iteration of Tekken is well-suited for beginners due to the plethora of tutorials and assist options in the game. If you wanted to start playing fighting games, trust me when I say buying this game would be a good start.

My immediate impression of the game at 14 hours is to not recommend it. I am hoping to change my review from negative to positive over the future span of the game, as i have every intention to continue playing. 

Tekken 8 has a lot of strong points, such as the graphics and new balancing, that so far seem to be much better in comparison to Tekken 7. I am personally not a fan of the music in the game and think its perhaps one of the absolute weakest points of the game, but the addition of the jukebox that allows you to turn on music from the previous games is an awesome feature. 

Whether or not you are new to Tekken, a casual player of the previous games, or someone who has grinded the game a lot in the past, i would like to strongly caution you against picking up this game if you might feel as i do. While the balancing seems overall better than prior games, in what feels like an attempt to endear itself to a more casual audience, the game has been made ridiculously spammy. It seems like every single match online is just strings upon strings upon strings of combos that chain into each other, where you just have to patiently wait for the spamming to end before its your turn. 

This is particularly noticeable with some of the new characters, that seem to be especially safe and easy to use, that you have to pay extra in order to get access to. I imagine this is exactly the same as they attempted to do with Tekken 7, where dlc characters were introduced with very clear examples of power-creep, likely as a tactic to give incentive to purchase the dlc characters. Much of this was patched and balanced later on of course, and i imagine they are going to do the exact same thing here. 

Most of this strings that people constantly spam online have ways around them, like sidestepping, crouching and punishing, etc. But often these windows of opportunity are incredibly small for online play where latency shortens your window of opportunity. Which translates to a very poor online experience, although the game DEFINITIVELY performs better as an experience for offline play. So i am eager to see how it performs in tournaments as a spectator. But so far over the 14 hours of online play that i have had, every match goes the same, all the way up to purple ranks. Every match is just strings upon strings getting spammed constantly, while you patiently wait for your turn to begin, as your opponent continues to spam while pushing you towards the other end of the planet. 

Certain characters, like Jun, also has incredibly colorful moves that just paints your entire screen with distracting colors and "Christmas lights", making it hard to see what is even going on. And she is not the only character with this feature either.

TLDR; Tekken has become incredibly spammy in pursuit of accessibility, music is subpar, visuals are cluttering and distracting mid-fight, but the game is overall far, far better for offline play than it is online. 

Also, you do not play because of the story. It is nonsensical and incoherent, but honestly unimportant for your enjoyment of the game.

Tekken 8 is the first fighting game I've meaningfully put any effort into, and I'm absolutely obsessed with this game. The characters are even cooler than I remember them from Tekken 5, they have so much identity, and look stunning in Unreal Engine 5. Compared to Street Fighter 6, it feels like combos are a lot easier to string together, and the combo system provides a great degree of creativity/versatility. That said, it also feels like Tekken 8 is a whole lot more complicated than Street Fighter 6, given the fact that its 3D, which is a blessing and a curse. It can be very daunting getting to learn what moves to duck, which to sidestep and how to punish each of the 32 characters, when everyone has at least 100 moves in the movelist. But on the other hand this provides nearly infinite gameplay value, because there's always more to learn.
On the topic of learning, Tekken 8 provides more tools for practicing than I've seen in both Street Fighter and Mortal Kombat. The highlight here is the ability to go and watch replays of your own matches, where the game gives you tips and feedback on which basic combos to use or which moves can punish the opponents offence. This combined with the ability to download "ghosts" of your opponents, which mimic their playstyle, create the best basis for leaning in any fighting game, in my opinion.
Oh yeah and the game is really content complete too, moreso than its competitors. You have story mode, arcade quest (cutesy storymode/tutorial), tekken ball, character stories, jukebox with all the previous tekken music, and an online lounge mode.

This is the best way to start playing fighting games!

This game feels really feature complete. There's a fun and silly story that I was able to get through in a day thanks to the good 'ol simple combo option available. It was much more engaging than what was in Tekken 7. It's a little short, and I'd love DLC, because the set dressing and production value is incredible.

And, hot dang, there is two especially important additions that I feel would've been super welcome in Tekken 7. First, the adventure mode that acts like a story, but is filled with tutorials. It got me learning about the new Heat system early on. And second, I dig the updated replay system - pretty goated. It's helped me learn about some enemy strings that I would've otherwise kept challenging and getting launched for, and let's me play right away to learn counters while it's fresh in memory. In the olden days, it would've been Uncle YouTube with my ass just to learn what a power crush was. Now, I feel like a complete beginner has some good resources to learn and get some wins. And the pool of characters is also much smaller than Tekken 7, so I feel like the rate at which I'm learning matchups is way faster.

The online play feels awesome on ethernet. I feel addicted to quickplay, man. This game for me is the epitome of "one more game" mentality. Sure, getting wooped by someone with a way higher skill level is rough - especially if I feel like I'm not learning anything. But, a good chunk of the games, regardless of rank, are exciting. I love the new default best-of-3 rematch system. Because those 3rd games that get to the Final Round, and the last 10% health on both sides; nothing beats that rush. I'm slowly but surely climbing the ladder in ranked. My one  It's pretty cheap that someone can unplug on ranked when they lose. I eat the L's lol, but I feel the game should be able to calculate who was going to win, especially during a rage art cutscene.

I don't play a ton of games, or for that long, but I've logged around 120 hours in the last year of Tekken 7, and got hooked. Jumping into Tekken 8, it's honestly everything I could've wanted in a sequel. The new gameplay elements, the story, the graphics and music; it's all top-notch, and I can feel the urge to play again well up inside me when I'm at work. Worthwhile purchase.

I will first start this review by breaking down the good and bad aspects I have seen and felt within the time frame I have played up to reaching mighty ruler in ranked matchmaking.

good aspects:
Brilliant visuals.
Brilliant effects.
Stunning scenery/stages.
Decent arcade feel hub in game to find many players with a interesting arcade cabinet style set up for matchmaking.
Great sound design.

negative aspects:
Terrible movement.
Over focus on flashy cutscene invoking moves mid game via use of "Heat" removes the immersion from the fight.
Terrible balancing.
Nerfed backdash for several characters which ties into balancing problems.
over bloated 50 50 options for many characters which makes the game more guess work heavy. 
bloated damage for certain launchers with not enough punish potential trade off if blocked. 
movement feels slow and clunky like walking through mud/wet sand.

In Tekken 7 I reached Tekken King rank online towards the later stages of T7 life cycle and I loved near enough every aspect of it. The movement felt balanced across all characters and rewarded you for putting time into learning the movement system and how best to utilise it in your game play to improve yourself. In Tekken 8 movement or more accurately stated as spacing is completely thrown out of the window with plenty of moves from near enough the entire cast can hit you at very questionable ranges and hit boxes seem to be bigger on many moves which effects how well you can utilise movement overall. Back dashing feels terrible for certain characters in this iteration of the series which is a odd take to go for with a game like tekken where it felt like movement was a core fundamental yet despite this in tekken 8 this is not the case.

Several characters in the cast that are string focused which for new comers reading this review means characters that use multiple button inputs to complete a 3,4 or more string of consecutive hits for whichever reason in this game now has built in tracking in some cases which realigns the character model with their opponent which also effects the movement system meaning that players mash happy more in this game with less regard to movement being a possibility to stop their advance unlike in previous instalments of the series. There are many recorded cases online where moves from certain characters have hit their opponent despite the opponent being completely in their back or completely off axis to the characters weak side.

The Heat mechanic in game is an awful addition to the tekken series as a whole. In game we now have the introduction of Heat engagers, smashes and burst. Heat is essentially a meter system. This is the first time in tekkens history I have seen where the risk reward ratio for a particular move is completely skewed in the players favor with absolutely no repercussion for blocking it. you could be pressuring your opponent and have landed a move on them granting yourself an advantage with for example a +5 on block advantage for the opponent to then use a heat smash to reset the situation and grant themselves a plus frame advantage essentially stealing their turn. Even if you block this despite it being your turn frame wise the opponent that used this heat smash is completely safe and now has a on average across the cast +2 frames to then turn the pressure back to you. These moves are armoured, have excellent range and deal chip damage which is also an unwelcome addition to the series. 

This game has now become a 50 50 guessing simulator where after using heat smash or a heat engager it then follows into a 50 50 situation meaning the player or opponent can now use a guaranteed mix up option and depending on the character you're facing this can be easier to accommodate to or much much harder all because of a character choice. this is directly linked to a balancing issue as certain characters can absolutely abuse this much more than others.

there are also guard breaks in this game with some characters example I will use being Jack 8 where he can charge up a move for a guard break which for some reason allows a guaranteed heat burst move which if at wall can lead to a guaranteed 80 or 90 damage combo in a game where it usually only takes two combos to kill. 

In this game there are currently 5 or 6 characters used more than the rest of the cast for very obvious reasons if you decide to play this for yourself and they outshine the rest of the cast by a astonishing degree at this stage. This game has been made by the developers to be deliberately more offence focused with the introduction of chip damage and recoverable health to incentivise players to attack more which makes for very mash heavy fights where certain characters outperform in this aspect also. all of this whilst making 50 50 mix ups much stronger options and adding heat smashes in game which have a built in mini cutscene which ruins the immersion of a fight and prioritising armour moves to steal turns back makes this iteration of the tekken franchise the most mash heavy and outright exhausting fighting game I have ever played and it's not even remotely entertaining to witness with most of the offence being thrown at you feeling like completely cheap thrown shots with no general aim but just used to see if it works because that's what the devs intended for.

Rage arts are still in the game along with the entire heat system as a separate resource and are all currently -15 on block meaning not all of the cast can launch punish these moves anymore which again ties into move risk reward ratio being completely unbalanced again. 

Grabs in this game are strange now where a lot of them seem to have built in tracking and then others don't all with varying degrees of frame break windows with some characters having generic grabs with not accurate frame break windows despite the rest of the cast sharing the same which again is a balancing issue or a bug and with many varying states that guarantee full grab chains for insane damage in some specific circumstances. 

movement is absolutely butchered in this game by comparison to its predecessors with back dashing being nerfed into oblivion for several characters and this makes the movement system feel terrible to utilise which makes it feel like moving through mud or sand. Sidestepping has been buffed slightly in this game, however so many moves now have weird tracking properties despite not expressly stating they are tracking moves and these can come from moves that are part of strings or outright singular hit moves. in this game tracking moves can be visually seen by use of blue lines stemming from the characters limb yet despite many moves not having this property you can still be hit in very odd and outright incorrect positions all because the devs have made offence a priority so locking you down with these big hit box moves seems to of been a intentional move. 

Good aspects of the game so far seem to be the netcode. I play on a high end PC with top upload and download speeds and I have absolutely no trouble playing with players from Pakistan, Japan and America despite being in the EU with very minimal lag noticed at all during sessions.
Sound design is impeccable.
Character model visuals are great.
Stages are stunning and interactive with many different situations and mechanics in built.
Overall graphics are incredibly nice and smooth.

Unfortunately the bad sides outweigh any semblance of good this game has in its current state as Tekken 8 is nothing like the core of what Tekken is and has been for years and years prior. What made online matches interesting to both watch and experience was the mind games and the footsies players would have vs one another to force a mistake wether through movement or punishment yet all of those core fundamentals of what makes tekken an amazing game that stands out from the crowd of other fighters has been completely stripped away in this iteration. Devs please go back to your roots.

Feature rich with a variety of modes to experiment with and enjoy including the highly revered "Tekken ball" mode from tekken 3.
