Tekken 8 is a fun and great game in which you can break the skulls of enemies on the ground a lot, you can also side step a lot compared to 2D fighters. The game is complex and the LAB(practice) required hours could cause you to worry :). I'm writing this review from the point of view of a casual gamer that has Tekken 8 as their first Tekken game and finished almost everything in it after 70-80 hours in offline/online(rank 10)

[b]Positives:[/b]
- Great graphics, combat looks cool, feels cool and brutal. Tekken 8 is the best version of Tekken
- Winning online makes your laugh out loud, very satisfying
- Good music options with Jukebox, can change to any Tekken music
- Good Campaign that lasts for 3-4 hours and has incredible cut scenes that are gorgeous especially in the last hour of the game
- Surprisingly funny 32 Story Episodes. Can try out moves for each of the 32 chars in these. Can take up to 5-6 hours
- Good Arcade Quest that invites you to learn the basics of Tekken 8 while advancing a campaign through some social arcade places/stores/bars. Can take up to 5-6 hours
- Strong Roster of 32 characters with around 10 characters that are really bad ass like: Jin, Kazuya, Devil Jin, Jun, Reina, Zafina, Paul Phoenix, Law(Bruce Lee), Raven(Blade), Hworang, Bryan, Victor and Lee
- Minimum of 30-40 hours of gameplay to a casual player and easily 100+ hours if you would like to explore more than 1-2 characters and push the online ranks
- Combat looks very cool, feels very brutal with the more heavy hitting characters like Jin and its satisfying to pull out a win in a stressful situation especially online
- Unique combat mechanics and combat style, no fireball wars but you get grab wars and juggle wars
- Unique mechanics like attacking your enemy on the ground a lot, side stepping attacks, auto blocking and blocking on Standing posture as the standard opposed to 2D fighting games where you block low as the standard
- Easy mode exists that will allow you to juggle/air combo enemies with ease and perform other more complicated attacks
- NetCode for Online pvp is great most of the times, no issues seen
- Multiple Online pvp modes like Quick Play, Ranked, PvP arcades which are all very populated
- Combat seems fair and responsive both for single player and especially where it matters more -> for online pvp
- Great practice mode where you can see the moves executed and then you get to practice them
- Great combo challenges
- Great replay system for your online matches, you can save your favourite matches, get improvment tips when you watch them and can actually execute the received tip on the spot -> totally new system which will help people improve a lot
- A lot of customisation options for people that are into that stuff
- Steam achievements are easy to get to 100% in around 25-30 hours as all of them are just integrated into the first hours of the single player and online journeys you go into.


[b]Negatives:[/b] I don't view the negatives of this game as something very heavy, some people could also consider then negatives positives. Like a hard learning curve could be a positive or negative, a lot of mechanics same story etc
- The story of the game is a bit generic, the graphics and the fights/explosions are amazing and save the campaign but the story itself is 'Power of Love and Friendship wins'. Maybe drop all the serious and granny like advice this story has and just make it funny like the Story Episodes are.
- The music is a bit uninspired like techno music that is not very hard or doesn't drop some sick beat or anything but you can actually load your own playlist into the game or just any other Tekken sound track from the Jukebox so this point is saved but its worth mentioning
- Even tho the game was simplified, i feel it could be simplified even more to attract the casual gamers. There are over 100+ moves(+1 stance and its moves) for each character(can be overwhelming) which denotes depth and variation but the execution skill needed to perform some of the moves i feel is still too much for a casual gamer
- Execution skill needed for combos is too high -> especially online when you are getting hammered. There is a case that a player should struggle a bit a progress but when the struggle is too great(the execution skill for moves/combos is too high) people will just quit the online play because you would need to stay so many hours in the lab/practice mode and its not fun anymore at that point.
- High end ranked games require a lot of lab hours(practice hours) which kills the fun of the game. If the moves could be easier, the lab hours would be lower. The lab hours need to be reduced for high end ranked play to include more people.
- Please make this version of Tekken or the next Tekken more keyboard friendly. Most keyboards cant take 3 inputs at once and some moves are just not possible where 3 inputs are needed


[b]Conclusion:[/b]

 I wanted to point out that the negatives are small in this game and you will be able to play your character without issues(60-70% of the moves are accessible), there is an easy mode available for the more complicated stuff but it will feel like cheating and you wont feel so cool using it/winning with it.
 In conclusion i can say i had a blast with this game, its a great game, especially online when you fight some close games and you win. This will give you a minimum of 30 hours(25 hours to fully clear the single player + 5 hours for the casual online pvp push) and 100+ hours over a few years or if you want to try out new characters, its worth the money.

I'm not gonna sugarcoat it.

Most of the time you'll run into, "Connection Quality did not match selected requirements." While queuing for Ranked or Quick Matches, Tekken 7 works just fine but something is up with the new Tekken 8 Netcode. Don't get me wrong there's tons of single player content to enjoy but after the 12 hours are up and you're done with all the Character Episodes and done with Arcade Quest learning about the new Mechanics, you'll basically be stuck finding matches in Tekken Fight Lounge, I do not know when they'll fix it but I'm from America and I keep getting matched with Asia 1, South Korea, and European players. If you want a work around you'll have to either find a better ISP or use a VPN which is pretty terrible practice coming from a newer fighting game. 

I would recommend holding off until they finally either fix online or consider saving your cash for other titles, I do enjoy playing against my friends but then again, on 7 the connection is good, on 8 it's really terrible.

Starting from Tag Tournament 2, Tekken has always been a franchise I love yet have had difficulty with playing competently. Tekken 8 however, is the most refined in the series, the most accessible for newcomers and the only serious modern competitor to Street Fighter 6. The game allows you to download your opponents Ghost to learn their match-up and makes labbing characters more fun than ever. Great story mode, character episodes that aren't total ****ing cringe, rollback netcode and the option to replace any stage music with tracks from Tekken 1-8 including Tag Tournament 1 and 2. This is a huge W for Harada and Bandai Namco. Hopefully the DLC will release soon and give us more characters.

A big step up from Tekken 7. Very impressive from a visual and stylistic standpoint. The initial barrier for entry to play the game is lowered thanks to a decent tutorial through Arcade Quest, and backdashing no longer being as gated. Furthermore, the game is no longer as convoluted due to actually having access to accurate frame data in the training mode. 

Thanks to the new universal Heat mechanic, characters that were/are missing tools for pressure benefit greatly, granting them more options (namely, a one-time guaranteed plus frame move at the expense of their meter). On the other hand, the tools of those who already have strong pressure gets upgraded with chip damage. However, Heat was designed such that it must be used wisely (extending combos for your entire Heat is a risky trade). Overall, this mechanic reduces potential power gaps between characters by giving whoever knows how to use it well an advantage. 

One iffy thing is that the devs put EWGF into the assist button (like for Kazuya and Reina), but at least they made it slower than regular EWGF. Also, still a crap ton of knowledge checks, but at least they changed a lot of animations to make it much more obvious where the moves hit.

A fantastic experience, even if you're not a fan of fighting games.

On the surface, this game is beautiful. The character models, their animations, the arenas - everything is top-notch. Optimization is great, as well - when I can't reach my PC, I use my Steam Deck (old model), 45 stable FPS (I set this to prolong battery life), and with decent graphics.

The fighters have great identities - both, in visuals and in fighting styles.

Under-the-hood, it has FANTASTIC depth. I watched some guides, and you can *literally* dedicate yourself to learning one character for *years*. Executing flashy combos and special moves is super rewarding, both visually and damage-wise.

Tekken 8 does seem quite intimidating, at first (and, frankly, it is for newbies like me), but it also has a "beginner-friendly" mode ("Special" style, which greatly simplifies controls). 

However, the game really shines once you start learning your fighter properly.

Something is weird with Tekken 8. I like it, but I cant help but think its way too strict with its gameplay.

Some characters have more moves that reach much further than the character animation/model than others, and I havent seen it be this severe. Tekken 8 is the most longest reaching limb tekken game I have played and I am not sure I like the inconcistency. [b]For example:[/b] There are so many more moves which you cannot strafe/sidestep. Getting hit by seemingly airboxing.

There are a lot more characters who have too much of a fast paced linear flow. As in, characters with forward momentum moves that puts them in advantage of some kind. Resulting in a fast paced Tekken game, sure. But its forcing the mechanics a bit too boldly to fit the mold they have planned, and it is visible. [b]To the point of[/b] characters almost playing by themselves.

I dont feel like that I (me) am playing the game in the way I want because the game conditions me to play by its rules set within the character I chose to in such a way that I have to follow the characters flow-chart.

[b]As another example[/b], what if I DONT want to heat dash after a heat activatable move? You ALWAYS heat dash after a heat activated move. Because of that, those moves that heat activate are balanced in such a way that they kinda leave you wanting the heat dash, resulting in those moves feeling like a resource you loose when heat is activated and done. Creating a soft decrease of every characters move-list (not that decreasing the move-list is bad, just pointing out how the mechanics influence to this conclusion).


But the game is fun, it has quality, lots of content. I just am having a hard time enjoying the fundamental aspect of the game which is the fighting.

Good game btw If someone have problem or update issue that said"DISK ERROR" this cause by anti-virus blocking tekken 8 to update since file is to big, close your anti-virus by follow this step
1.Open Windows Security.
2.Select the “Virus & threat protection” option.
3.Under “Current threats,” select “Protection history.”
4.Filter on “Quarantined Items.”
5.Select the “Restore” option on Polaris-Win64-Shipping.exe or Tekken8.exe.
6.Then select “Manage settings.”
7.Under Exclusions, select “Add or remove exclusions.”
8.Select Add an exclusion, pick folders, then choose your Tekken 8 installation folder to whitelist it from future false positive flagging. 
Or just close your anti-virus app on your bottom right on your screen ,hope this would help

I've always been more of a Soul Calibur person than a Tekken person, but this game won me over. Great base roster. Lots of modes. Gameplay is far less floaty and clunky than prior installments. Story mode was insane and had a lot of clear effort put into it. 2/3 newcomers are awesome. Started maining Reina, and she's both fun gameplay-wise and has an amazing personality. Victor embodies so many of the "agent character" tropes I love, and basically cheats (in a good way) with his blade and gun based moveset. Azucena outright sucks though. She feels like if Lucky Chloe and Christie were fused into one character, but had their personalities extracted and replaced with nothing but a love of coffee. I really hate one-note comedic relief characters, and she feels like a waste of space on the roster. Azucena reaches El Fuerte levels of cringe, but her presence is this game's only major flaw.
Great game over all!

Steep price tag, but worth every penny imo. It's a fighting game so there's a lot of replayability, not to mention that it's newly released so if they took it in the same direction with dlcs that its predecessor did, it's going to be a banger.

Graphics are amazing, but is optimized well enough that with enough processing power you should be able to smoothly sail in terms of frames. It looks daunting at first when you watch trailers of the game and such but I assure you it's very well optimized.

Netcode is a HUGE improvement, I'm able to play on 220ish ping against someone across the world with barely noticeable input lag (this is subjective, some combos that have strict timing can and will be dropped). Comparing this to Tekken 7, it's so much more smoother. 

Overall, the game may seem scary for new players cause you need to learn a decent amount of moves for over 30+ characters (how many ever characters are in the game), and not only that, you also have to learn matchups but hey, that's just how fighting games are.

The year is 2024, 30 years after the original Tekken (weirdly almost named 'Rave War") was released to the public square.  To begin, this absolutely is a continuation of quite possibly the best polygon fighting game ever made since others simply don't carry the reputation of Tekken on numerous levels going back to the 1990's.  Over the many iterations, the number of features has expanded and there are lots of variations within the game itself from the avatar you can build and test against other computer opponents to the customization of the characters, avatar and screen elements during play, just like Tekken 7 but expanded.  As has been stated too many times already, the heavy use of the Unreal Engine 5 (UE5) adds a level of detail that pushes the entire game visually beyond MK1 and SF6, although from what I read, some of the UE5 elements are not used for whatever the reason but the game visually is cutting edge.  It is nice that there are direct references to prior Tekken releases, I like having the "jukebox" feature so you can have prior Tekken music playing during your Tekken 8 experience.  The game play is of course tight, the heat system is a welcome new element that can change a match and the sound and various lighting effects are also excellent.  My 12 year old daughter who is taking actual Taekwondo found a realistic association with Hwoarang and set the game to medium difficulty and is enjoying the experience as someone who never played a Tekken game before and made the jump from Nintendo Switch games with their much lower graphic capability and simpler game library.  

As for negatives, well there are a couple, nitpicky honestly though.  The graphics are stunning for the most part, but when there are levels where the floor collapses, you can see this incredibly primitive polygons at times if you look carefully which is just kind of...out of place.  It isn't very noticeable but if you look for it, you'll see it.  Secondly, the stories for the characters are random in quality, but to each their own.  My 12 year old was noticing on one movie end sequence how Jin and Hwoarang were racing on motorcycles a high speed without motorcycle helmets and I told her to just roll with the fantasy elements because the character models are top notch, but this is a video game, goofy, unrealistic fantasy elements right along with mind-blowing visuals and slammin' sound.

So in summary, if you came looking for a superb Tekken update from Tekken 7, Tekken 8 is a worthwhile upgrade and maintains the high quality that comes with your standard Namco video game.

My machine: Windows 11 Pro, AMD Ryzen 7, nVidia RTX 30 8 GB of VRAM, 32 GB of system RAM and a 1 TB SSD, mostly ASUS hardware and the game runs perfectly on my ancient Sony 40 inch XBR6 HDTV at 1080p.

Pros:
-Multiplayer hub
-Various offline modes like Arcade Battle, an improved Story Mode from 7 and Tekken Ball
-Large private lobby system that can host multiple battles at once
-Rollback netcode
-No paid skins
-Largest release roster of any modern fighter out right now
-Gameplay is fluid with a large skill ceiling like previous Tekken releases

Cons:
-Netcode can go from silky smooth to unplayable.  Seriously, I get that rollback has to predict inputs but this iteration feels like it guesses wrong far too often.  Inputs get eaten on the regular.  I've watched punishes get 'erased' right before my eyes.
-Game still needs some TLC.  I've had to reinstall my drivers twice already since release to fix frame jitters.  For context, my setup is an i7 13k with a RTX 4060.  This shouldn't be happening.

Overall: 9/10
I know the technical fixes will come.  For the meantime, this game has a great foundation to build upon and plan on playing this for years to come.  Can't wait to watch T8 at EVO as well.

The best fighting game on the market right now, incredible music and story, I love Tekken too much and this game made my innerr child happy. It's fun, just fun.

[h1]Story Mode & Character Cinematics[/h1]

The story mode is a complete Jin fanservice, but you don't have to be a Jin fan to like it. They especially tried hard to excite the fans whose childhood coincided with Tekken 3, and I think they were successful in this regard. The cinematics, the music as always, and also the many surprises specific to the story mode were enough to fascinate me. Had many deep moments as well.

There is also a mini arcade mode where we can watch the individual endings of each character, I was very happy that the character cinematics returned, and the game has a true arcade mode now.

[h1]Music[/h1]

I can separately praise the music played in the story mode and the stage music we listened to in the game. The music is just... Tekken.

It was a great surprise for me to have the jukebox on the PC. We can access and listen to the albums of all games in the series and replace the stage music with the music we want.

[h1]Convenience and Learning[/h1]

As always, we can look at the movements and combos of all characters in the classic practice mode. We can learn how to do the movements and practice them.

There is also a mini game mode called Arcade Quest. In fact, this mode aims to teach new players Tekken and test their skills against artificial intelligence opponents that are similar to the player. Doesn't matter if you're just starting out or an og fan like me, the game holds your hand in some way.

[h1]Online[/h1]

Cross-platform works fine and matchmaking works better compared to Tekken 7. This makes me want to play online even more.

Using the avatar we created for Arcade Quest, we can wander around the online lobby and meet people if we want. The lobby functions as both a menu and a chat, it is well thought out.

By the way, fighting with ghosts that copy each player's performance almost exactly is as fun as fighting with the players. You can also train your own ghost.

Even though I'm not a good Tekken player, I enjoyed all the modes and I especially love playing online. Winning gives a strong pleasure, you can feel every hit you throw, and losing teaches you a lot about the character your opponent plays as you continue to play the game. If you like Tekken, do not hesitate, if you are entering the series for the first time, do not worry, the game prepares you for everything.

You can try the demo before buying.

Thank you Namco and Harada.

Between Tekken 8 and MK1, I highly recommend that Tekken 8 be your priority purchase. 

The game provides a substantial amount of gameplay for those who dislike online play. So much so that I would say 36 of the 36 hours spent playing this game have been CPU battles. 

Additionally, the super ghost mechanic provides a challenge that will help almost anyone improve.

The practice mode, along with the replay review system, provides ways for anyone to improve while removing some of the tediousness often found in the practice modes of other games.

When it comes to online gameplay, stemming from the minimal amount I've played, is quite smooth and has minimal latency. Occasional lag spikes have occurred but quickly subsided and did not drastically affect the gameplay. 

Over all, this is one of the best fighers I've played in terms of content.
Greatest modern fighting game.

Amazing fighting game, fun storymode experience for newcomers and returning fans of Tekken, crossplay on launch, a plethora of diverse characters to choose from, next-gen fighting mechanics and AI to simulate your greatest rivals. Character customization is akin to games like Soul Calibur, and unlike "other" fighting games, custom skins are not hidden behind a large paywall, you can easily play the game and earn in-game currency to purchase custom assets.  Special Style is an easy controls option available for new players as well, but the mechanics are not nearly as polished when compared to the Modern Controls seen in Street Fighter 6.

Hosting and creating sessions could improve with more quality of life features, it is difficult to search for a specific lobby and requires constant refreshes to eventually find the lobby you're looking for, and it would also be great to still be able to customize a session while hosting.  The option to fight a dummy while waiting for a match would also be great if a player would prefer to stay warmed up as opposed to spectating, a feature already in Ranked and Quick Match online.  I'm happy to see more people getting into Tekken.  I give Tekken 8 9/10, for great launch and great game on day one.

[h1] Mixed Feelings [/h1] 

I really don't want to give this neither a good review or a bad review. Look I love Tekken 8 as much as the next guy and I think its heading in a great direction. Tekken 8 is genuinely one of the best games I have ever played. & Just like majority of people. I paid retail price for this game. And like other I used to play Tekken 7 for a decent chunk of time. So let's set that as the ground-work. 

Tekken 8's multiplayer experience is what you expect from a Tekken multiplayer experience. Tekken players..... You know exactly what that means. For those not aware. Tekken has a history of having not the most stable / ideal online environment. Now, obviously this can come with the territory of playing fighting games online. Or any online match for that matter. Every game suffers from this. But, Tekken. Playing Tekken online for me feels just as bad as Tekken 7's multiplayer if not, a little worse. Tekken Players know what I am talking about but, examples are below. 

 [b] Crashing > Frame Drops > Lag > Massive Input Lag at times > Fake 3-4 Bars > Inconsistent Punishes Online > Disconnects > ( And So on )
 [/b] 

And in some ways. I almost feel ostracized / selfish calling Tekken 8's multiplayer a let down because so many people are calling it good.  I'm sure ton's of other people might not have the same experience & could disagree with my point by pointing out some technical leap they did to address theses issues from their titles. But, I for the last 30 hours have been trying really really really hard to like Tekken 8. But right now, in the state it's in. I can't seem to find that enjoyment. The feeling I get from the state of this game is the same feeling counter strike players got when counter strike 2 came out. 


Once the honey-moon phase of a new release is done. You start actually experiencing the game for what it is & Tekken 8 is not all glitter and gold lol. But, I digress. I'm sure like i mentioned earlier plenty of people are not having the issues I am having. Do I think this should stop you from buying Tekken 8? No, definitely not. The game is beautiful, fun & has tons of great content & heck. When the online works as intended and the stars align. You might even get to experience an amazing online match as-well. This game deserves all the praise it gets. But, nothings perfect. And I want you to know that going into it. It's a great game. But, be warned that the multiplayer is really not a good resemblance / example of that.  

But this has just been my experience with it. An average consumer like you, spending full retail price on a game

Amazing game with a lot of character and style. The gameplay is more fluid and responsive than pretty much any other fighting game on the market. Even multiplayer is fair and rewarding for newer players willing to spend some time to work on some basics and there are enough newcomers online to fighting games to be able to have a chance to do so. Arcade quest is a great extensive tutorial as well with a lot of fun and customization to be earned through it.
The only flaw with this game comes in on the story mode. Don't get me wrong, it's great up until the 50% mark.  There is a wave defense of fighting multiple enemies at once, which is fine, fun even for the first time. Then they do it again immediately after. And again. And.. again.. and again consecutively. I stopped the story mode here and don't think I'll go back to it. Even without the campaign though, this game is worth the time to learn and money.

Classic Tekken gameplay, gorgeous visuals, upbeat soundtrack, all things I expected from a Tekken entry.

But what I did NOT expect was a HUGE improvement to the intermediate player experience. You can watch your own replays and the game will pause when you get hit by something that the game thinks you don't know how to answer ("you could have ducked that", "here's how you can duck this move you just got hit by"). AND, at the touch of a button, you can launch a minigame in the replay where you practice dealing with that move you just got hit by in the replay.

The online is ok. I've heard some people have issues with the rollback implementation, but I'm not having any problems.

The quality of the game itself is great. The visuals are great overall and the actual performance of the game is great on my pc. Its very entertaining and I enjoyed my time playing ranked even though I'm a washed up Tekken 5 gamer. There's probably unbalanced cheesy stuff but as an inexperienced player it literally doesn't matter. There is a decent amount of singleplayer as well to ease in newer players which is great.

HOWEVER, this game has a huge flaw, and its the low level fatal error bug that causes a crash that has been extensively documented on the steam forums. For whatever reason, the game will experience a driver-related crash if you use certain GPUs for no real rhyme or reason at any given moment. Some maps appear to crash more than others, and this can happen during inopportune moments that can cause your save data to become corrupted or cause you to disconnect from a ranked match. This crash happens every time I play, I have not once closed the game from the options menu, relying instead on the inevitable crash to end my session with.

Like I said this happens to a wide variety of systems using various GPUs, AMD and nvidia. My system which has a 1080ti and is well above the recommended specs for the game can run the game on ultra with a constant 60 fps, but will crash within 5 minutes on one specific stage, and 30 minutes to 2 hours otherwise. People with 4090s have also experienced this same crash, so people saying its a hardware issue are downplaying the problem for some reason as it can happen on brand new top of the line hardware. For comparison my friend has a 2060 which can hardly play the game at a constant 60 fps on low, and he has never crashed. Meanwhile for me the game is actually unplayable.

Bandai has not even acknowledged that this error exists beyond a useless help article on their website that doesn't fix the issue. They've even replied to support tickets saying that you should "hire a technician" if you're affected by this problem. What a joke. This leads me to believe this error may never get fixed since its a relatively small number of players affected.

TLDR; Tekken 8 so far has clicked with me more than MK 1 from a beginners perspective, simply because it seems like it cares more about being a complete game with fleshed out characters, from a design standpoint at least. 

It can be a little overwhelming, but it is still a great time if you have a basic understanding of how these types of games work. I feel like that sums up this game pretty well. The first character I picked up to play has over 130 moves, however despite that, it still manages to be a good time even if I don't know many combos or anything like that. I think the key to enjoying a game like this is to not expect to be the best right off the bat, you will get destroyed in every match (probably), however this game provides you so many tools to where there really is no excuse one could have to not improve at the game. 

You can fight AI recreations of another players play style and play against it, which actually helped me understand their play style, to the point where I could actually beat them after adapting to it. You can also fight your own AI Ghost (as the game calls it) to weed out weak points in your play style. 

I think this game is definitely worth the time IF you like fighting games, and if you have the patience for that kind of thing. If you don't, but you still are intrigued by this game, I still think it's worth trying out the Arcade Quest at least, as it gives you the base tool kit you would need to learn how to play the game, albeit it is VERY basic things.

(Update) 
After the first update, I can change my review to positive. 

In my opinion this is the best Tekken game since Tekken 3: 

  - Stunning visual
  - An amazing Tekken battle system with new features and improvements. 
  - A lot of content from the start.
  - Tekken provides a big roster of fighters and a lot of character optimization. 
  - Each arena has highly detailed textures and area-layers. 
  - Good online, but need improvements.

Game feels complete and friendly to players, without a greedy free-to-play approach. Yeah, I’m talking about you Capcom.

I’m very satisfied with Tekken 8 and can recommend this game to everyone. 

P.S. Story mode is the weakest part of this game. Perfectly visually, but stupid and empty inside.

My score is 9 of 10.

Giving everyone two moves list, one that only has the moves you should concentrate on and the other is the full moves set. [b]Tekken 8, the latest installment in the iconic fighting game franchise developed by Bandai Namco, continues to redefine the genre with its polished gameplay, stunning visuals, and diverse roster of characters. I am going to go into detail about this:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Stunning Visuals and Immersive Environments:[/b]
[i]Tekken 8 screams breathtaking graphics and brilliantly designed environments that put players in dynamic and vibrant battle arenas.
From bustling city streets to serene natural landscapes and from there to Nightmare realities, each stage is a visual spectacle, enhancing the overall gaming experience.[/i]

[*][b]Refined Gameplay Mechanics:[/b]
[i]Building upon its previous installments, Tekken 8 introduces refined gameplay mechanics that offer a perfect balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for Tekken Pros.
The controls are responsive and creative, allowing players to execute complex combos and special moves with precision. I can also add executing combos that are just frames, are much more easily executable now.[/i]

[*][b]Diverse Roster of Characters:[/b]
[i]With a diverse roster of characters, each with their own unique fighting style and backstory, Tekken 8 offers something for every player.
From classic favorites like Kazuya Mishima and Jin Kazama to newcomers with innovative fighting techniques like Azucena and Victor, the character selection is vast and varied, and rumored to be becoming bigger and bigger in the coming years.[/i]

[*][b]Engaging Story Mode:[/b]
[i]Tekken 8 features an engaging story mode that delves deeper into the rich lore of the Tekken universe.
Players embark on a thrilling journey filled with intrigue, betrayal, and epic showdowns, unraveling the mysteries behind each character's motives, with the main story just based on the Mishima Bloodline.[/i]

[*][b]Robust Online Multiplayer:[/b]
[i]The online multiplayer feature of Tekken 8 delivers an exhilarating experience, allowing players to test their skills against opponents from around the world.
With robust matchmaking features and various online modes, including ranked matches and tournaments, the competitive scene is vibrant and engaging, the net-code is not perfect but its way better than the Tekken 7 when it came out back in the days. [/i]


[*][b]Customization Options:[/b]
[i]Tekken 8 offers extensive customization options, allowing players to personalize their favorite characters with unique costumes, accessories, and cosmetic items. Also paying homage to other characters from the games like Resident Evil with adding their customized costumes in the game.
From traditional martial arts attire to outlandish outfits, the customization options are virtually limitless, adding an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, so that my character may look cool while Kicking A$$.[/i]
[/list]

[b][i]In the end I would like to add that Tekken 8 surpasses expectations as a fighting game masterpiece, combining stunning visuals, refined gameplay mechanics, with new Game Modes and a diverse cast of characters to deliver an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or new to the franchise, Tekken 8 offers something for everyone and cements its place as one of the finest fighting games of all time. I would recommend highly to anyone and to anybody who is into fighting games or not, as this will hook them up.[/i][/b]

Let me just say 2 things. 
1. I don't really play fighting games very often. so I'm probably not the target audience for this game
2. I haven't played Tekken since like a hand full of times back in Tekken 2.

I just beat the whole game and i cant say that I actually learned how to play. In an attempt to make this entry more appealing to new comer to this franchise it seems that they have added in a soft "Auto combo" system the called "Special style". I took the time to read as carefully as i could when the prompts came up explaining how this system works and thought at the time that it was a simple base that would grow on me. but as the game progressed it was clear that this system and overall combat was far more complex than I had thought. I would either find myself stuck repeating the same attack over and over making me feel like I had little to no control over my character or completely wipe the enemy with an near endless combo string, leaving little time for the CPU to react. Through out the whole game there was the heavy feeling of "I have no idea what I am doing". I feel like the Special Style system was either not explained very well or that there needed to be a dedicated tutorial section in the game somewhere.

Story: it was serviceable

Performance: The game would sometimes stutter during cut-scene. even getting bad enough to skip whole sections of them.

As a devoted fan since the era of Tekken 3, delving into the latest installment, Tekken 8, felt like revisiting a cherished part of my gaming journey. With heightened anticipation, I embarked on this latest adventure in the King of Iron Fist Tournament, eager to experience the evolution of a franchise that has captivated players for decades.

Gameplay (5/5):
Tekken 8 boasts exceptionally smooth gameplay, a hallmark feature that has remained consistent throughout the series. From executing intricate combos to delivering devastating blows, every movement feels fluid and responsive, staying true to the essence of what makes Tekken such a beloved fighting game. Whether engaging in intense one-on-one battles or participating in frenetic multiplayer showdowns, the gameplay mechanics of Tekken 8 never fail to deliver an adrenaline-fueled experience.

Customization (3/5):
While the core gameplay mechanics excel, Tekken 8 falls short in terms of customization options. Compared to its predecessors, the level of customization feels lacking, leaving much to be desired in terms of personalizing characters to match individual preferences. Despite this drawback, the intuitive nature of the game compensates for the limited customization, ensuring that players can still immerse themselves fully in the combat experience.

Storyline (3.5/5):
Admittedly, the storyline of Tekken 8 may not be its strongest aspect. While it exudes a sense of nostalgia, particularly for long-time fans familiar with the lore of the series, some elements may come across as cringe-worthy or predictable. However, it's worth noting that the storyline serves as a conduit for invoking fond memories of past tournaments and iconic characters, tapping into the nostalgia factor that has been a driving force behind the enduring appeal of the Tekken franchise.

Overall Impression (4/5):
In conclusion, Tekken 8 stands as a testament to the franchise's enduring legacy, offering a compelling blend of nostalgia and innovation. Despite its shortcomings in terms of customization and storytelling, the game excels where it truly matters – delivering a seamlessly engaging gameplay experience that is sure to captivate both long-time fans and newcomers alike. For anyone with a passion for fighting games or those seeking an entry point into the genre, Tekken 8 undoubtedly earns its place as a must-play title.

I wholeheartedly recommend Tekken 8 to anyone who appreciates the thrill of competitive combat and the rich history of the Tekken universe. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer eager to experience the adrenaline-pumping action of the King of Iron Fist Tournament, Tekken 8 promises hours of exhilarating gameplay that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

This is my first time playing Tekken for real since I was an actual child and got repeatedly dumpstered by a group of insecure 20 year olds still living at home. Apparently since then the game has really come into its own, and instead of being an infinitely deep knowledge check gated by finger breaking mechanical execution, it's also still that but in addition it has a beautifully simple and low-mechanical-requirement skill floor for new folks. You can learn to play this game in a few hours and have tons of fun with your friends and other folks online (now that they have more modern netcode).

Forget the dumb full-dpad triple 360 with a dragon punch inputs of some other fighters. Forget the single frame execution requirement in your 40 move bread-n-butter string of some other games. You can learn these combos! They are fun to do! You can react to these grabs (unless it's Victor)! It's got easy, big one-button moves, but they aren't overtuned. It's got ridiculously over-the-top supers, but they aren't too long and you can't do them multiple times in a round.

As well, the game has amazing graphics all the way down to low-end machines like a steamdeck where it maintains 60fps in matches. The animations are beautiful. There are 32 EXTREMELY distinct characters on launch. It has the incredible soundtracks from every single Tekken game. The stages put the other modern fighting game stages to shame.

While the single player isn't quite as amazing as SF6, it's got two separate modes that are both really excellent. It has a great single player and offline experience generally, and top-notch practice and training modes.

If you have been thinking about getting (back?) into fighting games, I think you'd be happy choosing this one. It has that same "easy to learn, hard to master" quality that made Soul Calibur such a big social event back in the day. Just remember to wait your turn ...

After spending a good 1.3k hours in Tekken 7, the big question that looms in my mind is if Tekken 8 can follow up what Tekken 7 had left off. And after only over 60 hours, I can safely say that this is the best Tekken game to have existed thus far.

Tekken had always been a feature-rich game ever since Tekken 3, having different game modes on top of the usual 1 on 1 fighting game. From Tekken Ball back at Tekken 3, to the beat 'em up style of Scenario Campaign in Tekken 6, the series has everything from a solid fighting game for competitive players, and fun game modes for casuals. Although, Tekken 7 did take a huge hit on the amount of single-player/local multiplayer content being close to non-existent mainly due to it's budget, but it was it's best selling game on it's franchise's history which haven't topped off of since 1997 due to how the game was well balanced (for the most part), how accessible it is (being available for PC was huge since it was the first of it's franchise), and how well the game is as a spectator sport.

So how does Tekken 8 fair against Tekken 7? It pales in comparison. Gameplay wise, Tekken 8 decided to try something different by adding the new heat mechanic, which feels like an immensely drastic change from the usual Tekken feel. The game was always known with spacing and playing footsies on a 3D environment on an extremely high level, but now they really hammered down on making the game more offensive driven with the addition of every mechanic with the heat system, but the defensive tools got a slight increase with sidesteps covering more distance, and also power crushes getting buffed by it being safer on block once the player was hit during the startup frames. Graphically, the game is impressive. It shows how much budget the game actually has in comparison to its predecessor. It could be the best looking fighting game to date.

The story of the game is an absolute love letter to classic Tekken fans. Without getting into much detail, it is the most cliche thing that you could ever think of in any anime, but the final fight makes it all worth it. The final fight made me have that feeling that I can only wish I can relive that moment for the first time all over again. The character endings are back with the classic CGI animations and they do feel like the classic Tekken endings, some being absolutely funny, some weird, and some that is tied to their lore.

The practice tool is very in depth and improved from Tekken 7, giving you tips on how to punish certain moves against all characters and even through your replays. The replay tool also lets you continue from a certain point to help you play against a flowchart that a different person used against you in a match. So now there are added tools for you to learn the game even better.

Super Ghost Battle is an interesting game mode, and I have a little under 50 hours on the demo just playing around the Super Ghost Battle. What it does is it lets you create an AI that follows your every move, habits, combo routes even when you drop your combos. It reminds me of the amiibos in Super Smash Bros Ultimate.
And honestly, I have a lot of fun even just fighting against my own ghost, I see my own patterns and habits going against it and it does makes up for the default AI that Tekken 8 has when playing other modes.

Now here's the big kicker for me, character interaction, how the character feels like an actual character instead of them being random guy # 4 with a moveset. They nailed it here, each character does feel more alive, especially with some intro sequences. It's these levels of detail that made me love Tekken Tag 2. There are definitely some set of characters that needs special intros, but I still love that they exist.

Overall Tekken 8 is a 9/10. The game is damn near a perfect fighting game in my opinion, with the added single player content with Tekken Ball being a nice relaxing game to play with the homies, how well the netcode is to play with people around the world online, how each character and stage looks with very realistic graphics, and the infinite replayability of the Super Ghost Battle. It has the potential to be the best fighting game out there in the market and for sure it rivals Street Fighter 6, which I think is the baseline to what a modern fighting game should be.

Despite its number Tekken 8 is the 10th game in the series. A new entry for a new generation. Beautiful graphics and fast load times make the experience far smoother than the previous entry. 

The launch roster also boasts an impressive 32 characters! Street Fighter 6 launched with 18 for some context.

Most characters have been given a few new moves which adds a veneer of freshness Along with an entire system wide mechanic called "Heat".

The Heat system brings new moves along with the possibility to regenerate some health which really encourages a very aggressive style of play. While very flashy, the cinematic moves from heat gets tiresome very fast. With a first to 3 format these flashy scenes will play a whopping 10 times PER match. 

Its a real BIG pace killer. 

Its a solid game with a ton of potential. I personally prefer Tekken 7 for now but that could easily change.

[h2]Tekken 8 is a 9/10[/h2]

Tekken 8 is my first Tekken game ever. I'm not huge into fighting games, however I probably have about 125-150 hours across the Mortal Kombat and Soul Calibur  franchises.

Getting right into it, I am in love with Tekken 8. Clocking about 30 hours so far, the game has a way of teaching you the mechanics like non other through the various modes then game provides, right down to specific character mechanics. 

The practice tool is extremely versatile and helps you practice specific moves as much as you wish, where as the Arcade Quest Mode teaches you the generic mechanics of the game while facing seemingly more and more difficult challengers as you progress and learn to use the taught mechanics. Definitely recommend Arcade Quest to be your first stop as a new Tekken player.

The AI Ghost Battles are a fantastic addition to fighting games in general and I hope to see it in more games going forward as it is another great tool for practice.

Online play has been challenging as veteran players make there way up the ranks from the bottom.I can see and feel myself improving at a steady pace with lots of practice, which keeps me coming back for more. 

Those wanting a more social aspect to their fighting games will love the Tekken Fight Lounge, a virtual space in which your player avatar from the Arcade Quest Mode can walk around and interact with other players.

Customization of characters is very good in Tekken 8 and allows players to feel as though there characters are truly their own. It can leave me wanting more in some areas when it come to customizing, but I don't think that what makes a fighting game great, so I can't let that hold it back.

Tekken 8 is a 9/10 fighting game that is worth every penny to those willing to put in the time to learn the game at a controlled pace. I truly do not have many if any, negative things to say about the game.

Same 0 logic dumb game.Just learn button mash combos while character is in the the air and react to counter slow throw grabs and you are top 100 player. Same boring sh1t where if you get hit in the air you loose 60% hp and basically you loose.Basically all character with short hits are the best for online. If you want to fight online be sure to check first character tier because they are made uneven,so that some are slower or lack some useful attacks. Single play bots are dumb as wall. And I even try to teach my ghost fighter,still it is dumb as brick. Dumb noobish super sayan powers at low hp is SUPER anoying breaking fights rhythm and making both players stop and defend like 2 morons afraid of each other. What worse these moves have cut scenes and they are of course unskipable and soon they become tedious,repetitive and boring to level of annoying.
  And honestly no one is playing Tekken for single play. So most positive reviews are from people with around 10h played mostly offline. So I'd say wait for discount.

Tekken 8 is a breath of fresh air with many fun and unique mechanics for each character and challenging and refreshing pvp for each match. I personally like the game because you can sink hours learning and mastering a character and there will still be 60 other moves you never knew existed for your character. Oh and guess what, bored of a character, that's okay play a completely new one and spend hours learning there combos. I hope the rumored baki dlc is true to come and good updates come to prevent the game going stale.

I think SF, MK and Tekken are the 3 biggest fighting game franchises at the moment.  All of them having releases within half a year of each other.  This gives us very easy compares with those so fresh in our mind.  And there are a lot of arguments for Tekken 8 being possibly the best.  I say this because while I talk what I think the game does well and not well I will be making comparisons to it's contemporaries.  I assume that is why most people are reading a review is where should they put their money.

Graphics are gorgeous.  As of writing this the best looking fighter on the market imo and best of the big 3.  The story mode features movie like cut scenes which transition to game play.  If you blink you may not even notice you are about to enter game play.  SF6 does a better job with consistency.  For example there is less clipping of outfits and hair physics are better.  But this game is just downright pretty from the characters to the stages.

Sound is top notch.  Landing blows is satisfying.  Nothing sounds flat.  Blocking has the classic Tekken sound.  Nearly all the voice acting sounds really good.  Only a couple don't quite do it for me.  Music in Tekken is always hit or miss for me.  It's kind of the same here.  It will either be a banger or something having you say wtf.  One super nice feature is "Jukebox".  It allows you to play music from any previous Tekken game or all of them mixed in.  Even create your own play list.  At no extra charge - imagine that.

Story mode took me a little over 4 hours to complete on medium difficulty.  Each character has a "mini" story mode which consist of 5 encounters with beginning and ending cut scenes.  There is also a mode called "Arcade Quest" that is a story mode for the player but also functions as a great tutorial.

A single in game currency is used to unlock addition pieces to customize the players avatar for Arcade Quest and all kinds of bits a bobs for the main roster of characters.  You can kind of build your own skin.  Of course your limited to what is there.  But I have seen some crazy outfits and references I easily understand for online play.  You can make your character nearly unrecognizable.  For no extra charge.  Everything earned by playing the game.

Speaking of which, lets go ahead and clear out some elephants.  There is no battle pass.  No real money is asked for player avatar cosmetics or main roster cosmetics.  Sure, some things may come later as DLC.  But there is not an in game store button anywhere to be found.  While Capcom and NRS has put a disgusting amount of micro transactions into SF6 and MK1 respectively it's so nice to have a major fighting game release not try to milk their players for all they are worth.  In an era or 12$ fatalities and 15$ turtle avatar costumes Tekken earns a lot of respect from me personally.

Similar to Modern controls from SF6 Tekken has a control style called "Special Style".  Featuring auto combo's that can be varied depending on buttons pressed, access to easy throws and lows and some general special moves to throw out.  Overall it's neat to be able to do some crazy looking combo's while having no knowledge of how the game works especially since Tekken is an intimidating game to get into.  Without getting too deep in the weeds Special Style has a ceiling.  It will only carry you so far.  With Modern in SF6, while Classic is still dominant at high level play, I believe Modern can be competitive.  And can reach some pretty high levels.  You won't reach high levels with Special Style.  It's not really an alternate way to play the game.  It is true training wheels you will have to remove at some point.  Sooner the better.

Online is great.  Best Tekken has ever felt.  Some wireless opponents may be sketchy.  Accept those at your own risk.  But nowadays it more of a low risk.

The practice mode and tutorials are superb.  For being such an intimidating game to get into with every character having a couple hundred moves - they seem to being doing almost everything possible to teach basics, bread and butters and get players acclimated to the game.  When watching replays it will give suggestions like in T7.  But now you can take the replay over and actually practice the suggestions given.  Everything the game teaches may not be the most optimal stuff or things you will see at evo.  But it's effective.  You can apply everything to actual matches and see results.  Again, just superb practice mode and tutorials.

For me, it's a toss up between SF6 and Tekken 8.  Both titles bury MK1 in the dirt face down.  SF6 is probably a better choice for most people.  My 11 year old daughter and I have a much better time playing locally with Modern controls.  She even plays some ranked online here and there.  I am personally better at Tekken as I been playing off and on since Tekken 3 and it is a series that rewards skill earned in previous entries.  So I may be a bit biased also.  The training mode and tutorials are best in show.  I don't feel taken advantage off with silly micro transactions and battle passes.  Both SF6 and Tekken 8 are great games for different reasons.  Get em both if you can.

Tekken 8 has taken fighting games to new heights. Tekken has always been an extremely difficult fighting game to learn for new comers and it still is difficult but Tekken 8 is the most accessible Tekken in the series for new players. The game has amazing tutorials, practice features and really goes in depth to teach you the ropes on how to play the game proper. They also have a 'special style' feature that resembles SF6 modern controls and makes for a fun experience even for those who are completely new to fighting games. 

Every character in the game is juiced up with new moves and crazy buffs that make every character a serious threat especially with the new 'Heat' mechanic which I think makes this game incredibly fun and stands out from other fighting games. 

Harada, Murray and the Tekken team at Bandai Namco really focused not only on amazing gameplay but they put a heavy focus on single player features and content that I personally think blows SF6, MK1 and honestly any other fighting game out of the arena. Amazing story mode, possibly the greatest fighting game story mode of all time. The music, the atmosphere, the stages all make for an amazing experience. New Jukebox feature allows you to pick and choose which songs, from the entire godlike Tekken music catalog, you want playing during fights, main menu and other menu locations like customization screen. 

If you're not a super competitive person or are nervous to play ranked/players matches online with other people, you can literally try out Tekken ball mode, hang out with friends in Arcade area with you custom avatar and they have a ton of hilarious and really cool side story campaigns for each character that shows a video of what they are up to outside of the main story. Also, my personal favorite when I'm not playing ranked and that is Ghost Mode. You can literally play against some of the best player's in the world's Ghost AI that plays just like them or you can play against your own Ghost, who will resemble your play style. This is truly one of the greatest features of all time and it shows off how far video games have come and will continue to go in the future. 

If you are a competitive player and want to get good at Tekken or learn matchups, they track and keep record of all of your fights so if you're getting destroyed by annoying characters like Panda or Asuka, you can go to your replay of that match and the game will not only show you what is punishable and how to tech throws you were getting hit by but they also allow you to literally jump in to the replay and take control of your character to see what you could have done to counter what the opponent was doing. Truly next level stuff here.

Online netcode is very good, rematches are instant, no load screens like old Tekkens. Character customization is hilarious and very cool, they allow you to make some amazing custom skins with their customization features.

Tekken 8 has something for everyone and I can honestly say that Tekken 8 might just be the greatest fighting game of all time. 

I ABSOLUTELY recommend buying this game.

Very Complete game on launch.

The combat in this game is very fun. As my first 3D fighter there is a lot to grasp, but the process is very fun and rewarding. I really enjoy that every round you have your heat and ultimate so there is no cross round resource management and every round you can feel free to use everything at your disposal.

Also the customisation is great, Avatar customisation is ok. Character customisation is amazing and the Jukebox is a very welcome touch.

32 Characters on launch is amazing and not enough can be said about it. Feels like an endgame roster yet there is so much more to come.

Practice has some amazing tools as well which helps you improve yourself against anything you want. The AI Ghosts are also very cool and you can practice against anyone you want and it doesn't feel like a robot playing.

Online feels super smooth when its running well but sometimes there are more matches with small hitches than I would like. However overall it runs really well more often than not. Just be sure to use an ethernet cable.

At the end of the day its a fighting game, if you are willing to grind and enjoy the actual game play along with all the extra content you are in for a great time.

I've played my fair share of Tekken before but tbh, I was never a fan and was never captivated by it. Maybe due to the fact that I'm a street fighter fan and in general, I only really played fighting games during my childhood/arcade era. 

Now fast forward to 2024 after for dunno what felt like a millennia, Tekken wasn't even in my radar of games but for some reason just to get out of my monotony, I decided to just f**k it I'll buy whatever is on release that's out of my usual genre of games. And dang, it's whole a different experience! I felt the nostalgia of my childhood going to the arcades after school (I'm not a delinquent) I never felt like this for so long. I'm enjoying this game so much, like very very much! 

So anyways, Tekken 8 was really good. It has all the tools you need to keep your interest and be a better player especially for beginners such as me who never played fighting games for so long. One thing I would also like to emphasize is on how responsive the controls of this game. Not only it's visually impressive but it's    so responsive to play. That's why it feels good to play. 

Performance - Absolutely amazing. It's rare for a day one release to run almost without problems.

Still have much things to discover from this game and I'm excited to continue my journey with Tekken 8. 
It's a 100% recommendation. GET THIS AWESOME GAME!

Best Fighting Game in 2024

TLDR: For Tekken the story in 8 is 10/10, all but 2 of the character story were perfect, online matchs feels great (I only play 4+ bars), probably the easiest to learn Tekken in a while though it's still a fighting game so it's still not super "easy" to learn and play online, and with that said like always Tekken is one of the best couch co-op fighting games out there because if your just playing with friends you can just button mash and do ok. Only complaints are the fact Tekken 8 has less customization then Tekken 7 which didn't have much for a Tekken game, and the fact the devs heard some people don't like rage arts so they added heat smashs which are just unarmored rage arts that do little less damage but are super positive on block.

The story in 8 was probably the first Tekken game in a long time that I wanted to finish, even though it's very corny/cringey. I love it's being called anime fast and furious because it's pretty spot on, last couple Tekken stories had pretty bad pacing but this one is just non-stop action and every time you think it can't get anymore insane it proves you wrong.

I loved all the character story endings but I feel like KIngs and Pauls were missing just a little more at the ends.

Can't complain about the online, yea I have it set to only 4+ bars but I've had very little issue even wifi matchs.

I know the 180+ move list can be intimidating, but like I told people in Tekken 7 your only going to be using around 20-30 of the moves so don't worry about trying to remember all 180+ moves. And in Tekken 8 it seems like most characters need to use even less. On top of that it's not uncommon for different characters to have similar moves with similar inputs and if they are good on one character they're normal good on others.

Biggest complaint is the lack of character customization, I thought Tekken 7 was bare bone but 8 is a whole new level. I like how you can recolor nearly ever little detail on character default skin and alts but that's about the only positive thing I can say about the character customization.

I get that rage arts are like by people who don't play fighting games often, and honestly I personally don't have a issue with rage arts seeing how if their blocked they are easy to punish. I do have issue with heat smashs though, because with out smashs the heat system would be a ok new edition to the game.  Heat bust is a good "get off me" or combo extender, I really like that while in heat mode different moves get empowered, and heat dash is useful on some character. But heat smash is such a weird design because why use the empowered moves? Why use heat dash to make moves that normally can't combo work in a combo? Why do either of them when you can just heat burst and then immediately heat smash if it's blocked why would you care the person pushed so far away they can't do anything about it and if it hits then you do a big chunk of damage for just pressing a single button. I've played Tekken for a long time but I am not even close to a "pro" at all. So when I do real good in a round and I get the opponents hp down to right at the point they enter rage with only being jabbed a few times myself, and then they heat burst and keep backing up until they see me do anything, including dashing, and they burst doing big chunk of damage and then they wait for me to push anything again and then they rage art and because Yoshi doesn't have anythings to do they remaining hp in one hit they get the rage art. So by hitting just 3 buttons to burst, smash, and rage art they do as much damage as I did by "playing properly" or sometimes it's just enough to kill me even though I've only been hit by a few jabs vs the opponent who I've side stepped counter hit into full Yoshi combo two or three times, it feel really bad when it happens 3 or more times in a single hour. Smashs should not be even remotely positive on block and if they just throw it out and just completely miss, their character should be left reeling for a good long while.

This is gonna be one of my first reviews with a focus on the multiplayer rather than the single-player. For reference, I wasn't a Tekken fan before this entry. I disliked Tekken 7 and how difficult it was to learn. However, I haven't had nearly the same experience with this game. Inputs feel better, the characters are all extremely cool, and I feel like the training the game gives me is so much better. I love the character variety and some of the universal mechanics making it easier to play the game and enjoy it. I think it is a great competitive game that you can jump into, find a character you like and play. Character customization is okay, but apparently it is worse than other Tekken games but I can't give much input. The music is fire, and includes earlier games so if you don't like this one, you can do some of the newer ones. I think the story is absolute hot garbage of bullshit that makes absolutely no sense. It feels extremely rushed and everything moves so quickly. It is better than Guilty Gear Strive but looked at Street Fighter 6's in comparison, this one is awful. But, the core gameplay of competitive fighting is just fantastic.

Tekken 8 is solid, has good netcode and for the MOST part great online connections. Whatever you do, DO NOT play people on wifi if you want to save your sanity. Other than that, game has one of, if not the best training mode systems for a fighting game to ever exist. Game teaches you punishes for EVERYTHING for every character, ranking is good in this game, doesn't take long to rank up, you can get to red ranks super quick. The lounge is also a nice addition to tekken and the lobbies work properly. I've played people from asia and korea, japan etc. and the matches were more playable than people on a wifi connection LOL. Overall, feel like this is one of the best fighting games made right next to sf6, as a 3d fighter it feels solid and it really makes you learn the game in order to become better with many tools to do that. Definitely recommend to try and give it a shot. Story mode is also peak tbh

Tekken is one the biggest fighting game franchises in the history of gaming. 
This game proves why, after more than 10 major releases, Tekken is still on the Mount Rushmore of fighting games.

Beautiful design of stages and characters, incredible depth of gameplay, options, moves and customizations to keep everyone happy, from the casual gamer to the  online Ranked system grinders.

For the moment, the singleplayer features might be a bit lacking and the navigation of the online matchmaking systems could be (a lot) more intuitive.

If you enjoy your 1 v 1 fighting games and an incredible deep and satisfying combat system with a ton of fighters with even more moves, option and individual styles, get this game.
Unlike some other Triple A fighting game release (everyone's looking at you, NRS!), this game is worth every penny!

A ruthless and merciless martial artist. Feng has a lust for power and fighting, which can be seen as both a strength and weakness, as while he was skilled enough to be the best in his class, his greatest flaw is that his addiction and impulsive urge to start fighting eventually got the better of him, causing him to murder his master after he scolded him for fighting outside the dojo. He seeks to become the strongest fighter in the world, and is not afraid to show his full power against any opponent that gets in his way, and has destroyed many dojos and hurt many innocents in his wake to obtain what he desires. He also seems to loathe weak people, as he says to Asuka, "the weak don't deserve to live", when responding to why he attacked her father.

First, start off with an Electric Wind God Fist. This attack has increased hitsun, allowing you to true combo into an Electric Wind God Fist. Now, because of this move's extra hitsun, you should have enough time to combo into an Electric Wind God Fist. After that, for a true combo, follow up with an Electric Wind God Fist. Next, take advantage of the high hitstun of Electric Wind God Fist, and perform an Electric Wind God Fist. Finally, finish the combo with an Electric Wind God Fist. After finishing the combo, continue the combo with an Electric Wind God Fist. And if you did everything correctly, you should be able to use that move's massive hitstun for a finisher. In this case, EWGF, that's an acronym that means Electric Wind God Fist.

Tekken 8 improves upon Tekken 7 and goes above and beyond its predecessor to the point its hard to go back to Tekken 7.
First off they mad the combat more aggressive while still keeping the core Tekeken combat, the new heat system isn't as broken as I thought it would be and can consumed very quickly with the chip damage not being too bad when blocked.
The story mode is a big difference compared to Tekken 7's with having a lot more bombastic action and more higher stakes while still paying respects to the older story beats helping newer players understand Tekken 8's story.
Overall a very solid fighting game with a surprisingly decent story mode (for a fighting game story) and also Multiplayer is great and works so far, just get ready to come across those players who know how to play more than you and beat you for a bit.

Fun gameplay, fresh new graphics, lots of single player content...

Awful internet infrastructure. 5/10 of my online matches have had latency issues, complete lag spikes that ruin any plans i had of playing a fun game. This is on top of the noticeable frames of input lag on my side of things. It feels like playing underwater. The devs refusal to implement state of the art netcode out of PRIDE is awful. While this game was in development, fans urged Harada and the dev team to implement a netcode similar to Street Fighter 6's, which is amazing to play on. Didn't happen. 

This is being sold on Steam, a platform where 95 percent of players use online multiplayer when playing with others. I find the lack of great netcode (Like street fighter's) to be a glaring problem with Tekken 8. After story mode and single player, you will want to turn to online matches for fun, the poor netcode and online experience persists from Tekken 7, which really sucks after waiting so long.

Edit: So I learned something cool, If you go into game settings you can change the netcode system to "prioritize fluidity." You can also restrict matchmaking to 5 bars (near perfect) connection only. ALSO you can choose to not match against any Wi-Fi players and prioritize ethernet. So now, after you have removed 98.5 percent of the matchmaking playerbase, only 3/10 of your games will be laggy and feel awful. Try it out :)

TLDR: It is clear the Tekken team put a lot of time making this game look and sound beautiful, but the choice to ignore easily available netcode that would perfect this game, out of pride, is a horrible mistake that prevents this game from being the amazing next-gen fighter it could have been.

[h1] TEKKEN has now undoubtedly cemented its place as my favorite fighting game franchise of all time  [/h1] 

TEKKEN 8 is the culmination of decades of experience by the Bandai Namco team mixed with love and trust in their own franchise. Every aspect of the game, from graphics to gameplay, has been polished to its ultimate form in a show of dedication and passion. This series is, and always will be, the most hype and engaging of any fighting game series in my opinion. No other fighting game gets the same emotional response out of me such as this one. The overarching story for TEKKEN may be convoluted and nonsensical at times but The Dark Awakens is honestly one of the best stories in a fighting game to date. 

[h2] The Dark Awakens [/h2]

This has got to be one the hypest, most balls to the wall, action-packed single player modes in a Fighting Game to date. Its a short story, yes, but from beginning to end, the action never stops. Initially I thought it wouldn't be anything special but I'm glad to say I was completely wrong. Not only is it an entertaining story, it also manages to give far more character to some of the TEKKEN 7 cast that were left than TEKKEN 7 ever did. On top of that, fans of the series will absolutely love all the little details and references to past games and media. Great choreography and a blood-pumping soundtrack come together to raise the experience far above the rest. I've played my fair share of single player story modes but [h3] NONE [/h3] ever managed to be this exhilarating. I was screaming like a little girl as my skin crawled from PURE, UNFILTERED HYPE. God, I can't even begin to describe the final battle. I began tearing up a little bit as the jaw-dropping action took place and Jin faced his fears and limitations. This single story mode ALONE cemented TEKKEN as my favorite fighting game franchise. Previously I would go back and forth between SF and TEKKEN but not anymore. 

[h2] Gameplay [/h2] 

TEKKEN is all about personal fights. Very rarely will a character have a projectile. Most fights are face-to-face and close quarters. Your opponent will almost always be within striking distance at any given moment. TEKKEN has changed very little since TEKKEN 4/5, only deciding to improve on what's already there and adding to what's already shown to work. If it's not broken, don't fix it, right? TEKKEN allows for people of all skill levels to have fun with the game, but once you decide to look deeper, you'll discover just how complex it all can be. TEKKEN rewards your time studying and learning with full, uninterrupted control of your character.  The sheer amount of moves characters have may be daunting or even overwhelming for newcomers but, in time, you'll learn to trim the fat and focus on 15-30 key moves for your own character and your opponent's. I will admit I was a bit concerned regarding the new direction TEKKEN was heading with this entry. 
This game's theme is certainly [h3] AGRESSION [/h3]. I'm glad and relieved to say I'm enjoying this new entry very much. Defense will always be a huge part of TEKKEN and you can be as defensive as you like, and once you finally decide to make your move, you'll have the opponent guessing for their life... provided you don't take too much chip damage of course. 

[h2] Online [/h2] 

I'm delighted to say the online play is simply the best the series has ever had. I could go on and on and praise it for days on end but you'll just have to believe me. Those disgusting Wi-fi users are still a toss up between a good enough match or an awful, stuttering experience. Just deny the match and move on. Buy a freaking 5 dollar ethernet cable, damn it! 

[h2] Extras [/h2] 

Customization is not as good as it was in previous entries but its serviceable enough. You'll easily be able to make something you like, though I'll never be able to shake the feeling of what could have been. Regardless, if I love the way my character looks, that's a surefire way to get me to come back. 
Jukebox is finally here for every platform and I love how every single OST from the TEKKEN series is here. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

TEKKEN 8 is simply the best parts of the franchise put together into one. TEKKEN is the best (and only) 3D fighting game franchise and for good reason. It was all worth the wait.

Game is so good, It performed Ultra's or Fatalities on the rest of the FGC's games.

Story mode - Is amazing!

Super Ghost Battle - A Juiced version of treasure battle able to download ghosts of other players both pros as well as friends, You are even able to battle your own ghost.

Tekken Ball - It's back and better then it was in Tekken 3 or other Tekkens.

Has ranked and casual online modes.

Has cross-play.

Has Rollback.

Has a large launch roster of various fighters that are actually different from one another.

Has customization options you unlock by playing the game versus charging your card.

Has a theater mode to get a since of what happened in previous titles.

Has a Jukebox mode to customize Tekken 8's banger of a sound track as well as import tracks from previous games and assemble your own custom lists.

The multi-tiered stages with breaks on walls and floors are amazing! They were good in previous ones, but now they blow out "Level-oution" from games like Battlefield and that's a whole other genre.

It's like they took all the best things from Tekken 3, Tekken 5 and Tekken 7 and added new tools, Systems and modes on top of what made those games good as well as smoothing out the gameplay experience to where all movement feels very fluid and their is minimal input delay regardless of platform.

It bridges the gap between "believable" and over the top "anime" and "wire" action sequences much like great Kung-Fu cinema movies of the 60's - 80's, As well as more modern titles. 

If enjoy watching, Jackie Chan, Bruce Lee, Donnie Yen, Michelle Yeoh or Keanu Reeves in their big awesome action movies and over the top fight sequences. You will probably also enjoy this game.

Good:

> Has some single player content
> Improved SS opens up mindgames
> Improved Throw system makes them more viable
> Can view other players' replays 
> Can take over replay and lab situation without manually going into practice mode and finding the move in the move list
> Instant rematch 

Bad:
> Rank system has no placement matches and good players goes through lower ranks winning 20+ games in a row.
>> Fix: placement matches and make Tekken ladder ELO based.

> In replays it is hard to lab near end of the round as it automatically skips to the next round.
>> Fix: at the end of the round ask player for confirmation if he want to jump to next round.

> After the match if opponent declines , but you accept rematch you still have to wait for timeout to be able to go back to standby.
>> Fix: Allow going to standby

> You cannot exit game in the shortcuts alt+f4 is faster.
>> Fix: make exit game button default in the shortcut menu.

> You cannot tell if move is + on block visually for all such moves, not good for game with 100 moves per character
>> Fix: Adjust animation

Ugly:
> No punishment for pluggers.
>> Fix: make them lose rank. Time out them from ranked.

> Leaderboard show only top 10`000 people, I cannot see all my friends there and where they are.
>> Fix: Allow me to see all my friends on leaderboard - even if they are below 10k place

> In leaderboards when filtering by friends it sometimes gets stuck loading the list forcing me to alt+f4
>> Fix: Don't force me to stay in leaderboard tab while the search is going 

> No improvement for rollback netcode. Wifi is unplayable.
>> Fix: Hire people from Capcom

> Replays sometimes break after you take them over. And go completely async even if you go back to the replay.
>> Fix: find bug and fix it
Does not deserve negative reviews for connections issues, that will be fixed. This is a complete game from top to bottom and deserves the praise it's getting.
