I love the game but so far the online experience has been kind of awful. Even if it's a 4 or 5 bar match if its WiFi it's basically unplayable. I can't get matches unless I'm in a battle lounge and even then it takes ages to find one. If I want a good connection I have to play without cross-play and if I'm not playing cross play it seems to takes forever to get a match. I also get disconnected from the battle lobbies quite often. I'm playing wired on PC so I really don't think this should be happening. Customisation is a big step down IMO. But the single player content is really good and the game is a ton of fun, loving all the characters so far. If you like Tekken you're probably already playing it. If you're new to Tekken and are looking to jump in then this is a great starting point, especially if you live in a region like Europe or America. If you have a friend who's around the same skill level I think this would be the best possible fighting game to play together. Between the customisation and the cool factor, you're in for a treat. If you have no friends who play fighting games and aren't good at Tekken at all (like me) it might be a bit tough to get into. But I still recommend it if you're interested in fighting games and have the money to spare.

Very good, taught me a lot about fighting games even just in the first 40ish hours I've played so far.
Definitely hard to get into, but once you "get" Tekken, it's easily, and very oddly the most chill fighting game I know of.
Something about how flow is achieved? I don't quite have good words for it at all. It's super chill once you kinda get whats going on and you "figure out how to figure stuff out", if that makes sense. 

For those who've never played a fighting game before, this is both the easiest and hardest one to get into imo. For the easy stuff, it's fairly intuitive? Traditional 2D games are VERY archaic, they're intuitive once you get them but... Tekken kinda just makes sense. The high mid low game is both super easy to get and also very difficult to master. Yeah, you can "get" ducking highs or whatever, but I can only IMAGINE my self fuzzy blocking lows DURING neutral movement right now. Let alone reading wave dash mix, or whatever else is going on.

Execution is ALSO very easy... and some of the hardest in the genre. The button buffer is SUPER generous, movement buffer doesn't exist afaik. You can get good damage off a combo with 10 minutes of practice. You can get great situational damage off a combo after 600 hours of practice... it's crazy.

If you value movement in games? Specifically movement being a skill and something you can express yourself with, I HIGHLY recommend Tekken. 

Oddly, it reminds me of Melee? In a way? Specifically just that movement is hard, your character can be in a lot of states that cause specific attacks to happen. Neutral in Melee is obv VERY different but the core idea of turns being a little more loosely defined is VERY apparent in Tekken. If you're minus 1 to idk 3 or 4 in Tekken, it's fairly reasonable to just... move out of the way of someone taking their turn back with a jab, so you can steal their turn. They can respond by delaying their jab and catching your movement. Very cool stuff!

This game is a near Masterpiece. Unfortunately I've run into performances issues, including Several "Initialize error" messages and long load times. That could be my fault however as my CPU processor is old. Other than that this game has so much to over. The amazing fighting mechanics that Tekken has always been known for are present and over thirty characters in the base roster. This game has something to offer for every fighting game player. The Cinematic story mode titled The Dark Awakens is quite possibly the most ambitious, epic, and memorable fighting game story mode every produced. Its shorter than what you may be used to if you play MK and Injustice but it packs quite a punch. Jin Kazama goes through a tremendous character arc, one that brought genuine goosebumps and heartfelt moments. The final fight is beautifully choreographed and concludes the story with a bang. The ending leaves you wants more as expect and there are still loose ends to be tied up and explained but its good that we have a solid story arc to prop us into the next generation of Tekken after the somewhat lackluster Tekken 7 story mode. 
      Besides that there is a lot to do. The Arcade Quest is a fun little mini game reminiscent of old school Arcade play as well as a clever nod to Tekken world Tour competitive gaming. The new Replay and Tips feature adds so many tools to help player improve their skills and the New Super Ghost Battle ensures that you can play against anyone you want even when they are not available Online. You can even fight yourself. Its a brilliant feature and one I hope they will continue to build on in the future. The Presentation of this game is sublime. Namco really stepped it up with the visuals and this is apparent in the epic redesigns many of the characters have. I look forward to playing this for many years to come and to see the Tekken fandom and community grow after this new release. This is phenomenal and the best game to come out of this three decade old franchise since Tekken 5. What a time to be alive!

I don't normally get into fighting games, but Tekken 8 won me over.

Positives:
- currently no micro transactions or battle passes
- good quantity of single player content
- quality character cosmetic customization
- there is an official discord server to socialize on (link on Steam store page)
- large 32 character base roster
- crossplay

Game Modes:
- Arcade Quest (single player campaign including tutorials)
- Story: The Dark Awakens (single player story-driven campaign)
----- Gallery: cutscenes to recap the stories of Tekken 1-7
- Character Episodes (single player set of 5 VS CPU battles with some story)
- Arcade Battle (single player set of random 8 VS CPU battles)
- Tekken Ball (PvP & PvC)
- Offline Versus (PvP, PvC, CvC)
----- Ghost: "ghosts" are AI players made from analyzing player data. you can play the AI made from your own ghost as well as download and fight against other player's ghosts
- Online (Quick Match, Ranked Match, Private Sessions, Fight Lounge)
- Practice (includes combo challenges)

Additional Features:
- Replays
- Online Leaderboards
- Rematch feature in online matches
- Avatar customization (for Online Tekken Lounge and Arcade Quest game modes)
- you can practice while you are in an online match queue

Personally, I prefer the graphics and art direction of Tekken 8 over the other recent fighting games. Tekken 8 doesn't take itself too seriously and is intentionally ridiculous and over the top with characters like giant panda bears.

Tekken 8 is a 3D fighting game; your character can juke to their left & right and thus are not locked to a 2D plane. There are a lot of 2D fighting games on the market, but not a lot of quality 3D fighting games. So, I think it is likely Tekken 8 will maintain a healthy player population for a long time.

Tekken 8 has been my first Tekken game. Tekken is a bit notorious for being hard to get into, and I can definitely see why. It is complicated and will take a long time to master. However, there are a lot of game modes to help beginners, so despite the complexity Tekken 8 is proving to be a good entry point to the franchise.

- I'm gonna enjoy this game for many years forward.

Easily the best bang for your buck fighting game in the last decade, with many different and fun casual modes. It's got a very good and well-balanced character roster, decent character customization, beautiful stages, great music (plus jukebox mode) and a solid online netcode. If there was ever a time to get into Tekken or fighting games in general as a casual player, it would be now.

Personally I've never been a huge fan of fighting games aside from Smash Bros. because of the knowledge required to play them at a competent level. However, with Tekken I feel like the game was made so well for people who are new to fighting games to get used to the play style without the need to remember various button inputs. I am having so much fun with this game and if you are me to fighting games (like me) and are afraid of being overwhelmed, don't. This game is worth your time.
LAGGGGGGGGGGGGGYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY

As someone who grew up on this game while peers were on FPS games, this is what I really needed in the gaming scene. I haven't had any games to look forward to in a while besides CS2, which is really undewhelming, and MGS3 remake, which will allow me to replay another favorite from my childhood.

Anyways, onto the Tekken review. 

GAMEPLAY

If you've played Tekken before... it's Tekken alright. If you haven't, then you're in for a treat to one of if not the best fighting game of the past 10 years. New mechanics have been introduced that close the skill gap, which is good for newer players, yet will still reward veterans. I'd be saying nothing important to actually explain what Tekken is, but Tekken 8 is a damn good representation of how a Tekken game [i] should [/i] play.

CHARACTERS

I'll try not to stir the pot of who I think should be in the game or not, but I think I can say something all Tekken fans can agree on when I say the base roster is great. Whether or not it has some of my favorites is irrelevant, for new players specifically, this roster gives a huge variety! For veterans, I'm sure most of us can agree that there are characters here that we all know how to play already, despite some of us missing characters who were in 7. For instance, in 7 I was a big Kuni, Lili, and Julia player; despite Kuni and Julia not being here, at least we have Lili still, and I've taken a liking in Reina!

STORY

Usually in Tekken, the story is serviceable enough and is usually nothing to write home about. In 8, I enjoyed the story and like before, it wasn't anything to write home about. SPOILER IN HIDDEN TEXT, CLICK FOR SPOILER ! ! ! [spoiler] The ending where Jin slowly goes back to Kazama style was awesome, especially paired with his T3 theme! I do think the whole Angel Jin character design was a little goofy but I'm all for it building up to the ending fight. [/spoiler]

MULTIPLAYER

This is the core of all fighting games... and the ranked system is great! There's very little lag in my experience, and I've played with friends who live across the world from me, as I am in NA East, I've played with friends in Japan and eastern Europe with no lag to speak of. 

PRACTICE TOOLS

This is [b] HUGE [/b] for all you newcomers considering picking this up. Unlike the previous game, frame data is included with the base game. If you've played fighting games before this feature seems like a given, but since it was DLC in 7, it's great to see it here as part of the practice mode. Speaking of the practice mode, it's the best I've seen in a fighting game yet. You can change so many settings that it's hard to keep track of. You can even compete against a ghost of yourself to find gaps in your playstyle. Besides that, you can watch replays and take control of both characters (as long as the other player is not a CPU), which lets you see how you could have tackled a situation differently. For new players and people like me who go into this game labbing off day one, this is amazing to have available.

CONCLUSION

If you've never played Tekken before, this game will welcome you with open arms. If you've played in the past, it's all the same. The hype is justified for Tekken 8, pick it up and try something new. Good luck out there! 

P.S. if I PEWGF you in online don't take it personally.

The Story mode is awesome for what I've see so far, but the gameplay doesn't let you play it the way you want sometimes, it's like an interactive movie. And every single gamemode, I had to disable Special Style. In Arcade Quest, I'm still disabling it almost every battle.

This game is great for what it is so far, but I could only imagine the quality-of-life fixes coming.

My hours are kind of a lie, since I left it idling almost an entire day when I went to work, but I wanted to give it an honest try.  This was my first Tekken game - I'd mostly come from a background of SF and more anime 2D fighters.

Candidly, I wish I hadn't bought Tekken 8.  I don't think it's a bad game - by all accounts if you liked the previous Tekken this one is absolutely supurb.  I just know it isn't a game I have any interest in getting to learn or getting good at.  I feel like it plays so differently from any other fighter I've played that I have to just learn so much nuance specifically for a single franchise that I also just... don't care about.  None of the characters clicked with me - visually or gameplay wise.

But what it does? It does fine.  Netcode is good.  Graphics are good. Controls are responsive.  Has a really good tutorial and solid training mode.  I just have massive buyer's remorse as I know this is now a $70 digital paperweight on my steam account.  That's on me - the Demo didn't win me over either but it also only had 4 characters and I thought for sure at least one character would speak to me.  But, they didn't.

Anyway, that's why I'm saying I don't recommend it - for players like me, I don't.  For fans of 3D fighters or previous Tekken games you'll probably have a blast.  I doubt I'll be touching it again - I should have gone with my gut.  A life lesson learned, I suppose.

What can I say, the best Fighting Game 100% full stop.

[u]STORY[/u]

Out of the current Fighting Game titles, Tekken went and did and make an epic story possible. It was well written leaving you wanting for more. To add, it respected the legacy of the game since Tekken 1 by doing callbacks through music, in-game sequences, and gameplay changes as you play through the story.

Story is a 11/10 for me. 

[u]Gameplay, Online, and Monetization[/u]

1. Gameplay - HEAT is the new system added. A new system to promote more aggressive play. It added things like chip damage and heat specific moves. It's sort of an install/power-up for all your characters when you enter this state. its quite fun imo. The game also has been simplified for beginners and a well implemented tutorial system.

2. Online/Netcode - Its a huge step up from Tekken 7. Very responsive and overall a great experience so far for me. However there's still some hiccups. If people do not have their PC optimized or running the game where their pc barely handles the game it could cause problems on your end as well. Overall though, if everything is running smoothly be it on the internet or hardware side, it's a smooth experience.

3. Monetization - There's no monetization practice except the seasonal characters, that's it. Everything can be obtained in game.

Overall, it's my favorite fighting game. If you're looking to get into Tekken, now would be the perfect time.

Tekken 8 is the logical evolution of the series after Tekken 7. The overall presentation is excellent- the visuals and music are a step up from the last game. The mechanics are largely unchanged from the prior game, except with the awkwardly named Heat system which (name aside) is a nice addition that rewards aggressive game play. Online functionality is pretty solid as is the starting roster of mostly returning fighters. There are a few that I wish would return (Lidia, Katarina, Bob) along with a few surprising omissions (Anna, Armor King, Marduk) but I suppose Bamco has DLC to sell. Even Eddy was not safe. 

The single player modes are a blast, the stand out being "Arcade Quest" which is a "power of friendship" type story that helps introduces players to the mechanics of Tekken. This reminds me of a pared down version of Street Fighter 6's World Tour mode, but that is not a bad thing. "The Dark Awakens" is the other single player story mode and a cinematic narrative that goes into the next chapter of the Mishima melodrama. While I am not overly attached to the soap opera-esque narrative, I can say this is a definitive step up from the story mode in Tekken 7 narrated by the world's most boring journalist. While the visuals are stunning, I did find myself getting bored with the match ups towards the end as several of the fights even in the same chapter are between the same two characters who spout off a few lines of dialogue and repeat the same match up. I do hope you also like playing as Jin Kazama (thankfully, I do) since he will be your only choice for the majority of the campaign mode with a few chances to play as Lars and other randos. There is a tournament midway through the campaign that gives you the choice of who you wish to play as and I wish that was explored more. Regardless, the campaign spotlight is on Jin who does get some satisfying character growth especially towards the end of the fifteen chapter story. No one gets dropped into a volcano here. So far. 

I have enjoyed my time so far with Tekken 8 and anticipate it will fully replace Tekken 7 among my friend group. If you are new to the series, this is a fine place to jump in and get ready for the next battle.
Love it, will keep loving it and keep giving me more to love. Story was phenomenal, cinematic's were draw dropping, and the fights.....out of this world, literally. TK8 is THE fighting game

I`ve been a Tekken fan since 1995 and the game has had it`s ups and downs along the way, but Tekken 8 is nothing short of a masterpiece. 

For those struggling to start:
- Choose a character to your liking.
- Remember your character's fastest strikes - to intercept enemies' attacks and to start your own.
- Remember attacks and combos, that hit low (legs) - for the same reason as above.
- Remember attacks with hyper armor - they are super useful to break an aggressive pressing.

Every instrument in the list is useful. You just need to find its use.

When i tried the demo, I was like this heat stuff doesn't feel like it adds much compared to SF6's drive impact, but then it grew on me over time.

That said the single player for this game being only story and arcade quest feels short in comparison leaving with nothing to do pretty fast so if you really wanted to feel like there is a lot of things to do to unlock stuff, this game might feel too short.  Beat all the possible ghost npcs even the ones in the final fight/ super ghost battle computer search.  

Online is great, crashes were really bad at launch but seems fine now.  

Still wish it could do something to make fights happen faster.  It's annoying waiting for other players watching their own cutscenes before readying up or being stuck for the whole timer duration just because we ready up before the other player cancels and leaves.  

for some reason game struggles to find steam friends ingame.  need to invite using steam overlay tho do not put the game in borderless because it softlocks the steam overlay in my experience which was a frustrating time


the tekken fight lounge felt like a rushed attempt to copy sf6's fight hub but I wish there could of been more done to encourage player interaction in the hub as there seems to not be a way to challenge players you see at the moment.  You would have to see them sitting on one of the specific booths (for some reason place is made mostly with single player booths) that have a booth on the other side of it but even that because we have to sit in a single player character selection menu we can't tell if the player is even still there while we have to wait on a bunch of loading screens for what feels like an eternity before the game decides to search for the player on the other booth.


still think sf6 did alot more things right making the player experience feel smooth and quick to the point.  Fight more, stare at loading screens/menus/cutscenes less. i'm not sold on the ghost battle thing as it feels the npcs can just get cheesed out with plus frames.  The replay showing tips is cool tho.  even tho this review seems like i'm complaining alot, still fun game as the battles feel good being the most important part.

TEKKEN 8 directly follows the ending of TEKKEN 7 where Kazuya Mishima successfully removes the existence of Heihachi Mishima leaving everything to Jin Kazama to confront and end the years-long family feud between the Mishimas.

The game’s story concluded the Mishima Family saga very well and very well thought-out as well, and honestly, my only problem with the story is that it’s severely too fast-paced for my liking. I get it, a story mode isn’t really the focus of a fighting game, but hey, this game is concluding a 30-year story. Though, at the very least, TEKKEN 8’s story mode is better than most fighting games’ story, story delivery, and execution, and was a huge improvement to TEKKEN 7’s story mode… one with a very boring 3rd-person journalist who isn’t even relevant to the story.

I’d also like to say that the developers and the TEKKEN TEAM did an awesome job is hiding intricate details, along with musical callbacks throughout the franchise, which will cause surprises when you’ve actually played the story. Even I was not prepared when I saw the changes from the trailer to the final game and it gave off a totally different vibe. It was a beautiful experience. Directors of modern media should follow this, and not show almost everything in a trailer that you don’t even have to watch a film to know what happens.

The Heat System changes a lot of animation and frames of a lot of useful moves and tools of characters which allows them to just trap opponents in the block string—a condition where you are forced to just block your opponent’s attacks, consecutively. There’s also the Special Style which allows newer, or non-fighting game, players to enjoy the game with button mashing to assist the players in doing combos. 

In addition to this, I also like the fact that this is the most beginner-friendly game in the franchise, aside from having the Special Style. See, TEKKEN, in any of its iterations, heavily favors those who played the previous games since your fundamentals are: (1) relies on legacy experience, (2) highly different from any other games. I say this because they included another single-player mode in the game; Arcade Quest.

This mode has a story of its own, but is YOUR story. Throughout the story, you are taught the basics of the game up to the more advanced techniques and mechanics available in TEKKEN 8. It definitely is a welcomed addition to the game. Although, I’d say ArcSystemWorks does a better job at this, making it brief and concise, in comparison to the Arcade Quest which may take up a few hours which may lead to a newer player bored… but it really does its job in holding your hand and making sure you learn properly before you can proceed.. so, pros and cons, I guess.

There is also the return of TEKKEN BALL which is a fan favorite from TEKKEN 3 and the game’s character customization. I have to say, TEKKEN 8 character customization leaves me a bit dissatisfied as the available wardrobe and options are quite limited in comparison to previous games. Despite that, though, people took the saying “limitation only breeds creativity” to heart as people were still able to make stunning customizations but really it wouldn't hurt to have more options. Furthermore, there are also the character episodes where we’re presented with different what-if scenarios, though some are canon.

For a modern game to include multiple modes that you may enjoy offline or solo, it is quite a surprise, considering most modern fighting games only include 2 offline modes, story and versus, and online versus for the most part. I mean, we’ve received more in the earlier days of video gaming but hey, I’ll take what I can and it’s already more than most nowadays. I can’t say it’s cheap though since it’s quite expensive. 


TEKKEN 8 launched with $69.99, $99.99, and $109.99 price tags for Standard, Deluxe, and Ultimate editions and for a general consumer, that’s a little bit too much—but if you’re a fan, like I am, does the price really matter that much? It’s worth it, just for the story’s conclusion alone. On the flip side, like Capcom, Bandai Namco are very generous with sales and I’m sure we’ll be able to see the game on sale in a few months.

Overall, as a fan, the game is definitely a must-get. For those wanting to get into TEKKEN, this is the game to start with. There’s also the History section in the gallery if you want to be caught up to speed with the story before you start TEKKEN 8’s. There’s so much to unload with this game, from the story to its gameplay, and I’m enjoying and savoring every moment. 

	If I have any problems with the game, it’s that it could be optimized better for PC.

This is the Tekken we know and love, a huge improvement over Tekken 7. Now a complete package with great content, features, and, most importantly, rollback netcode. Thank you, Bandai Namco.

For anyone constantly encountering the message "Connection Quality does not meet conditions" when searching for matches, try asking your ISP to change your NAT type to open; this solved my issue.

Tekken 8 offers as much and more than any other modern fighting game.

Story: The story is incredible with pre-rendered cutscenes in a cinematic format with an interesting twist on the gameplay; i.e, you don't play as one character for 5 rounds of combat and then switch to the next. The story follows a protagonist for the most part and fights are broken up by quick time events and other interesting breaks mid game that make it feel fresh for most of its run time. The final chapter of the story is one of the best finale fights/boss fights ever, it is as close to perfect as I could have asked for as a tekken fan.  If you're new to tekken, there are story-line recaps available before you start the main story, it will ask you before you start if you want to watch them if you're unfamiliar with the series and its lore.

Second story-mode/Tutorial mode: The Arcade Quest serves as a tutorial, disguised as a mini story adventure where you create your own tekken avatar, (that will be used for online play in the fight lounge/ battle hub) and venture through arcade to arcade on a personal quest to improve at the game, meet new people, compete in local tournaments, and face off against your rival. It's a tutorial with phenomenal pacing, (it doesn't front-load its information, more so drip feeds you) disguised as a cute little adventure mode, that honestly, all fighting games should seek to emulate in the future.

Online play: The online play is the best it has ever been in the Tekken franchise. Ranked mode, Player matches, hosted lobbies, the fight lounge, group battles, etc. Its netcode has a blend of rollback and delaybased netcode with rollback doing almost all of the heavy lifting. There is no wifi filter, so spotty connections are bound to be spotty if you accept every match you're queued into. For a 3D fighting game, this is the premiere online experience and almost all of the time, feels like you are playing an offline match.

Arcade Mode: The classic arcade mode is present and is exactly what you would expect. There are some niche interactions with specific characters from what I've played, but if you've ever played an arcade mode in a fighting game, you know exactly what to expect from this. 

Character Episodes: Character epiosdes are back, this time feature 4-5 fights before achieving your character ending, all pre-rendered cg cutscenes with heartfelt and goofy moments alike. Yoshimitsu and Kazuya character endings stand out to me, alas I have not completed them all yet. You're pitted against lore relevant friends and rivals before fighting your biggest rival in the final fight. It's back and it's great.

Tekken Ball: Tekken ball returns in its best rendition in Tekken 8. This mode is incredibly fun, more fun than it has any right being, with wacky interactions and customizable balls i.e, beach ball, iron ball, globe projection ball, and more. Can be played online via the beach area of the fight lounge.

Graphics: This is the best Tekken has ever looked and is arguable one of the best looking games on the market at the moment and is visually stunning from the fore to backgrounds. some stages are interact-able in more ways than expected, like being able to kick llamas off of a cliff, mid combo, on Ortiz Farm stage for example. The pre-rendered cutscenes are fantastic and the gameplay is remarkably comparable. 

Customization: Avatar, Character, and player customization are possibly at its peak for this franchise. Tekken fans can rejoice in knowing that their playercards, player profiles, etc are fully customizable, just as they were in Tekken 7. Character customization rivals that of Tekken 7 and may even be greater, being able to customize each characters Hair/hair-color, eyes, makeup, glasses, skin color, clothes, tops, pants, shoes, hats, accessories, etc. I've spent several hours creating famous anime characters in game, like Old man Joseph Joestar, David Martinez, Jotaro Kujo, Terry Bogard, Wolverine, Walter White, Lara Croft, etc. You'll see plenty of goofy stuff online as well.

Sound Design/Soundtrack: Tekken 8 sound design makes you feel how hard hitting devastating combos are and really pack a punch. The counter hit sound effect is clear and recognizable and follows suite with the incredible production this game has. The soundtrack is as great as any other modern tekken game and features the Jukebox customizable mode where not only are you given access to every song from every tekken game, ever, you are able to customize your own playlist and mix and match songs to fit with any menu screen or stage in the game. Truly amazing.

Practice Mode/Replay System: Tekken 8's practice mode is top notch and chalk-full of features rivaling any other current fighting game, allowing you to do combo challenges for all characters, run drills with specific setups by having your opponent training dummy shuffle a large mixture of moves you can choose for them to cycle through, and is a contender for premiere training mode amongst all competitive fighters.
        The Replay System is an improvement from Tekken 7's replay system, where when watching you can choose to have tips on every replay for either side(P1/P2) and receive paused notifications mid replay on moves you can duck, punishment options for blocked moves, sample combos on whiffed combos i.e, you launch your opponent but drop the combo/don't know a combo from said launcher, etc. AS WELL AS, it allows you to jump back midmatch(replay) and PLAY as either sides character at any point and can practice specific situations that are difficult to emulate in training mode. You can drill punishment options for an obscure character or a tricky frametrap an opponent put you in etc. Revolutionary stuff.

Super Ghost Battle: This mode uses A.I. to mimic your playstyle and learns from you alone. It is a computer opponent created whenever you play arcade quest with a specific character, and you can train your Ghost to become better and better as it learns movement, punishment, combos, and neutral from the player. It can be reflective of a players skill and will in long term overwrite what it first learned from you as you first learned the game and emulate your playstyle over time. Players can create a ghost for each character in the game and can battle other peoples ghosts, whether its off of a profile from a ranked match you played with a random, off of your friends list, from high ranked players off of the leaderboards, and even the Tekken 8 developers themselves. That's right, you can fight Harada himself.

Conclusion: Tekken 8 is THE Premiere fighting game and is possibly the greatest entry in its long running franchise. Long live the Zaibatsu and play some good-ass tekken!

Another strong launch on Steam for the Tekken franchise.  Too bad Street Fighter 6 could have said the same thing if it wasn't for that disaster of a launch for SFV which led me to check out Tekken and at this point, I think there's no looking back as I am now a Tekken guy after being a SF guy since the SNES days.

Street Fighter 6 had a solid launch and comeback at the $60 price tag instead of the $70 price tag.  I was wondering if Namco was up to the task to at least be on par with SF6 when it came to the single player modes and T8 has more of that than I expected.  You have the Metro City setting in SF6 and then T8 has the main story, individual stories (like in T7), Arcade Quest, and Tekken Ball.  Tekken Ball is an okay inclusion and it could be argued that bringing back Tekken Bowl would have been a better choice but you can always go back to T7 for that.

There were issues with online play on launch day so I simply played the single player modes until before this review.  I loved the fact that you could fight someone up to a best of three sessions and while I was matched up against someone making their first online appearance, it was just fun and competitive to the very end which is what you want unless you are that Orochi in the Arcade Quest

I really enjoyed T7 and I can say that T8 is an improvement over T7 so I can recommend this game without an ounce of hesitation.

I tried Tekken 7 about a year ago and was nervous about if I would like Tekken 8 based off of my experience. I am glad that I didn't let that deter me from picking up Tekken 8. I fully understand why this is one of the top 3 fighting games. There is a wealth of content here for the money you are paying. I would honestly say there is more offline content here than Street Fighter 6. I thank SF6 for getting me into the FGC, but as time goes on I thank Tekken for retaining me.

I liked the ending of Tekken 7 story mode. Tekken 8 story mode is basically that last mission/cutscene just in 90% of the stuff there. So yeah, there is improvement made definitely. The combat itself has a great flow, while the new energy meter keeps the game fresh and not just a reskin to Tekken 7. I would still recommend to play Tekken 7 as well, just to check which combat you prefer.
This is a good game, definitely recommending.

As a newcomer to the series, I can say without a doubt this game is insanely good and fun. I looked up previous games stories and this game is a massive love letter to previous games and the fans very much like the stories of Devil May Cry 5, FF7 remake, Re 4 remake etc. 
There is much to do in this game, you can review matches and the game will tell you what you did wrong and where you could have punished and how, you can download not only your own ghost but even opponent's ghosts as AI and fight against them continuously as a way to learn. This might be hands down the best training mode i've ever seen of any fighting game.
I find that the visuals in this game are stunning. backgrounds/stages, the customization aspect is fun, I don't care much for it but it's a nice touch to let everyone have their own "unique" version of a character, albeit it's used a lot to meme which in itself as also fun lmao. 
The arcade quest thingy is also a nice addition for new players such as myself to learn. 
While Tekken feels a bit overwhelming to learn how to play given how different it is from other fighting games I have played (MK games, SF, DBFZ) and the extensive move lists, im having a blast learning and I can't wait to play more ranked. 
Tekken 8 and SF6 are 2 near perfect games and a prime example of games that are back to form, maybe even peak form. I can easily say I am now a tekken fan.

This is the first Tekken game I have put over 40 hours into. I can say confidently that it covers all of the bases that someone would want in a next gen fighter (minus 120fps). Incredible graphics, exciting competitive game play and a fairly decent campaign. 

With that being said - if you are planning to pick up Tekken for the first time and enjoy matchmaking/online play, you are sadly mistaken... This game is riddled with sweaty neck-beards that have thousands of hours sunk into the franchise. You will spend more time watching your fighter bounce off the ground combo-locked than actually playing.

Purchase this game knowing that you will have to practice and memorize move sets/combos, watch youtube videos and study the living sh*t out of other characters tendencies. Most people will ultimately quit over sheer frustration. Others will enjoy the challenge and practice to get better.

Do you have what it takes? 9/10

Here is my actual review: 

I've been a long-time Tekken fan since my dad introduced the game to me on PS1 when I was 3. Since then I've never missed a single game in the series, and enjoyed every one (yes even 4) even though they may have their faults. 

I can honestly say that Tekken 8 might be the most fun game in the entire franchise. The character's move-sets seem more simple at first, but the game has completely expanded due to the heat system. The game is much more offensive focused, flashy, and faster paced than previous installments. There is much to learn about the game, and I continue to be excited to progress.

There is so much single player content to keep you engaged without even stepping foot in an online lobby, an extensive practice mode with combo trials and frame data (that you don't have to pay for), a jukebox to allow for soundtrack customization which every fighting game should contain moving forward, a replay system that actually helps you learn from mistakes during a match, and new fighters to the series that are so damn fun that I can't stop playing them (Victor supremacy btw).

New fan or old you will love this game. Best fighting game in this new golden era by far.

I bought this game on release specifically because Arcade Quest looked really cool, for some single player content. It seemed like Tekken might have taken a page out of MK's and SF6's books and added a genuinely fun way to pass time when you don't really feel like playing other players.

Arcade Quest is a glorified 4ish hour tutorial.

I _expected_ a few extra tournaments after the tutorial part was over. And sure, I could just play arcade mode - but then I could also just play Tekken 7. I want to take my character from Arcade Quest into post-game tournaments that actually challenge me. There was talk about building up a following of fans and then going into tournaments with people cheering you on - and I don't see _any_ of that. Just scripted interactions with people who've been following you.

The rest of the game is what you'd expect from a Tekken game. It's solid. It's _fine_. But it's also a $70 price tag on something that really isn't much different from Tekken 7.

Did you like Tekken 7? Hopefully not because this removes everything that 7 did well, and replaces it with a coin flip simulator. Heads or tails for who gets a launcher first, because when you get launched, most characters have a very close to 100 to 0 combo with the new heat system. If you're lucky enough not to die from the first combo, then congrats! you get to meet the wall, with wall combos even stronger in this game, you're certain to die, and that's only with a regular wall, where we've got plenty of other flavours of wall to kill you even quicker. With improved mobility in all characters, any wall or barrier break now rewards you with a full combo, often over to the next wall. And now we move on to bomb walls, which explode on wall smash dealing lots of damage, and rewarding you with another free full combo to the other wall. 
Other fun new inclusions are a million particles all over the screen which cloud your view, removing any hope of sight reading your opponent, and a fucked input system because the only thing better than being stuck blocking for 5 minutes while the enemy deals chip damage to you through an un-punishable combo, is the game randomly dropping you back input, along with most other inputs because why tf not.

Game design is over, enjoy 0 skill floor, and 0.1 skill ceiling via slamming your forehead into your controller to for a 200 damage combo

Edit: After playing some more I've come to understand the fun of the game... nah just kidding, this game is coded on spaghetti made of solidified diarrhoea with not even the slightest attempt to balance or bug fix what so ever and somehow is even more toxic than league of legends which I didn't know was possible

GOAT Tekken. I'm surprised to see the reviews less than, "Overwhelmingly Positive," at the time of this post, but for me it is. Online has some kinks to work out, but literally everything else is high quality and varied. Street Fighter 6 reined supreme for several months, but this is currently my, King of Fighters for 2024.

Honest Review : 
Positive :
- They took time to fix issues that ruined the previous franchise and fixed a lot of them (like not being able to go back to the main menu once u go in ranked match mode) etc..
- The new ”My Replays” system is bomb. Long story short u can ”go back in time” and take control over ur character in a replay to learn how to punish the enemy. A good way to learn and adapt.
- Game has really beautiful maps and soundtracks overall. some better than others.
- Air combos seem easier than T7 cause u got more time to react (at least in my opinion).
- Jukebox mode is finally a thing.
- Shoutout to all 3D/ VFX artists, animators, graphic designers (etc.) that worked on the game. it came out flawless.



Negative : 
- No Tekken Tournament mode. I find it funny that they included a fake Tournament Mode Offline in Arcade Mode but not an actual real Tournament Mode like in Tekken 7. Very dissapointed with that...
- No direct ”Tekken Ball” mode Online, only if u go into the Lounge, then go into the Beach Area. 
- Very Unbalanced (King, Dragunov, Jack-8, Reina, Paul & Victor (to name a few) deal too much damage for no reason. Like more than half ur hp is gone and they are full hp themselves type of damage.)
- Hitbox sucks.
- Need more outfit variety in both character and player costumization. they reused the same stuff from tekken 7 too much...so much so that they didnt include actual legacy outfits, like tekken 5/6 outfits. buwomp.
- Game is a bit pricey for what u actually get.

A great Tekken game for casuals, veterans and newcomers alike. New Heat system can take some getting used to, but provides a new dynamic to the game that makes it more explosive than previous Tekken games and increases the skill ceiling for those looking to get sweaty. 

Story mode is also great. Very corny at times, but a love letter to long time fans and with enough intense cinematics to keep you engaged for its 2.5 hour duration (may be longer if you die a lot lol). Those who have played older Tekken games will be happy to see that Character Episodes have the same wild endings that you would expect from the franchise. Arcade Quest mode is a fun way to learn mechanics of the game systematically as you progress through offline ranks.

The customisation - while a wee bit limited - allows for creative outfits and cosplays to let your personality shine through your character. The updated graphics really make the characters and environments look stunning - truly a next-gen fighting game. The return of Tekken Ball is also very welcome. Overall, the offline content will keep you entertained for hours, 9/10 from a long-time fan (would be 10/10 if we had old school team battle).

The new online Fight Lounge seemed a bit weird at first (cartoony avatars in a Tekken game?), but having that experience of seeing other players in an arcade setting is lovely. Tired of ranked matches? Go hang out by the group match arcades and practice some combos - anyone can join at any time to have a few matches. Maybe you're tired after some hectic games, so you can wind down with some Tekken Ball at the Beach Area.

However, the netcode seems to be a bit weird currently. I've had 5 bar matches with certain friends in Tekken 7, but in Tekken 8 we're lucky to match in the first place, and it's usually 1 bar and basically unplayable. This may be fixed in the future but should be kept in mind. Overall, my personal experience with matching is great, especially with the addition of Cross-Play. 90% of my games have been smooth, while the other 10% were still playable, but very janky (for reference I have a wired fibre connection). Another issue, albeit rare, is that I would match with someone, the first game is fine, and then upon a rematch, we would disconnect after the first round.

Online experience - 8.5/10 - would be higher if the netcode is optimised a bit more.

As someone who's played Tekken since Tag 1, I would say this is a worthwhile purchase.

P.S. PC players, PLEASE lower your graphics settings if your system can't maintain 60 fps in actual matches. An online connection can be smooth, but will lag horrendously if one person's PC is struggling to run the game, and I know it's not my 6600 XT.

In general, people considered to be possessed are not regarded as evil in themselves, nor wholly responsible for their actions, because possession is considered to be unwilling manipulation by a demon resulting in harm to self or others. Therefore, practitioners regard exorcism as more of a cure than a punishment. The mainstream rituals usually take this into account, making sure that there is no violence to the possessed, only that they be tied down if there is potential for violence.

Requested and performed exorcism began to decline in the United States by the 18th century and occurred rarely until the latter half of the 20th century when the public saw a sharp rise due to the media attention exorcisms were getting. There was "a 50% increase in the number of exorcisms performed between the early 1960s and the mid-1970s".

Overall, this game feels a fresh breath of fighting games. The mechanics, gameplay, graphics, character customization, etc all seems to be balanced. Although few characters are OP but with each season I'm expecting Namco balancing the stuff. 

Story mode: The story mode gives the sense of Tekken 3 era. Well structured and the story was progressed in exciting manner. All the characters were wisely used in it as compare to previous Tekken titles where some characters were left alone.

Online Experience: Now comes the most important perspective of this game, the ONLINE EXPERIENCE. So far its good. I easily find players online. The rollback features seems to make gameplay smooth but the net code can be further improved. Its not bad neither perfect. I hardly faced DC issue till now but it can't be predicted for near future experience. 


I would say games like Tekken needs to be promoted thinking they bring new stuff into this genre rather than other games which just tweak a bit and release new titles every now and then.

Hands down, Tekken 8 is the best fighting game of this generation.  There may be a little bit of bias here. Since I've been playing Tekken since 1995 on the PS1.  Still, if you look at the amount of content, the 32 character roster, number of game modes with one of the best tutorials "Arcade Quest" that teaches you all of the mechanics of the game.  What more is there to love about this game.  

This version of the game has the lowest barrier of entry for newcomers and still maintains the technical side for us hardcore players who want to go in-depth with our favorite characters.  For $70 you truly get a complete game and then some. From character customization, amazing soundtrack and previous Tekken soundtracks, multiple game modes and a main campaign that could be it's own full feature movie, with additional character story campaign for all 32 characters with their own endings that really ties the knot.  Not many developers create games with this much content on day 1.  Typically, developers want to milk you $$$ with each iteration and update where you'll have to pay 100s of dollars to get the full game experience. 

I highly recommend you purchase Tekken 8.  Even if you get the standard version, you will truly enjoy it!  It is a gem.  This game is going to make a huge impression on a lot of kids childhoods.  It did in mines waaaay back in 95.  I've met some of my best friends playing Tekken.   It's really going to be hard for Bandai Namco to top this one.  Great job, keep up the good work!

However in my case, the disappointment I've with SF 6 is so palpable, that i decided to get Tekken 8 and try it. I enjoy Tekken 7 but this one is better IMO. The story is good, the ghost system is fun and the multiplayer is excellent. I haven't experience any lag online so far in any match. Tekken learning curve can be hard but is really satisfying. I've more fun just doing short combos and trying to maintain good spacing, to the point that even losing matches can be fun by watching the replay and learning counters.

Tekken 8 is the intergalactic wrestling match you didn't know you signed up for. Forget about earthly concerns; now you're throwing punches on Mars, settling family disputes among the red rocks. The character selection is so wild; they've added a sentient slice of pizza as a fighter – yes, you can now battle with the 'Dough-jo Master.' Plot? Who needs a plot when you can witness a showdown between a cyborg grandma and a time-traveling hamster in a mech suit? Tekken 8: where gravity is optional, and your opponent might just be a talking potted plant with a black belt.

If you like deep combat, enjoy learning different strats,tech and improving when ever you can then you are gonna sink hundreds of hours in this game.

Has a large list of characters, feels really smooth, new systems that help players comeback / do cool combos, has options to make the game easier for people, practice modes, and lots of other things. The story is pretty meh overall and very "anime"-like, which took me out of it a bit. Plus, in the story you're playing as Jin like 90% of the time instead of jumping around and learning about other characters and what they are doing. I think MK9 did it much better in terms of a playable fighting game story. Should have really focused on multiple characters and had more things than just the same few fights over and over (and the wonky fighting masses of 3D enemies).

Either way, this is a great continuation of the Tekken franchise. Just wish it had more practice tools, macro setup, a few more characters (saving them for DLC, I guess), and more game modes (Tekken Ball is fun but give us more). Still think Tekken Tag Tournament is better because of the 2v2 dynamic, but this is very solid. Oh, and I wish they brought back Paul Phoenix's "Rapid Fire to Stone Breaker" move... I miss it so much!

Out of all the new fighting games that have come out, this one feels the best to me. Tekken has always been a fun fighting game that anyone can jump into. I am TERRIBLE at fighting games, but the level select on here and the button menu you can pull up during the fights to remind you of what button does what, helps tremendously. The way Tekken handles it's story line is awesome as well. You don't need one character to fight the entire gambit of people in order to flesh out their story. Each one has their own unique story line that you can complete fairly quickly to understand what all is going on. Within an hour I had 3 characters done. 

Again though, the combat is more fluid than other fighting games I've played this year. I haven't played the Tekken Ball yet so I don't know anything about that, but fighting wise it's very fluid. It will take me a while to get combo runs figured out, again I'm terrible at fighting games lol, but Tekken 8 is actually fun to learn and not a slog fest. it's worth checking out, for sure!!
So much fun

I highly recommend this game to all fans of fighting games, especially Tekken lovers.

The story mode is fantastic. It's impressive how smoothly the game transitions from cutscenes to gameplay.

The Character Episodes are great. They remind me of the classic Tekken style where you play through arcade mode to unlock a character's ending. Now, it only takes four stages. Each character's story is unique and worth exploring. Kazuya and Steve are must-plays.

Arcade Quest is enjoyable, offering a mix of story and arcade culture. It’s particularly good for beginners because it includes helpful tutorials.

The character customization isn't as good as in Tekken 7, but it's still pretty cool. You can do a lot with it. I hope they allow more mixing of different costume types soon.

I've had no problems with the online play. They've changed it to best-of-three matches, which is different from the endless matches in Tekken 7. This makes sense for ranked play and the matches load quickly.

The player ghost feature and the Replay and Tips option are great for learning and improving. If you lose to someone online, you can download their 'ghost' to practice against. The ghost system isn't perfect yet, but it's helpful. The Replay and Tips tool is essential for getting better. It analyzes your replays, shows you where you can improve, and lets you practice specific situations. It's already helped me counter certain moves better.

In summary, Tekken 8 is nearly perfect. Any small flaws are minor compared to its overall quality. The graphics are stunning, and the game runs smoothly. I love how the characters interact, and every new character is fun to play.

If you're a Tekken fan or enjoy beat 'em up games, this is a must-have. For newcomers, it's a great introduction to the genre or the Tekken series.

I rate it a 10/10.

It's certainly not without flaws, but T8 is objectively the best fighting game ever made. And although more accessible and appealing to newcomers than ever, it's not any less complex and sophisticated than previous titles. It's a wonderful game for series veterans and complete beginners alike.  

[b]What I love the most:[/b]

- The increased viability of sidestepping
- The improved practice mode. Getting better at Tekken (i.e. 'labbing') has never been more fun.  
- Crossplay
- The arcade lounge  
- T8's newcomers are much more interesting than the ones we got in T7. 

[b]What I think Tekken 8 could improve upon/is currently still missing:[/b] 

- Modes like team battle and survival battle

- Customisation (although I'm fairly certain it's been confirmed that they will add way more options as DLC). On a loosely related note: the men are too muscular, too similarly built, and their asses are way too flat. It just doesn't look right, bc they're all freakishly muscular above the waist. King and Feng are the only two male characters in the game who look like they know what a squat is. The rest has 0 cake and just looks awkward as hell. As for the women: none of them are built like fighters. Where are their muscles? You can't have the physique of a Victoria's Secret model AND throw grown men around. Give the ladies some muscle definition. 

- Less serious stages, like the ones in Tag Tournament. The stages we currently have are a little too serious for my taste. Give me the airport, mall and beach from Tekken 4, or a library, an aqaurium, a casino and Mt Fuji, to name a few examples. 

- Most of the music is just awful. I don't know what happened to Tekken 5's composers, but after Tekken 6, the quality of Tekken's music dramatically dropped (Tag Tournament 2's soundtrack is downright offensive, while 7's is just OK. Of course the Jukebox fixes this problem, but it's still unfortunate that those of us who actually know and care about music, are essentially forced to change the tracks specifically made for this installment, to ones from past games. 

- No Miguel (yet) 

- Ghosts are just really bad. Perhaps not surprising to most other people, but I was really convinced this new AI technology was going to change Tekken forever. Ghosts seem to be quite good at replicating a player's offense, but none of the ghosts I've fought (including those of pro players), had any defensive capability to speak of. The AI clearly isn't advanced enough to actually take into account things like timing, spacing and the opponent's tendencies, so ultimately, playing against a ghost just feels like playing against a much weaker normal CPU. 

[i]For now, I give the game a solid 7,5/10. It has the potential to become a masterpiece, but it'll have to be improved upon in several ways first. Still, there isn't a better fighting game on the market right now, so if you're even a little interested in the genre and somehow don't own T8 yet, you really should go ahead and buy the game imo.[/i]

Very fun game. They have added alot of tips and tricks in their practice mode to help new players such as myself. And if your fingers arent fast enough for combos you can always activate assist mode to help you out. The story is okay at best and only take 2-3 hours to complete.

- High tracking on non-homing moves in general. I was knocked down behind the opponent several times while sidestepping linear moves.
- Easy access to 50/50 mixups across the board, thanks to the new heat system.
- Massive chip damage on + moves.
- Increased range, clean hit range, and tracking on unseeable low sweeps.
- Throws are unbreakable under certain conditions, on some characters, and counter hit throws are a thing now, They have significantly reduced throw tech windows. If you run into situations where you could've sworn you'd teched the throw, this is why.

All in all, I don't like the gameplay direction Tekken is going. The new mechanics still feel overtuned, even though they were massively nerfed since the beta, and should be addressed in upcoming balance patches.

If you don't care about the gameplay balance and just want to play Singleplayer or casual matches, then it's a pretty good game.
It runs great, online matches feel like local ones, and it's just a ton of fun. Recommended for anyone who likes fighting games of any kind.

Each character in this game almost completely changes the game for you with their unique fighting styles, combos and mix-ups. Learning to use each character has never been more rewarding and easy to do with all of these new training features. Harada has clearly made the best Tekken to date and I won't be dropping this game anytime soon. This is some good a** Tekken.

The game is a little more complicated than other kinds of fighting games, however it doesn't seem to be too hard to learn as I prefer to not stress myself over practice combos and do what I can instead. The achievements aren't that stressful either as the online achievements seemed to be the only ones that take more time to accomplish. 

The Arcade Quest story really does help teach people who haven't played Tekken before how the game works and how to do some moves or combos as time progresses. It's a fun game to play and takes more time to get real good at it.

Jun is finally back! I enjoyed the hell out of this game, played through all the single player content and while it's not the strongest compared to other entries in the series, I'm thankful it's atleast here and I enjoyed it alot more than Tekken 7. Loved the stories ending, glad to see a conclusion to some character arcs that have been going on for decades. Overall great game, I'll definitely be playing this online more for fun.

As someone who isn't big into fighting games of this nature, This game is fucking awesome. I have played street fighter and mortal kombat but I believe that Tekken is victorious over both of them. You have so much freedom with character customization and a bunch of characters to play on launch. And there will be more with dlc's coming out every few months. 

A concern that you may have is that you'll suck at this game. I think that I suck at this game but I suck a lot less than I did before I started. Since each button is binded to a limb you can think of combos that make sense without having to necessarily study all the 100 combos each character has. Also the the 3D arenas with interactive elements gives the game so much more life compared to MK and SF. 
The game has quite a few modes. It has a story mode where you play through the Tekken 8 storyline, a mini story mode for each character to go more in depth with their storyline/backstory, A career-type mode where you play as yourself playing through the competitive tekken world. Online battles, offline battles, and tekken ball. It's pretty rad.

[b]This is the fighting game to start with even if you have no experience with fighting games.[/b]

Ultimately if any of this sounds interesting, I would suggest either playing the demo or buying the game and seeing if you like it for 2 hours then refunding it if you decide against it. That way you aren't limited in the things you can look at whereas you can only do the story mode in the demo.

- The game is absolutely not suitable for beginners in online mode. Even at a low rank, you constantly come across some geniuses and nerds who simply do not let you out of combo attacks and win without even allowing you to gain control of the character. The game simply lacks balance. If you just want to try out each character and learn how to play them, I'm afraid I'll disappoint you, it's impossible. Most of the games you will be up against an imbalance character whose movements are simply faster and stronger than yours and you will not have a single chance of winning.
In addition, the game looks too chaotic and aggressive, where your block or battle strategy does not matter when everything around you glows and sparkles, causing headaches. 
- Character customization is terrible. Almost all of them have the same items. There is no variety or specific things that can make each of the characters unique. The worst thing about this is that they are mediocre. The person who made the customization simply has no taste or aesthetics. 
- I don’t understand why critics compared it to Tekken 3. From this masterpiece from childhood, there are only a few characters and a game mode on the beach with a ball. it's just a poor imitation of Tekken 3. 

In this condition I wouldn't recommend the game at full price. Buy it with 50% discount and you will love it. May be.

I don't know what kind of magic they used, but they managed to make the fights run at 60 FPS constantly on my 3-year-old 1660 SUPER. Even at max settings.

Anyways, this game is pretty much like Tekken 7, but with a new system thrown in to make fights a lot more aggressive. I want to point out that everything looks amazing - from the fighters themselves, to the actual stages. I know it's supposed to be a fighting game, but some of the details are almost stealing the show. Also the soundtracks from some of the stages are INSANELY good!

I heard (and saw) people getting crashes and having issues connecting to online matches, but I haven't encountered either of those so far. Might have been just during launch, considering I got the game a few days after.

All in all, I'd say it's worth buying if you like fighting games, and especially if you're coming from Tekken 7. Even if you are new to the genre, they added a neat little mode that simplifies your inputs a lot, which I think will be a lot of fun for people who are still learning.

Really, the only drawback so far has been that my fingers are starting to hurt so much after too many ranked matches.

I like the game, it's pretty fun and I truly do think it's one of the best Tekken's so far but:

-Balance is horrific at launch. Expected, but still unacceptable. Super Armor and "Heat" truly make some characters broken and I'm not excited to see the same 2-3 characters in top 8 tournaments for the next year.

-Customization is awful. It's just lacking. Barely any effort was put into this and for 70$ this is just flat worse than Tekken 7 and definitely worse than Tekken 6 was.(10+ years ago!).

- Technical problems. This game has issues reading controller inputs, the screen flips on customization, the audio lags.... it's a mess.

-Story: It's lame, what happened? Tekken 7 had some hype moments, this one has...sorta hype, mostly bland moments.


I'm sure patches will eventually fix it and I'm fine with that, but can I recommend this game full price as-is? Nah.
Maybe a discount buy tho.

The game is not for everyone. Take an IQ test, if your IQ is under 115, you should not play this game. Check your reaction speed as well. The game only tests fluid intelligence, no other factors. Someone with an intellectual quotient of 110 could even be a Physics PHD and solve high level math equations, but they will never be good at Tekken, as Tekken tests Fluid Intelligence. That is not to say Tekken is a very intellectual or intelligent game; the complete opposite: it's too fast paced to develop strategies. Any strategies you employ will purely be done by your subconscious mental processes in the same way a Boxer does not think about what he's doing in the ring. The irony is that Tekken is simultaneously a brain-dead game, yet one that only checks for fluid intelligence. Maybe because it is only an IQ test it makes sense that no kind of knowledge or experience in the game can help you improve. I wish this post was ironic or coming from a point of view of ignorance, but I have thought about this a lot and I find this conclusion hard to refute. If you test low on the IQ test, save your money, or you will waste your time and nothing but frustration from your lack of progress will await you. I'll have to go ahead give this one a down vote, as I think our time spent playing and practicing should be rewarded, like in most other pursuits in life.

Great successor to 7 with way more cool features like super ghost battle & replay takeover. Jukebox got changed a bit to allow more freedom. Customization is still neat, and tekken ball is very fun. Arcade quest is okay -- it kind of feels like a rushed singleplayer mode in response to sf6's world tour. The lobby is neat. The netcode is sub par, but I've had plenty of perfect connections between ethernet pc to pc matches. Crossplay has a weird unique jitter to it in my experience. The game overall isn't very optimized it seems despite a lot of options to tweak -- I've experienced strange slowdowns in specific matches and it may be because of opponent PCs lagging. Netcode setting should also be on prioritize response by default. I also have issues with my controller when tabbing out and tabbing back in.

The best stages I've seen in a FG, pretty graphics and vfx, a 32 char launch, and different customization/expression options make this a great pick for me. Tough to get into, but it's pretty great. Definitely feels like another next gen AAA fighter despite being a tiny bit rough around the edges.

Tekken 8 is a marked improvement over T7, and I held that game in the highest of regards. Deep, yet accessible, gameplay with an amazing and deep cast of playable characters at launch. Amazing overall package, and the best in the genre for my money.

If it weren't for the poor customization options (even less than T7) it would have been possibly the best Tekken game ever made. Although I'm a veteran of the series, it's great to see all the new tool tips and general improvement of the practice mode. From frame data, to detailed info for each move, or tips on how to punish properly make this the friendliest Tekken has ever been to new comers without compromising its core and complex gameplay.
yas good
BRILLIANT!

How best to describe Tekken 8? In one sentence: Tekken 8 is Tekken 7 version 2.0. And that is a GREAT thing!

The graphics are insane, the fighters have so much more expression and personality. The sound design is even better then Tekken 7. And in my opinion, that's saying something! Netcode has drastically been improved. Combine this with crossplay, and you'll have a match in a second. Even WiFi is decent (most of the time). Tekken 8 introduces some new mechanics, which I think is a good thing. I'm kinda sad about the rage drives being gone, but the new Heat system gives alot of flexibility every single round. 

Single player is sorta meh. They added a whole "tutorial" campaign in Arcade Quest, which I didn't much care for, but is great for new Tekken players. The story is not my cup of tea, but not bad. I love the characters, but the storyline feels like a bad fanfiction. The cutscenes are straight up banging tho. Oh, and the customization of the characters feels a bit lackluster. But to be fair, that is comparing Tekken 8 at launch with Tekken 7 after 5 seasons of content.

So yeah, I know I'm biased. I fell in love with Tekken with Tekken 7 (1000+ hours) and this just feels like the successor I wanted for that game. Easily the best FG of 2024 and with a bit of luck, the best Tekken in the series so far. Definity recommend, even if your a casual fighting game fan!

I been around with this franchise as a kid since Tekken 4 coming back and forth with it. But consistently it has been one of my favorite fighting games to get into, especially 8 which is the most beginner friendly one I have played yet. I hope to see more familiar characters in the roster but genuinely one of the few games I can say I don't care if my friends don't get into it, I still love it. Not scummy combo things like smash bros, or needing much of a manual to learn how to play like street fighter. I can't stress enough how beginner friendly this game is for most fighting game enthusiasts

Its good to see a fighting game that can still both interest new players and players who haven't played a good fighting game in a long time. Tekken 7 was good but lets face it, we needed something fresh and appealing to everyone.
Its a more advanced fighting game than the usual but it just feels good to play even in practice mode when you're warming up. Combos and inputs slowly get complicated but reward it in terms of output and set play, but it is a tekken game so its expected.
With my utter demonstration of an entitled opinion, this is better than both Mortal Kombat and Street Fighter, would recommend to even people who are new to fighting games.
(And yes, even my fellow Blazblue and Guilty Gear friends would enjoy this.)

For those who weren't impressed by Tekken 7's story mode, Tekken 8 presents a vast improvement. Not just with the main story, but with character episodes as well. They're no longer 1 battle ordeals with lackluster endings. They are now a series of 5 battles with wonderfully animated CG endings.

The only con is that Tekken, as far as fighters go, is still one of the more difficult to learn and master. That being said, if you are willing to put the effort in, you'll be rewarded accordingly.

((WARNING: SLIGHT SPOILERS AHEAD))

The King Of Iron Fist Tournament 8 has arrived and it truly is a fight against the tides of evil. A much needed step in the right direction, Tekken 8 gives you the best bang for your buck next gen Tekken experience. Leading up to the game's release I had genuinely set my standards pretty low with the amount of characters from the previous game I liked being cut out (and likely later slated for DLC) and all the talk about this 'arcade quest' mode (which upon playing I still didn't care for) but once I actually got the game and played it upon its launch day I can safely say it definitely blew my expectations out of the water. The fighting is much more improved over the previous game, whereas the rage art almost feels more like a crutch they seem to make the blocking much more effective than the previous title; whilst adding a sort of mini rage art called a heat burst in which you can use to chip off a sizable amount of damage. But that's not even talking about the amazing range of detail and snappy and genuinely realistic movement in the animation department. This game is absolutely stunning and boasts that every character ending has a fully animated, somewhat beautiful cutscene and it sure does. This genuinely looks like a huge step up compared to the previous installment, I can see Jin's pores now! This is a game I feel I can surely come back to in a few years and see that the cgi hasn't aged one bit. It genuinely flows really well in and out of gameplay that at moments I almost forget that I'm in a cutscene and get really amped up and start pressing buttons in anticipation for the next battle. I also think they've massively improved the story mode by making each chapter feel genuinely meaningful and have it flow well as a story. In the last game I kinda felt the game had this problem with overexplaining what was happening and also giving us these story mode battles that felt kinda unfocused to the main plot at hand and it was honestly kind of a hassle to get through at times while this one keeps you on the edge of your seat focused on this whole Devil Kazuya world domination plot. My only genuine gripe with the story mode is chapter 10 almost being similar to that of the Tekken Force mode from previous installments in which they try to make the characters have a wider range of movement fighting an onslaught of enemies, but still kinda falling in this idea that they want to keep your character on an axis, I don't know about you, but I think that controls really weird and disorienting, but I really liked in-story that while this is happening, all these small battles are also happening that you get to take control of which offers more traditional Tekken gameplay. And while I may not like the gameplay of chapter 10 nearly as much as the rest of the game, I can say those moments at least feel more meaningful than yet another onslaught of JACK-6s that just so happen to drop in. The story flows genuinely super well and keeps you hooked with all its fun character interactions and somewhat twists it throws your way. I also want to mention the lack of Heihachi. I think if he were in this story it simply wouldn't nearly be as effective as I was more excited for the feud between Kazuya & Jin, that being the main focus of the game. These characters finally get to duel at like full power and it's a much wanted to see fight as a Tekken fan. It really has the intensity and satisfaction you're looking for in a story like this one. Very much recommended for people trying to get into the series, Tekken fans, and fighting game enthusiasts in general. It has about everything you'd want in a Tekken game and comparatively to the other Tekkens on the market currently, I'd honestly say just get this one. It even seems from the first day's online issues they kind of patched it up because since then I've had no problem playing online with my friends, even if it means having to find them through the dreaded arcade quest mode for simplicity's sake. It also plays more fun than the past 3 installments and satisfies any and all story itches you'd be looking for in a new Tekken game (minus Mokujin) and I'm seriously looking forward to all the new things they have in store updates & DLC-wise.

Story mode is fun but has a lot of growing pains that slapping special style on everything doesn't really fix.

Buying the game super early alongside Tekken diehards means Ranked is still getting figured out so you're going to be pit against people -way- out of your skill level. The AI you fight to get your power level gives nothing, I've had multiple friends tell me they got put in beginner and they are in Maurauder and higher in T7.

Once you finish the offline content, there's really not much to do as a new player for a while because online is just going to be out of skill range.

Otherwise the game has great presentation, feels good, and I would infinitely argue to buy this or Street Fighter over Mortal Kombat 1.

10/10
Edit -
After playing the game for almost 40 hours, as well as finishing the story mode.
I can't express how emotional this game made me. I can't put it in words besides expressing it with, it's damn perfect. It's some REAL good ass Tekken.

Story:
The Tekken story was never really known for the stories besides the occasional fathers throwing their sons out of cliffs or into volcanos, and even with quite a few plotholes to the lore, it depicts the story in an epic way with some good naration and BADASS cinematics and fights!
Made me feel like when watching Dragon Ball Z or Naruto as a kid and had me hyped through the whole thing.

Gameplay: 
I've tried a few fighters besides Tekken, like MK11, Street Fighter 5 & 6, KOF14 and some of the older KOF games, but man... No fighting game feels as good and epic as Tekken, this is my humble biased opinion, but DAMN! Only Tekken can scratch this itch, and with the implementation of the heat system, that kinda forces you to play much more aggresive than the predecessor games, it's gotten so much more fun! They also made quite a few moves easier for certain characters, which imo is welcome.

Gamemodes:
I've only done first chapter of the Arcade story to unlock super ghost battle, and I havent tried other gamemodes besides online rank matches or online sessions with several of my friends, so I can't speak for them all. However, it sure is fun to play vs your own ghost or other players ghost.

Online:
In Day 1, expectedly servers wasn't too stable cause of the inflation of players on the servers, however, now that there's less people on, it's really damn good! Connection is super solid for me when I play ranked matches, even vs console players or wifi players. Big step up from T7.

Final Score:
MAAN I'm a unapologetic biased Tekken fan, so easy 10/10, where as T7 was more like a 8/10. This game has everything I wanted. More juicier combos, smoother combat/gameplay, and juicy graphics. No need to wait for sale. (Actually if you don't make a lot of money, you might wanna wait a bit, I had the luxury to afford it this time around)

This is by far the hugest step up from T7.

Pros:

- The Story. It's leagues better than T7's trainwreck of a clickbait news article.
- Gameplay. 
- Character Episodes are WAY better than T7's by far.
- Tekken Ball makes a grand return
- Newcomers are fantastic (Victor's my personal favorite)
- The Roster is good as well for the most part
- I hate to admit it, but they slightly improved upon Shaheen. (Key word: Slightly. He still sucks personality-wise.)
- The visuals are outstanding as all hell.
- Avatar customization is something I never thought I would like in Tekken.
- Incredible OST (Rising Storm/Pave Your Way is my personal favorite)
- Jukebox being included on all platforms

Cons:

- The customization is still limited compared to T7's. But hey, we can take solace in the fact that there are new features in customization.

Overall Score:

11/10 Absolutely incredible.
