I owed 7 this review after 'discovering' it late, and now that it no longer matters, I thought I'd toss this out relatively early after the release of 8 to show my approval.  It's clear so far the Tekken 'formula' is still there and going strong with the latest. And while this new heat system is a little different and will take some getting used-to, it seems to fit in nicely with everything so far, and I can tell I will be regularly revisiting this game over its lifetime.

The graphics look great, but are making my card's age (radeon vega64) a factor.  I can maintain a steady 60FPS @ 1440p with reduced rendering scale and all other settings on max, so I'd still say it looks beautiful and runs well on this card.  It may still drive an upgrade for me, though.

I played Tekken 2, 3, tag and 4, back in the late PS1, early PS2 days, when it was a great party/roommate game for me and my friends at that stage in our lives.  Then, after shifting to PC, and getting away from fighting games altogether, I was pleasantly surprised when trying 7 on a whim late in its life and finding out the fundamentals are still there and solid as ever, and the online matchmaking, despite its flaws, was good enough to feel like dabbling in.  This has carried over into T8 from what I can see already, and am already as hooked to the online/ranked system there as I had gotten with the previous.

As an adult with a life and a job, who will not be pursuing any fame or prize money from video games, this particular style of online competitive play still feels good to me.  The matchmaking is fast and has gotten even faster in 8, and the matches themselves are also fast - you're playing many matches in a sitting, and the inevitable reality of the 50-50 win-loss rate (that every online player in every competitive game must learn to cope with) doesn't feel so bad with the quick turnaround.  This is more of a general fighting game vs other competitive game style point, but it feels like Tekken's devs understand this and have designed with it in mind, which I appreciate.

There is single player content in this game, too.  There is a lore behind the characters in the game, but it's ridiculous.  I think it's ridiculous for the sake of being ridiculous, but it's hard to say.  Either way, it looks beautiful, and it's fun, and the arcade quest and ghost battles are a good way to get into the casual beginnings of online ladder play, which is where the real fun with these games is to be found.

Tekken is my favorite fighting game, and if they stick with the formula they've got nailed down, it will stay that way for years to come.

First time playing a fighting game in 20+ years.  Played the hell out of Tekken 1, 2 and 3 back in the day.  Mostly 3.  

It feels like Tekken, having a great time.  Getting my ass beat, but it's great.  

I would definitely recommend this game to any other older folks like me.  The tutorials in this game are very good and so is the training hall.  

The characters all still have their own styles and personalities, and the game leans hard into this.  The appearance customization is also pretty damn good.  

If you have an itch to pick a game and build some skill, I recommend this 100%.  I'm more of a survival RPG / isometric cRPG person, but even I'm having a blast here.  

Oh the Arcade Lobby is pretty cool.  Reminds me of walking around arcades when I was a stupid 90s teen.  

Just be prepared for some trolls and cocky kids who are high ranking but only know one combo.  Some things never change lol.  Most people are great though.  Good time all around.

In short, an outstanding return to form for the series and one of the best entries in decades. 

Tekken 8 is held firmly by more of the deep, technical, and ultimately satisfying gameplay the series is known for, made even more exciting to both play and spectate with the new Heat System. All three newcomers are well designed and evoke nostalgia whilst bringing something to Tekken never seen before. The training and replay systems are extremely robust, promoting intuitive learning without tedium. The graphics are stunning, boasting high quality character models with a noticeable improvement in the stages themselves.

However, the game is marred by its mediocre single player. The story mode is a fun 4 hour romp, and leans heavily into shonen anime tropes, which can make it polarizing for players not already invested in the story. The character episodes are simply 5 AI fights to watch a 45 second ending, and can be tedious just to find out your favorite character gets a silly cutaway gag as an ending. Arcade Quest is a short tutorial mode that does its job decently, but fails to deliver how exciting high level gameplay can be or give a player a better reason to sit down and learn the fundamentals rather than to just go online and mash buttons. I will say that something is better than nothing over Tekken 7's absolute lack of a tutorial mode.

The online netcode is markedly better than Tekken 7, but the netcode still isn't up to snuff with near perfect implementations of its competitors, namely Guilty Gear Strive and Street Fighter 6. An unfortunate side effect of the high fidelity graphics is that if your opponent's PC struggles with performance, you also feel it as well to keep the game in sync. Many players online do not optimize their graphics settings leading to unplayable matches, exacerbated by poor wifi connections. The online play experience is passable, but I will applaud the vast improvement over Tekken 7. It's fine and playable but not perfect.

Despite this, Tekken 8 still has some of the most exciting gameplay in the gaming market today. It hits all the important points of a fighting game as hard as it can, while making decent attempts at welcoming and retaining new players with more single player options and improved netcode. All of this adds up to be a outstanding game I will be playing for many years to come.

As an off again on again Tekken fan I was only semi excited for 8's release, but as more and more features were presented I realized just what a beast this game actually is. Every aspect of this game was designed by people who love the franchise, and it absolutely shows. 

Fighting games can certainly feel like "more of the same" when the next iteration drops, but every part of T8 has changed (at least slightly) and after some time with the beta and now full game, I can confidently say it has changed for the better.

The loading is insanely fast, the graphics and flare are top quality, even the story this time around was a blast. However, the one defining set of features that make Tekken 8 the BEST fighting game out there are its practice tools. 

My god, to say they went above and beyond is [i]not[/i] doing it justice. The practice mode bot is super customizable, there's wiff punishing training, followup training, combo trainings for each character, ghost fighting, and oh my god it just keeps going! These features are doing massive work, helping newer (or even older and just not as good players like myself) learn how to play Tekken to its fullest potential.

The one specific training tool that needs a callout is Replays. You can watch your recent matches sure, but you can also PAUSE AND HAVE IT TELL YOU WHAT YOU COULD HAVE DONE BETTER. And as if that wasn't the coolest thing yet, you can then TAKE CONTROL of EITHER CHARACTER and play out the next 10 seconds! I cannot stress enough just how cool and USEFUL this is when learning. 

So yes, absolutely recommend, even if you're not a Tekken fan. Even if you hate online there's a full campaign, full arcade campaign, 32 character battles, arcade mode, ghost fight mode, etc etc. I don't know what the future holds for Tekken 8, but I am excited and confident that it will be bright.

Arguably the best Tekken game to ever release.
I felt like with Tekken 7 a lot of the aesthetic and identity was lost. 
Tekken 4, 5, 6 and TT2 had amazing identity, graphics and style that made Tekken what it was.
8 brings back its style, identity and flow that we've all been missing in T7.

The roster consists of 32 characters, each with their own unique fighting style, moves, and combos. It holds a rich story mode, a variety of online and offline modes, and stunning graphics and sound.

Story mode picks up where Tekken 7 left off, with the final showdown between Kazuya Mishima and his father Heihachi Mishima. We explore the origins of the Mishima family feud, the secrets of the Devil Gene and its orgins as well as the fate of Jin Kazama, who is missing after the events of Tekken 7. The story is presented in a cinematic style, with fully voiced cutscenes and dynamic battles. 

Gameplay is fast-paced, fluid, and responsive, with a balance of offense and defense. There are new mechanics, such as the Heat mechanic, which allows the player to unleash powerful attacks as well as recovering health, chip damage and Power Crush, which allows the player to absorb some damage and continue their attack. The game also has a variety of stages, each with their own environmental hazards and transitions.

Online mode is robust and smooth, with a ranking system, a replay, and a spectator mode. We also have cross-play between different platforms, allowing players to challenge each other regardless of their device. Sounds are impressive and immersive, with realistic character models, detailed animations, and expressive facial expressions. There are diverse and dynamic soundtrack, featuring rock, techno, and orchestral music.  The voice cast is of talented actors, who deliver their lines with emotion and personality.


To sum this overall great package:
Positives:
+ Amazing gameplay
+ Phenomenal Design and graphics
+ Stages, characters and moves are perfect
+ Tekken Ball
+ Online Lounge and online modes in general are smooth except Day 1 Release
+ We can use all Tekken soundtracks in the game from T1 all the way to T7 and 8
+ The Story is awesome. Really well done.
+ Easy to get into. Arcade Quest and the tutorial really help out bringing the best in you. It's easy to practice, easy to learn and very hard to master.
+ The Ghosts AI is actually capable and useful. What a great design choice and implementation.

On the negative side:
- Not enough customisation options. T6 is still the GOAT in that regard
- No Tekken Force
- The sound of punches isn't as satisfying as T7 but it's good enough still

Tekken 8 is a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike, as it offers a satisfying and thrilling fighting game experience. The game has a lot of content and replay value, as well as a deep and engaging story. The game is a masterpiece of the genre, and a fitting conclusion to the saga of the Mishima family.

Do you wanna see a father & son battle better than baki, Invincible or the real life? (because at some point some of us had beef with our dads/sons)

Then welcome to Tekken 8, filled with an impressive story where the main Protagonist-turned-Antagonist-turned Protagonist Jin Kazama faces off His father Kazuya Mishima, the story rolls around 6 months later timeskip after Tekken 7 story when Kazuya successfully murdered his father Heihachi Mishima.

This game as most gaming channels call it is a game changer for the next generation of fighting games and for me...this game is the next generation of making people rage quit in a different way, call me cocky but this game is fun, it features:

- father and son beef
- character story what ifs (some are canon than the other)
- Limited costumes than previous games (maybe in future updates they'll add more)
- Plot twists
- ships
- crying after losing a ranked match with broken fingers after combo-ing so much for nothing
- Combo-ing to the point people report you that you're cheating and never utilize that you're just THAT GOOD
- restless hours of playing
- And for some reason this game is really satisfying to play at night no matter the country you're living on, it just feels so satisfying

Overall if you're planning to kys, play this game first and then decide if you actually want to. I'm not a masochist myself, but I can be sadistic if you find me in online matches, no hard feelings players, I'm just playing the game!

The most feature-rich, accessible, graphically advanced, aesthetically pleasing, responsive, funny, ultimately satisfying Tekken game ever made. And this is only the beginning. The new era of Tekken is here!

Tekken 8 is, in my humble opinion, the best tekken...gameplay wise.

The story mode is okay, but has so many tweaks to health values and lets you spam supers 3 times back to back, sometimes more. It's one of THOSE where the story mode itself plays nothing like the actual game.

The customization is....alright. You can recolor most costumes, but it has less customization than even Tekken 7, which was less than half than that of Tekken 6 already. It feels like customization is becoming less and less of a feature and more of a "well people expect it so we HAVE to have it." but there's little other than colors and a handful of really poorly modeled accessories.

The Alternate modes are...sparse. The ghost battles are very limited and the Ai is too easy. I was able to consistently beat the highest ranked ghost in the game easily, even with characters I've barely used in the past, and I'm not a great player by any means. The character stories are literally 5 matches fought in the same arena with an ending cutscene with no real story relevance.

So...why am I reccomending the game? Because the core gameplay is some GOOD ASS TEKKEN.

It's the legacy-skill-heavy, Beat-faces-in, get-mixed-for-days, turn-that-jin-into-a-win, Lili-more-like-shutup-frenchwoman-you-smelly-baguette Tekken you've known and loved, but more refined, and more aggressive.

[b]Pretty good package all around. But I am deeply hurt to say, no Tekken Ball online. Only Local.[/b]

[b] Main story shows love to fun side characters.[/b]  Story itself isn't really that interesting, but there's a lot of effort put in it to make it a fun display.

[b] There's another game mode called Character Episodes. Short CGI endings are back and they look great, however it still feels like a "fun little side thing".[/b]  It could have used more matches than five, could get a little harder at the end as it doesn't feel like a real game mode but something to do for casuals. I don't like that idea, I think even casuals would like to overcome some challenge, which would make them more likely to play online. Nevermind that, they could actually advance characters' storylines instead of repeating the same old feuds. So there's not much really new, would absolutely be more fun if you had no idea what Tekken is, I guess. But it's way better than Tekken 7 at the very least. 

[b] Arcade mode is a tiny bit better in the matter of gameplay[/b], eight battles that are a lot more challenging, but I don't really see why you would play it again after you've seen it once, especially when there's Super Ghost Battle.

[b] Super Ghost Battle is truly fun, you can download someone elses ghost you face online, you can basically download a bunch of good players and make an Endless Mode of your own.[/b] Of course they are still not the carbon copy of the player and act slower, but they use similar tactics and make similar mistakes, so it is a very useful tool to break down the opponent's patterns.

[b] I think the biggest achievement of Tekken 8 is that they've done everything they could to teach the game.[/b]  Streamlined a lot of characters' game plan, added Heat as a last resort for choking newcomers and turned it into an actual fun mechanic so it isn't a burden on experienced players, the practice mode is great, being able to watch replays is great, you can even take control during a replay to try a different approach, it's really amazing how much thought they put into it. [b]Arcade Quest, while it condescendingly babies the player with Mii characters, sets up well thought tutorial matches to show you the ropes.[/b] It still doesn't break down everything, but at least it is character specific and gives you a good idea of what to expect. It's nice if you're someone who never played a fighting game and want to avoid studying a video game. It gives you the basics however it still won't teach you everything about your character, or about actual bastard plays people make in Ranked.


[b]I'm very positive about the gameplay itself[/b], while I think the visuals are cluttered and Rage Art cutscenes are annoying because it forces you to watch a customized anime character do a bunch of generic bullshit whose shameful creator is surely jerking off during that whole minute, [b]I think this game allows a larger variety of gamestyles than Tekken 7.[/b] Turtling is not unbeatable anymore. You can sidestep, power crush, throw, and most importantly use explosive moves like King's or Paul's punches to stagger the enemy and put pressure on a blocking player or fish for openings. There's still a lot of times when it feels unfair, like when a character pulls up with something in a confusing mix-up, a trap for you to lower your guard to punish you for a simple jab, and spams that because it's the easy thing to do, but I do not think a fighting game can ever be truly balanced without being boring.

[b]Network connection is fine in general, but it doesn't deal with high ping extremely well. I wouldn't try to play this with a friend in a far country.[/b]

Of course, this game is a precedent reputation among fighting games in terms of performance and style of play and combat, but this time and in this series, it exceeded my expectations in terms of speed of performance and comprehension and they specially put an unreal engine 5, which increased its aesthetics and gave clarity and a real feel in terms of characters, places and  Specifically, the characters in the story are real. I salute the staff, including Mr. Katsuhiro Harada, who entertained us all these times with this great work, and I hope he will continue to do more of and create a wonderful game of this great series. ---TL;DR Review---

The Good:  Moment to Moment gameplay is good, the Heat and Rage systems are fun to play with, and everything plays very well.

The Bad:  The campaign mode still sucks.  Get ready for 30 Jin vs Kaz fights with little to differentiate them.

Overall:  Great fighting game with an archaic single player offering.  I didn't play Arcade Quest, but frankly I wanted a cool ending to the Devil Gene storyline and this just simply isn't one.

Tekken 8 is a real treat for any fan of the franchise, with little nods and homages to it's previous instalations and a true celebration of how good can fighting games still be. Not only it respects it's audience, It's also an improvement over it's predecessor in every single way and stands alongside 3 as the best game in the series. 

Not enough people praising how a game that looks this good is running this well as well. I don't think I've seen many games look as stylish and as beautiful as this game does. The movements and combos are meaty, the sounds are punchy and give feedback, a real technical marvel.

I only wished there were more unlockables like the old school entries, it would feel much better unlocking the characters as you finish stuff as it also would give you an incentive to play more on the down times and to give more meaning to complete other modes. The online functionality is working perfectly, had absolutely no problems playing against strangers and friends alike, except for getting my butt kicked, but that's a granted. 

If you're still not convinced, remember it still has Kuma in it, and if that doesn't convince you, I don't know what will.

I haven't seriously played tekken since Tekken Tag was new game on ps2. I have to say this game is amazing, this game is the total package for a fighting game, like the jukebox which holds every Tekken ost ever made. The awesome character customization (i made my king look like cena), The game has 3 seperate story modes. AI ghost training and even more. Not to mention the stellar combat system. If you even kind of like tekken and havent played in awhile or are completely new. This is the one to jump in on. seriously.

Tekken 8 is an incredible experience, especially for returning players and new players. Introduces many systems designed to level-up player skills in an incredibly deep and complex game. If there ever is a perfect time to get into Tekken, this is it.

Personnaly, I played T2, T3, TTT1. Was pretty good at it... then T4 came out and it literally sucked out my passion for Tekken. Went back at T7 and almost immediately dropped the game due to its frustrating online + I never got used to the walls introduced in T4.

T8 is a whole different beast! I've clocked in pretty much 20 hours in two days and have barely scratched its surface. I rarely clock this amount of time, now that I'm older. Despite the game still having walls/floors and being crappy (<10% win rate online), I just keep going and going. I can feel that energy of wanting to be better. I've selected a couple of characters, but focusing on one to really get good at. With the tools/modes they provide, I'm sure I'll get there.

The game runs smoothly. Story is great. Only critics are that I wish dialogue would be always in english as an option available and cinematics / gameplay could be more than 60 fps. I highly recommend this game.
Fighting GOTY has just arrived

First off, I'm not a day one Tekken fan. I played Tekken 4 at friends'  house and always enjoyed the game but my child brain couldn't get the combos and tactics. Fast-forward some years and Tekken 7 was one of my most played games of all time. I love the competitiveness of the community, the effort it takes to truly master a character, and the bizarre storyline. Tekken 8 didn't knock it out of the park but I definitely am satisfied with my purchase. 

Pros:
Beautiful game with a hype ass soundtrack
Combat is intuitive and rewarding 
Each fighter is beaming with personality especially the new characters 
The practice system is great and it's nice not having to pay for frame data lol
Cons:
New heat system allows for people to steal turns with the press of a button. 
The Visual effects are OD sometimes. 
The combat is good but the fighters don't feel like they have weight to them. 

All in all it's a great game. If you want to get into fighting games, this is a great start.

=== ENGLISH ===

Let me start by saying that I am a long-time, non-competitive SoulCalibur player.
I decided to give TEKKEN 8 a change after trying the demo. I'll tell you, on paper I appreciated the changes introduced compared to the predecessors and the excellent entry level in the single player mode, the Ghosts with AI...
For Singleplayer or to play with friends, nothing to say.

However...

For me it's a huge NO, to version 1.1.2, at least as regards multiplayer and character balance; which should then be the pinnacle of experience in games of this type nowadays.

On the one hand there is a Netcode that is too unstable and ruins the gaming experience, so the results of a match can be overturned too easily.

On the other hand there is a fairly obvious problem with the fighters.
I realize that, as in all fighting games, there are characters that are more optimal than others for one reason or another, and that many times developers can make mistakes in their creation (the times of Leroy Smith in TEKKEN 7 at the first release speak for themselves, or when they introduced Akuma without any rework)...BUT THIS TIME, it seems clear to me that the DEVs haven't really reasoned or, if they have, they have reasoned very badly because many of the characters in the rouster are :

-extremely simplified in the execution of their combos (Law is embarrassing for how quick and simple he is, to name one out of many);
- advantaged over others in their game mechanics (King and Azucena can make too much use of air combos, in a game where they should have been reduced to the bare bones and which promised to change the approach to gameplay);
- made unstoppable due to the animation frames which do not physically allow you to build an adequate defense or punishment, creating too many differences in the final game experience between one character and another.

Even putting effort into learning a character's kit well (without using assisted mode) is pointless, since you can play the most advantaged characters in that mode and make them even more awkward than they already are.
It doesn't matter if they do little damage, they enter an eternal loop of animations in which you can't find any opening and are unable to deliver a punishment.

I wonder what was the point of revolutionizing the game by removing pokes, air combos, giving such a substantial rooster and revolutionizing everything, if we then end up with this imbalance.

Truly a disappointment.
I'll only play it for Singleplayer, I'll be honest.


---


=== ITALIAN ===

Premetto che sono un giocatore di vecchia data di SoulCalibur, non competitivo.
Ho deciso di dare una change a TEKKEN 8 dopo aver provato la demo. Vi dirò, sulla carta ho apprezzato i cambiamenti introdotti rispetto ai predecessori e l'ottimo entry level nella modalità Singleplayer; per giocarci con gli amici o da solo, nulla da dire insomma.

PERO'...no.

Per me è un gigantesco NO, alla versione 1.1.2, almeno per quanto concerne il Multiplayer e il bilanciamento dei personaggi; che poi dovrebbe essere il culmine dell'esperienza in giochi di questo tipo.

Da una parte c'è un Netcode troppo ballerino e che rovina l'esperienza, quindi i risultati di un match possono essere ribaltati troppo facilmente.

Dall'altra c'è un problema abbastanza palese con i combattenti.
Mi rendo conto che, come in tutti i picchiaduro, ci sono personaggi che sono più ottimali di altri per un motivo o per un'altro, e che tante volte gli sviluppatori possono compiere degli errori nella loro creazione (i tempi di Leroy Smith in TEKKEN 7 al primo rilascio parlano da soli, o quando introdussero Akuma senza alcun rework)...MA QUESTA VOLTA, mi sembra palese che i DEVs non hanno proprio ragionato o, se lo hanno fatto, hanno ragionato malissimo perché molti dei personaggi nel rouster sono:

- estremamente semplificati nell'esecuzione delle loro combo (Law è imbarazzante per quanto è rapido e semplice, per citarne uno su tanti);
- avvantaggiati rispetto ad altri nelle loro meccaniche di gioco (King e Azucena possono fare troppo uso delle air combo, in un gioco dove dovrebbero essere state ridotte all'osso e che si riprometteva di cambiare approccio al gameplay);
- resi inarrestabili per via dei frame delle animazioni che non consentono fisicamente di costruire una difesa o trovare aperture per un punishment adeguato, creando troppe differenze nell'esperienza di gioco finale tra un personaggio e l'altro.

Anche impegnarsi ad imparare bene il kit di un personaggio (senza usare la modalità assistita) è inutile, dato che i personaggi più avvantaggiati puoi giocarli con quella modalità e renderli ancora più imbarazzanti di quanto non siano già. 
Non importa se fanno poco danno, tanto entrano in un loop eterno di animazioni in cui non riesci a trovare alcuna apertura e sei impossibilitato da assestare un punishment.

Io mi chiedo a che cosa sia servito rivoluzionare il gioco rimuovendo i poke, le air combo, dare un rooster così sostanzioso e rivoluzionare tutto, se poi ci si ritrova con questo squilibrio.
Veramente una delusione. 

Lo giocherò solo per il Singleplayer, sarò sincero.

Get ready for the next battle!

However, the only con i see here is the customization which is not unique to each character, having universal customization shared by all characters seems lazy. but its still good, there's lot to choose from, also free (unlocked by in game currency) and better than any fighting game in the market in my opinion.

I'm not the biggest tekken guys, I've dabbled in the series here and there but I never fully commited to an entry. I did like what I've played though.

But God Damn this is the real deal. Probably the most fun I've had with a fighting game since Guitly Gear Strive. Highly recommend it even if you're a casual player like me. It's alot more feature rich than T7 was.

The most innovative Tekken, since Tekken4 for sure. Love the game as a Tekken fan from Tekken2. All the team really did an amazing job, make look Tekken 7 like from previous century with graphics, story, fun element, offline modes, innovative stuff, new stuff etc. Amazing Harada and Michael Murray and your whole team!

Edit: PSA for all PC players on keyboard, try mapping 1234 (punches and kicks) to keys on the same row, so you can use all 4 fingers at the same time without moving. Controllers will never make sense to me in a game that requires you to flow between button combinations.

Ghost AI of other players. That's the best feature of the game. Even if you are shy and intimidated by the game's hardcore reputation, you can play alone in Acrade Quest and button mash in offline for hours of fun before the difficulty goes up and you start thinking about looking up and practicing normal combos. Then you notice walls are a problem so you look up wall combos. Then counter-hit combos etc. I am no serious fighting game player, but the gradual transition towards higher-level play, all while offline, was so smooth. Winning against ghosts gave me confidence as well, and by the time I joined ranked online play, apart from connection spikes, I was already winning. I recommend the youtube video called "Learning Any Character ~ Tekken 7" from Zug to understand the fundamentals of the series. 10 frames for a jab, ~15 frames for a launch, that kind of thing always seemed too intimidating to learn, but they come naturally with a well-featured Practice mode that lets you try punishing enemy moves, and a helpful Replay mode where you can review your mistakes and retry mid-replay.

 I am a convert.

I don't know how to put this but this game, it just has a way of getting exactly the right way on my nerves. In a good way! No other game makes me so angry at myself when I lose overwhelmingly, no other game feels this good to win at when you're doing well. I've screamed F me so many times because of how bad I still am at Tekken. And yet, I keep coming back.
No matter how crazy the previous rage quit hits me, I'll never say no to a new challenger. Happy to say it was worth the money! I liked 7 well enough, but this one is on a whole other level entirely, the expressiveness is through the roof! Flowcharts still exist of course but now it feels way more distinct when someone is obviously following one. It's like I can tell exactly what my opponent is thinking through their actions sometimes!! You don't get that in many games, certainly not most fighting games!
100% worth the wait. One of the best, if not the best, Tekken game of all time. 10/10

I played through the Story mode and I can say without a doubt this is the first Tekken game I've ever really loved. The transition between cinematics and gameplay were incredible, and the game has some of the best graphics I've ever seen with amazing sound design. The music got me really worked up during key moments.

The story was epic from start to finish, with effective tropes from anime and comic-book movies that keep us coming back. It was a truly international ensemble, with every character speaking in their own language - and about everyone had their turn in the spotlight, while managing to not stray far from the father and son driving it all. 

Even as a relative newcomer, I found the story very accessible thanks to a recap cinematic mode and some lines from characters that summarized their past. But I was familiar enough with the series to appreciate some callbacks. Gameplay wise, I kept the newbie-friendly "Special Style" mode on most of the time which let me pull off flashy combos with ease.
